heading: Tesla (TSLA) 'obviously' plans to take on Uber and Lyft, says CEO Elon Musk
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) more
Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced his company’s plans to join the self driving car market after a better-than-expected Q3 earnings report. Musk said the decision was “obvious,” saying that the company will maintain a fleet of autonomous vehicles capable of providing rides.
CNBC provides insight:
While full self-driving tech is still in development, Tesla’s newest Autopilot Navigate features will enable drivers to automatically change lanes, handle forks in the road and take highway exits along a planned route, according to Tesla VP of Engineering Stuart Bowers who spoke on the third-quarter earnings call alongside Musk.
Tesla shares boosted 12 percent after the exciting earnings report. The company already possesses “driver assistance” available cars that can take care of some tasks but retains the need for drivers to hold the wheel.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $314.86 per share on Thursday afternoon, up $26.36 (+9.14%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 1.13%, versus a 2.50% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #3 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shares Rise After Earnings Beat
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) delivered a surprising earnings beat after the bell on Wednesday, and shares popped as a result. more
CNBC has the details on the electric vehicle maker’s results.
Tesla shares soared by more than 12 percent after the company reported a surprise profit for the third quarter as CEO Elon Musk made good on his promise to start turning regular profits in the last half of the year.
The company’s earnings report, released after the markets closed Wednesday, also showed better-than expected car sales and a faster timeline on its Model 3 production. The electric car maker said its midsize Model 3 sedan, which it hopes to produce on mass scale, was the best-selling car in the U.S. when measured by revenue and the fifth best-selling car in terms of volume.
For the quarter, Tesla reported revenue of  $6.82 billion and earnings of $2.90 per share. Analysts were expecting a top line of  $6.33 billion and a loss of 19 cents per share. On a call with analysts, Musk referred to it as an “incredibly historic quarter.”
Tesla Inc shares rose $26.50 (+9.19%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -7.34%, versus a 0.72% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #3 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Analyst Places Outperform Rating on Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has received a vote of confidence from JMP Securities in the form of an outperform rating. more
CNBC passes along the firm’s take on the electric vehicle maker.
JMP Securities gave Tesla shares a new outperform rating on Wednesday, citing the automaker’s collection of top talent and competition that continues to lag behind Elon Musk’s electric car manufacturer.
JMP’s message to buy Tesla comes hours before the company will report third-quarter earnings on an earlier date than expected.
JMP’s Joseph Osha provided insight in a note to clients. “Stretched balance sheet, but we think Tesla can make it. The combination of the Model 3 ramp, capital spending plans, and pending debt repayments have left Tesla in a difficult position,” Osha wrote. “Our detailed modeling suggests the company can make it through the next 18 months without having to raise money, but there is little room for error. We believe the company would be well served by raising several billion dollars in additional equity capital.”
Tesla Inc shares rose $9.86 (+3.35%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.53%, versus a 3.87% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #2 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla (TSLA) stock jumps after legendary short seller flips position
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has won over a Citron Research’s Andrew Left, who has shorted the stock for years and is also suing the company.more
Andrew Left has revealed that he is betting the stock will rise, and that he thinks it is the only company that can buy and sell electric cars. Left is simultaneously suing Tesla for an August 7th tweet by Elon Musk about taking the company private. Left claims Musk did this with the intention of manipulating stock prices.
CNBC provides details:
“Citron is long Tesla as the Model 3 is a proven hit and many of the TSLA warning signs have proven not to be significant,” said Left in a blog post Tuesday. “Plain and simple – Tesla is destroying the competition.”
“TSLA is not just pulling customers from BMW and Mercedes but also from Toyota and Honda. Like a magic trick, while everyone is focused on Elon smoking weed, he is quietly smoking the whole automotive industry,” the short seller added.
After an extremely volatile year, Tesla stocks got a boost in light of CEO Elon Musk’s settlement with the SEC.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $294.14 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $33.19 (+12.72%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.53%, versus a 3.87% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #5 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: How did Tesla (TSLA) get its name?
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is named in honor of the great inventor, Nikola Tesla.more
Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor who invented the AC electric motor that Tesla vehicles utilize. Tesla immigrated to the United States in 1884 and started his career working for Thomas Edison, where he helped Edison improve his DC power system.
Fox Business provides details:
Tesla and Edison eventually had a falling out after Edison dismissed Tesla’s proposed plans to utilize an AC power system, leading to Tesla’s decision to join Westinghouse Electric Company and marking the start of the “War of Currents” between Thomas Edison’s DC power system and Tesla’s AC power system.
Tesla cofounder Martin Eberhard originally came up with the idea in Disneyland’s Blue Bayou restaurant.
Tesla, Inc shares closed at $260.00 on Friday, down $-3.91 (-1.48%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -16.49%, versus a 4.87% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Introduces Lower-Priced Model 3
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has taken the wraps off of a new lower-priced version of its Model 4 vehicles. Elon Musk shared the news about the new mid-range vehicles, which will have a base sticker price of $45,000. more
CNBC has additional details.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced on Twitter that a new variant of the company’s Model 3 electric sedan is going on sale today.
He wrote, “Costs $35k after federal & state tax rebates in California, but true cost of ownership is closer to $31k after gas savings.”
The electric vehicle maker provided additional details to CNBC via a statement.
“As Model 3 production and sales continue to grow rapidly, we’ve achieved a steady volume in manufacturing capacity, allowing us to diversify our product offering to even more customers. Our new Mid-Range Battery is being introduced this week in the U.S. and Canada to better meet the varying range needs of the many customers eager to own Model 3, and our delivery estimate for customers who have ordered the Standard Battery is 4-6 months,” the statement read.
Tesla Inc shares rose $4.73 (+1.79%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -15.24%, versus a 4.93% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #7 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Elon Musk Plans to Buy Massive Amount of Company Stock
body:
Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) Elon Musk is going to put his money where his mouth is. A new filing indicates that the Tesla honcho has plans to purchase a massive amount of company stock. more
CNBC has the details on Musk’s plan.
Tesla chief executive Elon Musk told the electric car company that he plans to purchase $20 million of common stock during the next open trading window, according to a filing related to the CEO’s settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
The 8-K filing outlined Musk’s intentions. “Separate and apart from the settlement, Elon has notified Tesla that he intends to purchase from Tesla, and Tesla expects that it will issue and sell to Elon, $20 million of Tesla’s common stock during the next open trading window at the then-current market price,” the filing reads in part.
Tesla Inc shares rose $6.09 (+2.20%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -9.53%, versus a 6.28% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #10 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Snags Plot of Land for China Factory
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) previously announced plans for a factory in China have taken a major leap forward. The electric vehicle maker has purchased a massive patch of land on which its vision will become reality. more
CNBC has the details.
Tesla successfully acquired an 864,885-square meter plot in Shanghai’s Lingang area for the electric car maker’s new factory, according to an announcement from Lingang Wednesday afternoon. No price was immediately disclosed.
Plans for the wholly-owned factory were first announced in July. Lingang is located on the coast, about 47 miles southeast of the center of Shanghai or a roughly two-hour subway ride. Several auto manufacturers with foreign ties have facilities there, and unmarked test vehicles can be seen roaming the streets.
Back in August, the company noted in an earnings release that it expects to begin production in China in three years. Funding for the factory is expected to mainly come from local debt.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.51 (+0.91%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -11.16%, versus a 6.45% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #10 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Tries To Pump Up Sales of its Most Expensive Cars
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is taking advantage of its phasing-out tax credit by encouraging buyers to purchase its most expensive model.more
Tesla’s sophisticated electric cars are expensive to produce, and to turn a profit the company is using creative tactics to boost sales. A full, $7,500 tax credit is only available to consumers who order the vehicle by October 15th, to whom Tesla guarantees their vehicles will be delivers by the end of 2018.
The Motley Fool provides details:
However, many reservation holders may not be able to afford even the cheapest Model 3 variant currently in production. While there are hundreds of thousands of outstanding reservations, Tesla has been allowing nonreservation holders to order the Model 3 versions currently in production (essentially skipping the line) since July. Nevertheless, the lead time has shrunk to a maximum of four weeks for rear-wheel-drive models and eight weeks for dual-motor models.
Tesla’s Model 3 dual-motor all-wheel drive variants are more expensive than rear-wheel drive counterparts. Tesla hopes to boost sales of their most expensive vehicles by pressing consumers with the deadline.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $259.59 per share on Monday afternoon, up $0.81 (+0.31%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -16.62%, versus a 4.20% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) reportedly produced 7,400 Model 3 sedans in less than 2 weeks
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is starting the quarter of with a bang, boasting volume output that is close to matching its goal of 5000 cars per week.more
According to a report in Elektrek, Tesla has produced 7,400 Model 3 mid-sized sedans since the beginning of the quarter. Including its other vehicles, Tesla has produced 11,500 cars since the start of Q4 a few weeks ago.
CNBC provides details:
Tesla has struggled with production on the Model 3 in the past. It had originally aimed to make 5,000 cars a week at the end of 2017 but did not reach that goal until the end of the second quarter this year. However the company did deliver more vehicles in the third quarter than analysts expected. At the time, the automaker said production had stabilized.
The rate is holding strong despite the tendency for production to slow down at the end of the month. After years of struggling with production, Tesla created more vehicles than analysts expected last quarter.
Tesla, Inc shares closed at $258.78 on Friday, up $6.55 (+2.60%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -16.88%, versus a 4.76% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Full Tax Credit Set to Go Away
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) customers have until October, 15th to take advantage of a $7,500 tax credit when ordering vehicles.
more
The new time-sensitive offer has the potential to give sales a major boost, but it also comes with the challenge of delivering the vehicles on time with the deadline the company has insisted on.
Tech Crunch provides details:
The tax credit begins to phase out once a manufacturer has sold 200,000 qualifying vehicles in the U.S. Under these rules, Tesla customers have to take delivery of their new Model S, Model X or Model 3 by December 31. Tesla explained how the tax credit would phase out and the Dec. 31 delivery deadline two months ago.
Until Thursday, it wasn’t clear if or when Tesla would impose a deadline for customers to order their electric vehicle.
The deadline for vehicles ordered before October, 15 to be delivered is before the end of 2018.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $258.78 per share on Friday afternoon, up $6.55 (+2.60%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -16.88%, versus a 4.76% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Lots of Uncertainty Surrounding Next Tesla Inc (TSLA) Chairman
body:
The Financial Times has reported on who the new chairman of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), but CEO Elon Musk has basically said not so fast. Musk has taken to Twitter to dispute the report. more
CNBC has the news.
Outgoing Twenty-First Century Fox Chief Executive James Murdoch is the lead candidate to replace Elon Musk as Tesla chairman, the Financial Times reported on Wednesday, but Musk in a tweeted reply to the newspaper said, “This is incorrect.”
Tesla has until Nov. 13 to appoint an independent chairman of the board, part of settlements reached last month between Tesla, Musk and U.S. regulators in the wake of Musk tweeting in August that he had secured funding to take the electric car maker private.
The Securities and Exchange Commission came down hard on Musk over his flippant tweets about potentially taking the company private. He’ll be allowed to stay in place as CEO, but a new chairman will need to be appointed. According to Musk, Murdoch is not the choice, although reports indicate he wants the gig.
Tesla Inc shares rose $0.01 (0.00%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -17.26%, versus a 5.32% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #10 of 25 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Stresses Safety as Test Results Prove Company’s Models are Low-Risk Injury Vehicles
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has received safety perfect scores for its Model 3 car.more
The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) gave perfect safety scores to the Model 3, and it even appears to score higher than average on statistics that are not usually provided by the federal government. Tesla posted a blog post which boasted a statistic from the NHTSA, making it “safer than any other vehicle.”
CNET provides details:
As for Tesla’s other two vehicles, the Model S and Model X, the news is almost as good. According to Tesla’s chart, its larger vehicles sit right next to the Model 3 on the probability-of-injury chart. Tesla’s image doesn’t name any runners-up from other automakers, although some vehicles appear to be pretty close.
It is unclear exactly how these statistic are acquired by the NHTSA, but Tesla’s repeated success in every subcategory grants consumers serious reason for confidence in the electric car manufacturer.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $250.20 per share on Monday afternoon, down $11.75 (-4.49%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -19.64%, versus a 9.34% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Hedge Fund Sees a Bad End to Tesla’s (TSLA) Run
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is showing similar signs to Lehman Brothers before its 2008 bankruptcy, according to analyst.more
Greenlight Capital president David Einhorn, who famously predicted the collapse of Lehman Brothers, sees dark times ahead for Tesla. Einhorn pointed to the way the electric car company deflects criticism and hides problems.
Market Watch provides a quote from the analyst:
“There are many parallels to TSLA,” Einhorn said. “In 2013, TSLA was on the brink of failure as customers who had paid deposits weren’t taking delivery of the Model S. TSLA’s cash reserves fell to a dangerously low level and CEO Elon Musk secretly and desperately tried to sell the company to Google. Rather than communicating truth to shareholders, Mr. Musk bluffed his way through the crisis. There were no regulatory, legal or market consequences for failing to own up to reality. The business survived, and Mr. Musk was celebrated for his successful bluffing.”
Musk’s success has emboldened him to continue being deceptive, according to Einhorn. After receiving a fine from the SEC last week, Musk sent out an indignant, provocative tweet, mocking the organization as the “Shortseller Enrichment Commission.”
Tesla, Inc shares closed at $261.95 on Friday, down $-19.88 (-7.05%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -15.87%, versus a 9.26% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #8 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Still Not a Fan of the SEC
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk sends another provocative tweet out shortly after settling with the SEC.more
Musk sent out a tweet Thursday saying, “Just want to that the Short seller Enrichment Commission is doing incredible work. And the name change is so on point!” Ironically, the original issue was also caused by a tweet, in which Musk claimed he was taking the company private. The SEC sued Musk for the tweet, saying that it was misleading and caused major market disruption.
ZDNET provides details:
As part of the settlement, Tesla executives are meant to monitor Musk’s posts in the interest of the company and investors. If Musk continues on his one-man Twitter crusade, perhaps they will see a need for more firm action when it comes to the executive’s use of social media platforms — especially as these messages now have the power to impact the share price of the company.
Musk will retain his role as CEO, but must step down from chair and not seek reelection for three years, according to the agreement reached in the compromise.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $262.22 per share on Friday afternoon, down $19.61 (-6.96%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -15.78%, versus a 9.24% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: How Elusive Are Tesla’s (TSLA) Profits?
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has maintained spotlight in the media for the past few weeks and many are curious about its ability to turn a profit.more
Elon Musk’s most recent SEC fine and settlement has been a source of constant media attention, and Tesla’s ability to make a profit will be a major factor in determining the company’s fate. The Motley Fool’s John Brommels is skeptical, pointing to the fact that 2018’s Q2 was Tesla’s biggest quarterly loss to date.
The Motley Fool provides context:
Musk had recently sent an email to Tesla employees — posted on the company’s blog — in which he stated, “We are about to have the most amazing quarter in our history, building and delivering more than twice as many cars as we did last quarter.” That would have translated to producing more than 106,000 vehicles and delivering more than 81,000. It’s unclear whether Musk was referring to Q3 2018 or Q4 2018 — or, for that matter, Q1 2019 — as the quarter when this feat would occur. Tesla’s there on the deliveries but not on the production…at least, not yet.
CEO Elon Musk has failed to meet promises regarding the electric car company in the past, but it did meet ambitious quarterly production goals of its Model 3 and could theoretically make a profit if it continues to maintain its production rate. The company has proven to maintain high stock prices without profits, but they will be necessary as the electric car sector begins to become more competitive.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $281.83 per share on Thursday afternoon, down $12.97 (-4.40%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -9.48%, versus a 9.88% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Moody’s Sounds a Warning on Trade Fears Affecting Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Bottom Line
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is another company that could be impacted by a trade war between the United States and China. That’s the word from both J.P. Morgan and Moody’s, which have separately sounded the alarm of concern. more
CNBC has the details.
The escalating trade conflict between the U.S. and China could be bad news for Tesla, according to J.P. Morgan.
On Tuesday, Tesla cautioned investors about the “headwinds” in China from the trade war in its third-quarter vehicle production and deliveries announcement. The company said the trade conflict has led to a 40 percent import tariff on Tesla vehicles exported to China.
In a note to clients,  J.P. Morgan analyst Ryan Brinkman pointed out that the deliveries release speaks to challenges in China relative to the increase in tariffs for vehicles imported from the United States.” Moody’s analyst Bruce Clark expressed additional concerns in his research note.
“Cash generation could be dampened, however, by rising trade tensions with China,” he wrote. “China is an important long-term market for Tesla and exports to the country represented approximately 20% of automotive revenues during 2017.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.87 (-0.30%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.32%, versus a 10.75% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #9 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Hedge Fund Legend Continues to See Tesla Inc (TSLA) Becoming a Trillion Dollar Company
body:
There always seems to be an air of negativity surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), and that makes it pretty tough to envision it becoming a trillion-dollar company down the road. Don’t tell that to Ron Baron, the billionaire founder of Baron Capital. more
CNBC passes along what Baron had to say.
Major Tesla shareholder Ron Baron told CNBC on Tuesday the electric automaker could be a $1 trillion company in revenue by 2030.
“I think it could be a $500 billion battery business, $500 billion car business. I give that better than 50-50 chance,” the billionaire buy-and-hold investor said.
Baron acknowledges that the vibe around Tesla would be better if CEO Elon Musk would ease up on his Twitter posting habits. However, he also notes that he believes the company is actually close to self-funding.
“I think this is going to be the biggest car company,” he said.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.14 (-0.05%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 0.85%, versus a 10.64% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Report: Tesla (TSLA) May Have Hit Production Record in Q3
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) hits its most impressive quarter in its history this quarter.more
After months of challenges concerning both supply chains and publicity Tesla, has achieved a very impressive quarter in regards to manufacturing. The automaker is expected to release its official numbers regarding production later today, but for now it appears the automaker has achieved its Model 3 goal with days to go.
Electrek provides details:
A source familiar with the matter has told Electrek that Tesla produced a record ~80,000 vehicles this quarter.
This level of production is unprecedented for the automaker, but deliveries could turn out to be even crazier.
Electrek also argued that Tesla’s intense end of quarter practice, while impressive, hurts customer service. Hopefully Tesla will achieve a more standardized production rate that alleviates extreme volatility in manufacturing.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $309.60 per share on Monday afternoon, up $44.83 (+16.93%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -0.56%, versus a 10.81% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Professor: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Will Need to Find a Deal Partner at This Point
body:
Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) never-ending troubles are going to continue to snowball, and that points to the company being bought out at some point. That’s the take from NYU professor Scott Galloway, who believes a pair of tech titans are natural suitors for the electric vehicle maker.   more
Galloway shares his thoughts on Tesla in a piece for L2.
Apple or Google are the most likely suitors, as the car is a platform of sorts, and one can see Apple employing their high-margin luxury brand, vertical distribution, and artisan strategy on Tesla.
Conversely, Google could also use the (car) platform as a means of jumping ahead on self-driving and serving up ads/info/media while in/on this platform. It says something bad about our economy when any industry digresses to iOS or Android. The valuation prohibits another auto firm from acquiring Tesla, as the markets assign a tech, vs. auto, valuation to the firm. Tesla shareholders (note: I do not have a long or short position in TSLA) are also about to start hating @elonmusk.
Galloway points to the company’s recent kerfuffle with the SEC and increased competition in the electric vehicle space as a pair of problems that could lead to major changes at Tesla.
Tesla Inc shares rose $42.05 (+15.88%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.72%, versus a 10.85% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Set for Early Pop Following CEO Elon Musk Settlement with SEC
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has apparently had a change of heart. Last week, he seemed intent on fighting the SEC fraud suit that was leveled against him. He thought better of that over the weekend, and the Tesla roller coaster is heading back up for the time being as a result.  more
CNBC has the details on Musk’s settlement.
The SEC charged Tesla with fraud alleging CEO Elon Musk issued “false and misleading” statements and failed to properly notify regulators of material company events. The charges were in relation to a tweet that Musk posted in August saying he was considering taking the electric carmaker public at $420 a share.
But on Saturday, Musk settled the charges with the SEC, agreeing to pay a civil penalty of $20 million and give up his role as chairman of the board for at least three years. The SEC also imposed a fine of $20 million on Tesla. The carmaker must also appoint two independent directors to the board.
Based on the terms of the deal, neither Musk or Tesla needs to admit to any wrongdoing. That puts a bow on the latest batch of Tesla drama, at least for the time being. We’ll patiently wait to see what the rest of the day brings.
Tesla Inc shares rose $49.93 (+18.86%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -14.96%, versus a 10.37% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Settles With SEC, Will Remain CEO
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk’s latest debacle has apparently come to an end.more
As Reuters reports, the embattled executive has reach a multimillion dollar agreement with U.S. regulators to settle a tweet-fueled dispute:
Tesla Inc and Elon Musk have agreed to pay $20 million each to financial regulators and the billionaire will step down as the company’s chairman but remain as chief executive, under a settlement that caps a tumultuous two months for the carmaker.
The securities fraud agreement, disclosed by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Saturday, will come as a relief to investors, who had worried that a lengthy legal fight would only further hurt the loss-making electric car company.
The problem arose last month, when Musk tweeted that he was considering taking Tesla private at $420 per share. “Funding secured,” he wrote in the blockbuster tweet that sent shares soaring.
Spoiler alert: funding wasn’t secured, and it’s unknown whether Musk ever seriously considered taking the company private to begin with.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $264.77 on Friday, down $42.75 (-13.90%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -14.96%, versus a 10.37% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: A Tesla Inc (TSLA) Without Elon Musk Probably Isn't Ownable
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) shares had their worst day in nearly five years on Friday, plunging almost 14% amid the SEC suing CEO Elon Musk.more
CNBC has more details on the landmark action against the electric automaker’s founder, and the potential fallout:
The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Musk on Thursday, alleging for fraud. The complaint says Musk issued “false and misleading” statements and failed to properly notify regulators of material company events. Musk called the SEC’s allegations “unjustified” and said he “never compromised” his integrity.
Barclays believes if Musk is forced to leave because of the SEC action, it will be weigh on Tesla’s stock.
In fact, Barclays analyst Brian Johnson wrote in a note to clients that “The SEC civil action may lead to Musk’s exit from Tesla (either permanently or temporarily) and the Musk premium in the shares dissipating. Tesla shares have ~$130 of Musk premium for future success that might dissipate.”
Johnson rates TSLA as Underweight with a $210 price target.

heading: Credit-Default Stops Signaling Trouble for Tesla (TSLA)
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) stock dropped 13% in its worst one day drop in years after news broke that the SEC was suing CEO Elon Musk.more
CEO Elon Musk was sued by the SEC for an August tweet in which he stated his desire to take the company private. The tweet resulted in an immediate boost in Tesla share prices, all of which have been wiped out in the ensuing weeks. The SEC is challenging Musk’s intentions and capacity to take the company private at the time of the tweet.
Zero Hedge provides analysis:
“To be clear, near-term if Tesla is able to ramp the Model 3 over the coming quarters, we believe cash flow should improve,” Joseph Spak, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets said Friday. “Having Elon Musk as CEO has undoubtedly made that easier in the past. Securing attractive funding in the future could be more difficult.”
Tesla holds $11.5 billion in foreign debt, which is mostly held by the European Insurance Company Allianz. New capital will be harder and more expensive for the company to acquire, especially if CEO Elon Musk is forced to step down.
Tesla, Inc shares . Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -14.96%, versus a 10.37% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Hits Production Targets for the Quarter
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has maintained an extremely high level of production and met its quarterly goal with two days to go.more
Despite a quarter of drama, doubt, and delays, Tesla has broken records in achieving its electric vehicle production goal this quarter. After Thursday’s news of an SEC suit against Tesla CEO Elon Musk, the news of successful quarterly production is a welcome victory for the auto-manufacturer.
Electrek provides context:
Extrapolated for a year, it is equivalent to an annual production rate of 320,000 vehicles. It’s quite significant when you consider that Tesla produced just about 2,000 vehicles back in 2012.
This record performance comes at a strange time for Tesla as Musk is being sued by the SEC, but I personally think that this accomplishment should outweigh the authorities going after Musk because of a few tweets.
Tesla’s flagship Model 3 was facing months of difficulties and delays in production this quarter, but the company has managed to produce 51,000 cars with days of production to go.

heading: Analyst Puts Sell Rating on Tesla Inc (TSLA), Cites Too Many Concerns
body:
The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed suit against Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk, and that was the final straw for one Wall Street firm. Citigroup is tapping out on Tesla. more
CNBC shares the firm’s take.
Citigroup downgraded Tesla’s stock to a sell rating from neutral Friday, a day after the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a fraud lawsuit against CEO Elon Musk.
The brokerage detailed two paths forward for the electric car maker, one with Musk and one without. And both options aren’t great for stakeholders.
Citi has slashed its price target for Tesla down to $225. The firm provided some insight on the current conundrum for the company in a note to clients.
“There’s little question that Mr. Musk’s departure would likely cause harm to Tesla’s brand, stakeholder confidence and fundraising,” the note read in part. “If Mr. Musk ends up staying on, the reputational harm from this might still prevent the stock from immediately returning to ‘normal.'”

heading: SEC Brings Charges Against Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk
body:
A tweet from Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has led to an investigation by the SEC. Back in August, Musk dropped a major piece of previously unannounced news on Twitter. As the SEC has now made crystal clear for him, that’s a no no for publicly traded companies.   more
Investor’s Business Daily has the news on Tesla.
The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filed a lawsuit against Tesla (TSLA) Chief Executive Elon Musk charging securities fraud and sought to ban him as a director of a public company.
Musk misled investors in August with statements that he could take the company private at $420 a share, SEC officials said in a press conference late Thursday. The agency also alleges statements that funding for the transaction had been secured were also misleading. Musk’s contention that the only remaining uncertainty was a shareholder vote also led investors astray, the SEC said.
“We allege that Musk’s statements were false and misleading because they lacked any basis in fact,” said Stephanie Avakian, the SEC’s co-director of enforcement. The agency notes that it doesn’t appear that Musk had secured financing when he made the announcement, and that any deals he may have been pointing to were ripe with contingencies.
“An officer’s celebrity status or reputation as a technological innovator does not give license to take those responsibilities lightly,” explained Steven Peikin, an SEC co-director of enforcement.
Tesla Inc shares fell $35.37 (-11.50%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.23%, versus a 10.35% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla,Inc (TSLA) Solar Roofs Not Hitting Mainstream as Company Had Hoped
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has only finished installing 12 solar roofs after revealing the tiles in October 2016.more
In August Tesla CEO Elon Musk said hundreds of the solar roofs are in process to be installed. The company used its impressive showcase of the tiles to help validate its $2.6 billion acquisition of Solar City. Musk has stated that the lack of widespread success with the tiles is due to lengthy process of confirming the adequacy of a roof to sustain the technology for 30 years.
CNBC gives details on the situation:
“I would expect these solar roofing tiles, in just a few years, to be quite reasonably priced if they can get the market interest that they’re hoping for,” said Dan Kammen, an energy professor at University of California, Berkeley. “It’s not just a roofing shingle anymore, it’s a power plant on your roof.”
Experts anticipate a wave of new solar installations within three to five years.
Tesla says solar roof installations will scale up later this year and into 2019.
Tesla hopes to increase cost-parity in its roof panels by making solar tile installations long-lasting with resilience for thirty-plus years.

heading: Report: Tesla (TSLA) Cutting it Close on Quarterly Production Totals
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) will have to maintain very high production rates to reach its production goals this quarter.more
In addition to maintaining high production rates recently, the Model 3 received perfect safety scores. But Tesla is still facing challenges maintaining its production goals (6,000 vehicles per week) every week and it will be a challenge to reach its low end goal of 50,000 to 55,000 vehicles.
Electrek provides their opinion on the situation:
As usual, let me start by saying that no matter how you look at those numbers, Tesla is producing electric vehicles at an incredible rate, better than any legacy automaker, and that should be celebrated.
The lower-end is still achievable, but Tesla is going to have to maintain the higher production rate that it achieved over several days earlier this month. I still think Tesla can get close to an overall production of 80,000 cars in the quarter, which would be extremely impressive.
CEO Elon Musk said Tesla is on track for its most amazing quarter in history.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Gets Perfect Safety Rating
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) earns positive feedback on its Model 3 after months of controversy.more
After months of volatility at the premier electric car manufacturer, Tesla is enjoying a perfect score for safety on its Model 3 vehicle. All of Tesla’s vehicles have now earned a 5-star rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, including the Model X sport utility vehicle and the Tesla Model S sedan.
CNBC provides details on the challenges the Model 3 has been facing:
Much has been said about Tesla’s “production hell,” as CEO Elon Musk has called it. The company has missed targets by several months as it worked to ramp up production. At the end of the second quarter Tesla said it was repeatedly producing 5,000 Model 3 cars per week, a goal it originally aimed to achieve at the end of 2017. As production improves, the company faces other challenges. Recently Musk said in response to a customer complaint on Twitter that Tesla is now going through “delivery logistics hell.”
Other reviewing agencies have similarly lauded the Model 3, although its path to success has been fraught with challenges. The model has been criticized for an unfavorable stopping distance, which the Musk-led auto-manufacturer remedied with a software update, and for its autopilot driver assistance system, which has been involved in several crashes.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $300.87 per share on Thursday afternoon, up $1.85 (+0.62%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.37%, versus a 10.98% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Competitor Says Bait & Switch Will Shorten Company’s Lifespan
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) was criticized by AutoNation leader Mike Jackson for what he calls a “bait-and-switch” strategy, as he predicted Tesla will not be a major player in the electric car industrymore
Jackson believes Elon Musk doesn’t possess a sustainable business strategy, pointing to the frequently publicized production problems with the Model 3. Meanwhile, he perceives established auto-makers as having an edge in the market as they use profits from trucks and other vehicles to subsidize electric car production, while Tesla must use shareholders to subsidize their research and development.
CNBC provides quotes from the AutoNation leader:
“We’re past the inflection point on electrification,” Jackson told CNBC on Wednesday, predicting 30 percent of vehicles will be electric in about 10 years. “I think if Tesla was there it would be quite something.”
“I think when you’re skimming the Model 3 with a bait-and-switch strategy maybe it works” for a while, the outgoing AutoNation CEO said on “Squawk Box.” “But there’s going to be a day of reckoning.”
Tesla CEO Elon Musk’s behavior has been consistently controversial over the past few months, including an August 7th tweet about taking the company that is being investigated by the Department of Justice, and an appearance on Joe Rogan’s podcast in which he smoked pot. In the past Mr. Jackson has said that he has no personal beef with Musk or Tesla, and would be willing to sell their vehicles at AutoNation locations.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $296.92 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $11.96 (+4.20%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.63%, versus a 10.10% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Justice Department Turns Up Heat on Tesla CEO Elon Musk
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is being investigated by the Department of Justice in regards to a tweet from CEO Elon Musk about taking the company private.more
Tesla shares declined by 7.1 percent after news of the investigation came out early Tuesday morning. The Justice Department is running a criminal investigation in conjunction with a civil fraud probe sponsored by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Musk’s August 7th tweet about taking Tesla private resulted in a major increase in stock prices, which has been lost in the past few weeks after various other controversies involving the flamboyant CEO.
CNBC provides an acknowledgement from Tesla about the situation:
“Last month, following Elon’s announcement that he was considering taking the company private, Tesla received a voluntary request for documents from the DOJ and has been cooperative in responding to it. We have not received a subpoena, a request for testimony, or any other formal process. We respect the DOJ’s desire to get information about this and believe that the matter should be quickly resolved as they review the information they have received.”
The primary issue is a potential violation of the SEC’s rule 14e-8, which prohibits publicly traded companies from announcing plans about buying or selling securities with the intention of manipulating the stock price or inability to follow through on their claims.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $284.77 per share on Tuesday afternoon, down $10.07 (-3.42%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.54%, versus a 10.07% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla, Inc (TSLA) Entry Into Pick-Up Truck Market Won’t Be an Easy One
body:
Tesla, Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has plans to enter the fiercely competitive pick-up truck market.more
Despite recent turmoil in the the electric vehicle manufacturing company, Tesla is seeking entry into one of the most competitive markets in the auto-industry. CEO Elon Musk’s bold vision could pay off in carving a niche, high quality pick-up model, as its electric motor would be able generate the torque and power necessary for towing.
From Market Insider:
CEO Elon Musk seems pretty excited about the pickup, suggesting that it will have range well beyond the 300-plus miles currently delivered by Tesla’s top-of-the-line batteries in its existing cars. He’s also said that it will be able to serve up 240-volt, on-site power to plug in tools, and have towing capacity that’s as good or better than what customers expect from Chevy, Ford, and RAM’s full-size offerings.
The level of competition in the pick-up market is best highlighted by some of the biggest players currently participating in the market. Despite their high quality, Toyota’s Tundra only sold around 115,000 vehicles in the US while Ford’s F-150 model only sold 900,000. As some of the most competitive pick ups in the market, they showcase the challenge Tesla would likely face upon entry.
Tesla, Inc shares were trading at $294.84 per share on Monday afternoon, down $0.36 (-0.12%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.30%, versus a 9.37% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Frets About Delivery Bottlenecks
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has yer another batch of problems on its plate. According to CEO Elon Musk, the company has followed up its ongoing production issues with troubles on the delivery front. more
CNBC shares what the Tesla chief had to say.
Tesla’s Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk acknowledged that the electric carmaker’s problems have now shifted to delivery logistics from production delays, the latest speed bump in its efforts to achieve profitability.
“Sorry, we’ve gone from production hell to delivery logistics hell, but this problem is far more tractable. We’re making rapid progress. Should be solved shortly,” Musk said in a tweet in response to a customer complaint on delivery delay.
The customer had complained that “my delivery has been delayed indefinite,” and shared a picture of a lot of Tesla vehicles that are apparently ready to be delivered to waiting customers. The electric vehicle maker has been working through a countless number of issues on the production front, and it sounds like another wrench has been thrown into things with delivery troubles.
We’ll have to wait and see if the company solves this latest batch of problems quickly or if it lingers in the press for days on end before updates are made.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.43 (-0.48%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.19%, versus a 9.93% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Millennials Continue to Bet on Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shares
body:
Despite a number of controversies that continue to loom large for Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), shares of the electric vehicle maker remain quite popular with the younger crowd. Data from one popular stock trading app indicates that Tesla still has plenty of fans in spite of its troubles.  more
Business Insider passes along one positive sign for Tesla.
Despite that, Tesla is still one of the most-popular stocks among millennial investors. On Robinhood, Tesla was the second most-added stock over the past week, with a total of 11,316 investors adding shares, up 13% from last week, according to Business Insider’s tracking of the data.
Tesla is the 14th most popular stock on the brokerage, up from 17th last week.
Executives have been fleeing the automaker, and CEO Elon Musk has raised eyebrows numerous times with comments on social media and curious behavior during interviews.  That’s led to a volatile roller coaster ride for investors, but it seems to be inspiring traders on Robinhood.
Over the past week, more than 11,000 investors scooped up shares on Robinhood, a no-fee brokerage that has proven to be quite a hit with the younger crowd.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Analyst: Tesla Board Needs an Overhaul
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) shares are falling and the company has lost 13 key executives over the last year. Elon Musk’s volatile behavior is in large part to blame, according to CNBC’s Gene Munster, who argues that the company must restructure its board.more
After a summer of incendiary tweets and most recently a controversial episode on Joe Rogan’s podcast, Elon Musk is being criticized by many analysts for hurting his company’s success. Musk is an integral part of Tesla and pulling him from the company is not the answer, but the famous CEO’s board is failing to protect him from his own worst impulses.
CNBC‘s Gene Munster offers a potential solution:
If Musk were to step down and another director gave up his or her seat, the company could explore bringing on a new chairperson with no ties to Musk that may be able to influence him. Al Gore, currently on Apple’s board, could be an interesting fit given his interest in climate change. Former Boeing CEO Jim McNerney would also be a good option as the former chairman at the company.
Munster adds his belief in Musk as the spirit of innovation driving the company and that those calling for his firing are misguided. He reasserts that the issue is that no one on the board is strong enough to stand up to him, and that restructuring the company’s decision-making apparatus is the best way to rebound the ailing company.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.36 (-0.12%) in after-hours trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -7.03%, versus a 9.91% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst Makes a Case to Buy GM Instead of Tesla Inc (TSLA) Stock
body:
Shareholders of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) seem to be on a never-ending roller coaster ride, and one analyst is about ready to get off. Instead, the analyst is looking towards a legacy automaker as an appealing alternative. more
Marketwatch‘s Jeff Reeves shares his insight on Tesla.
I understand Tesla’s growth potential has many investors hanging on, particularly if they bought years ago and are playing with house money at this point.
But it seems quite dangerous to rely on blind faith. In fact, boring General Motors GM, +1.05% may be a better bet over the next 12 to 18 months.
Reeves points to various controversies that have been swirling around Tesla in recent months, including CEO Elon Musk’s latest bizarre interview. Controversy aside, he’s also getting a little tired of Tesla’s failure to deliver on promises.
He points to GM as an interesting alternative instead, and noted that the automaker’s current valuation metrics look awfully appealing.

heading: Cramer: Elon Musk Should Take A Leave Of Absence From Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has been acting pretty strangely as of late, and one prominent Wall Street pundit believes he should take a break from his duties.more
As CNBC reports, Cramer is calling for Musk to take some time off:
Elon Musk’s “self-destructive” behavior is a major concern for Tesla shareholders, and perhaps the board should put the CEO on a short medical leave, CNBC’s Jim Cramer said Tuesday.
“I’m worried about the guy,” Cramer said on “Squawk on the Street.” “Medical leave is fine. I think the board puts him on medical leave. That’s not a sin. It could be a good thing.”
It’s not all bad news, however. Cramer said that “a healthy Elon Musk is something that can take the stock higher.”
Musk’s seemingly strange behavior began several months ago, when he angrily cut short an earnings call with analysts. Since then, he’s tweeted about taking the company public, had an eye-opening New York Times interview, and appeared on Joe Rogan’s podcast apparently drinking whiskey and smoking marijuana.

heading: Analyst: Buy Tesla Inc (TSLA) On Gigafactory Strength
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) shares have had a rough several weeks, but not everyone on Wall Street is swinging bearish on the electric automaker.more
As CNBC reports, at least one prominent bull still believes in the stock:
Investors should still buy Tesla’s stock in spite of all the “drama” surrounding the electric car maker and its management, an analyst at Baird said after touring the company’s factory.
“We recently toured the Fremont factory and came away incrementally positive” about the company, analyst Ben Kallo wrote in a Monday note titled “Tesla, Inc.: Buy Even with Drama in LBC.” “Gigafactory 1 creates a significant barrier for competition and manufacturing capability should be a competitive advantage for TSLA over the long term. We believe TSLA’s Gigafactory enables the company to drive down costs through an industrialization of battery pack assembly and economies of scale.”
Accordingly, Kallo reiterated his Buy rating and $411 price target on TSLA, which suggests a 56% upside from current levels. heading: Short-Seller Predicts Single-Digit Stock Price for Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
The bottom is really going to fall out for Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), according to short seller Robert Chapman. During an appearance on CNBC, he explained how far he thinks share prices are going to fall. more
CNBC passes along Chapman’s take on Tesla.
Tesla shares are extremely overvalued and will drop precipitously, Robert Chapman said Friday.
Chapman downplayed concerns over CEO Elon Musk’s erratic behavior, instead focusing on the carmaker’s financials for his bearish view.
Chapman, who is short shares of Tesla, shared his take during an appearance on the network’s ‘Halftime Report.’ “I actually don’t think you should short it on [Musk’s] judgment. I think he is a fascinating businessman, probably the most incredible entrepreneur since Edison …. Selling him short, I think, is a mistake,” he said. “I think selling short a $50 billion enterprise auto manufacturer that is struggling to create a business model that is sustainably profitable — that, I think, is a great trade.”
As he sees it, “inevitably you have a stock that’s headed into the single digits.”
Tesla Inc shares rose $9.10 (+3.46%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -12.64%, versus a 9.14% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) In Q3 Dash, Offers Immediate Delivery
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is on a push to hit its Q3 Model 3 goals, and that has led the automaker to offer up an additional perk to reservation holders. A limited number of the sought after vehicles are being made available for immediate delivery. more
Techspot has the news on Tesla.
Tesla wants to increase its Model 3 sales figures before the end of the third quarter, and that means getting the vehicles to customers as quickly as possible. To achieve this, the company has started “immediate deliveries” of the EVs on a “first come, first served” basis.
The news comes from website Electrek, which writes that Tesla is emailing day-one reservation holders to inform them that a limited number of Model 3 rear-wheel-drive cars are available for immediate delivery.
The offer is effective as of today. “As a first-day reservation holder, you’re invited to take advantage of this opportunity on a first-come, first-served basis,” the email from Tesla reads in part.
There is no word on exactly how many Model 3’s will be made available for the offer. Tesla continues to push towards its goal of producing 50,000 – 55,000 Model 3’s in Q3.
Tesla Inc shares rose $6.26 (+2.38%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -15.45%, versus a 8.69% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Cramer: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Bonds More Telling Than Its Stock Price
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) relies heavily on recent bond issues to fund its operations, but the value of those bonds is plummeting.more
As CNBC notes, venerable market pundit Jim Cramer sees this as a major danger sign:
“It’s the bondholders who matter, not the stockholders, and the bonds keep going down,” CNBC’s Jim Cramer said on “Squawk on the Street.”
Tesla’s 2025 bonds dropped on Friday to an all-time low of 82.03 cents on the dollar, down from 93 cents on the dollar on Aug. 7 — the day Musk announced he had secured funding to take Tesla private. The drop raised the bond’s yield to 8.89 percent. (Bond prices move inversely to yields.)
“I don’t even look at the stock anymore, because that’s emotional. I look at the 2025 bonds, and I look at it incessantly,” Cramer concluded.
Tesla’s chief accounting officer just resigned after only a month on the job, citing “the level of public attention placed on the company,” the company said in an 8K filing. That’s another “red flag,” according to Cramer.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $263.24 on Friday, down $17.71 (-6.30%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -15.45%, versus a 8.69% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shares Dive on News of Accounting Officer Resignation One Month Into Job
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is on the hunt for a new chief accounting officer. That’s because the man that previously held the position is resigning just one month after coming on board. more
CNBC has the details on the latest troubling sing for Tesla.
Tesla’s chief accounting officer, Dave Morton, has resigned after just a month, citing “the level of public attention placed on the company,” the carmaker said in an 8K filing.
News of Morton’s quick departure follows CEO Elon Musk’s bizarre weed-and-whiskey interview with Joe Rogan.
Morton provided additional insight on his decision in the filing. “Since I joined Tesla on August 6, the level of public attention placed on the company, as well as the pace within the company, have exceeded my expectations,” he said. “As a result, this caused me to reconsider my future. I want to be clear that I believe strongly in Tesla, its mission and its future prospects, and I have no disagreements with Tesla’s leadership or its financial reporting.”
Prior to joining Tesla, Morton had spent more than two decades with Seagate Technology, most recently as CFO.
Tesla Inc shares fell $21.71 (-7.73%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -14.57%, versus a 8.47% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

body:

CNBC has the scoop on Musk’s appearance.
Billionaire Elon Musk took viewers by surprise late Thursday when he briefly smoked marijuana and drank whiskey during a live interview.
The Tesla chief executive was speaking with comedian Joe Rogan, an advocate of legalizing weed, on his live internet show when he was handed the joint. A spokesperson for Tesla was not immediately available for comment when contacted by CNBC.
“The Joe Rogan Experience” is quite popular, and Musk’s appearance quickly went viral. The pair was engaged in a back and forth on a number of topics when Musk was handed a marijuana cigarette.
“Yeah, I think I tried one once,” Musk said.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Production Remains Bumpy But Overall Goals Within Reach
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) swung and missed on weekly Model 3 production goals, but it appears that the automaker remains on track for the quarter as a whole. more
Elektrek has the scoop on where things stand for Tesla on the Model 3 production front.
Tesla has been aiming for a production rate of 6,000 Model 3 vehicles per week by the end of August and an overall production of 50,000 to 55,000 Model 3 vehicles throughout the third quarter.
Electrek has learned that the automaker missed the 6,000 unit production rate goal, but Tesla is nonetheless on track for its overall third quarter goal.
It follows our report from last week about Tesla being on track for a production record this quarter but slightly behind its ambitious Model 3 goal.
Sources tell Elektrek that Tesla has produced over 34,700 Model 3’s thus far in Q3. That places the electric vehicle on pace to reach its quarterly goal by the end of the month.
As always with Tesla, there are no guarantees that another wrench won’t be thrown into production, so we’ll wait for the final tally as opposed to assuming it’s a sure thing.
Tesla Inc shares fell $3.18 (-1.10%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -9.13%, versus a 9.25% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Goldman Sachs Sees Significant Downside Risk for Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Goldman Sachs has resumed its coverage of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA). Unfortunately for the electric vehicle maker, the investment giant doesn’t envision things going along swimmingly in the near term. more
CNBC shares Goldman’s take on Tesla.
Tesla’s electric car sales will suffer due to increased competition from other luxury automakers, according to Goldman Sachs.
The firm resumed coverage of Tesla with a sell rating, predicting the competition will cut into the company’s share of the electric car market.
Analyst David Tamberrino has placed a six-month price target of $210 on Tesla. He outlined the firm’s concerns on the automaker in a note to clients.
“We see the medium-to-longer term industry backdrop as challenging for Tesla’s products; this follows from an increasing number of EV launches from both traditional OEMs and other start-up competitors — at a time when the company’s product cadence hits a gap,” he wrote. “We believe the company will see pressure to its lead in EVs as competition catches up.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $6.31 (-2.09%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.25%, versus a 9.51% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: BlackRock Wants A Non-Musk Chairman For Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk may have a new battle on his hands over the potential direction of his company.more
As Reuters reports, the largest asset manager in the world voted to install a new chairman for the company:
Funds run by BlackRock Inc voted in favor of a recent shareholder proposal that would have required Tesla Inc to replace Elon Musk with an independent chairman.
BlackRock-managed funds voted for a measure requiring the chairman be an independent director, according to BlackRock’s filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday. The proposal, which was defeated, would not have affected Musk’s standing as Tesla’s chief executive officer.
The proposal was roundly rejected by a vote of approximately 86 million to 17 million, but it’s important to note that such a measure would have been pretty much unthinkable just six months ago. In that period, Tesla has endured production issues, an SEC investigation over a failed bid to take the company private, and concerns over Musk’s physical and mental health.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Has to Repair Reputation on Wall Street
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is dealing with yet another public relations fiasco. As the company works towards mending another self-inflicted wound, questions abound as to whether or not its credibility will be able to be repaired this time around. more
CNBC takes a look at the situation at hand for Tesla.
Wall Street analysts believe Tesla’s credibility will suffer from CEO Elon Musk giving up on his plan to take the carmaker private.
Late Friday, Musk said in a blog post the company will remain publicly traded, citing resistance from existing shareholders to his plan to take it private.
That follows weeks of drama that stemmed from Musk’s flippant remarks on Twitter about taking the company private. RBC Capital Markets analyst Joseph Spak is among those who believes the company’s standing with investors has been damaged as a result of the latest episode.
“We think credibility has taken a hit. [The blog post] reinforces the idea that this whole episode was not planned or fully thought out and thus could get added to the list of debatable statements from the company over the years,” he wrote in a note to clients. “It has become clear to us that funding was not secured or there was not sufficient interest to take the company private at $420/share.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.77 (-0.24%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 2.01%, versus a 9.69% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Report: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Production Behind Schedule
body:
A new report from Elektrek notes that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has made impressive progress on the production front for its Model 3 vehicles, but the company remains behind its own goals. The company still hasn’t been able to reach its desired output of 5,000 Model 3’s per week.  more
Electrek has the scoop on Tesla.
Virtually every new quarter for Tesla comes with new records and critical financial milestones. This quarter is no exception as Tesla attempts to become profitable and increase Model 3 production in a big way.
Electrek has learned that Tesla is on track for an incredible production record this quarter, but at the same time, the company is behind on its Model 3 production goal. It is also a different tally than other “guesstimations” out there.
Electrek pegs the company’s weekly run rate for Model 3’s in the range of 3,500 to 4,900 vehicles. At current rates, the outlet estimates that Tesla will wrap up the quarter with 70,000 vehicles produced.
That would break the previous quarter’s record-setting mark of 53,000, but it remains behind where the company wanted to be at this point.

heading: Wall Street Ready for Tesla Inc (TSLA) Sell-Off Following CEO’s Change of Heart on Going Private
body:
It’s shaping up to be another wild day for Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) shareholders. CEO Elon Musk has announced that he’s no longer thinking about taking the company private, and the market is poised to react accordingly.  more
CNBC has the news on Tesla.
Trading in Tesla shares in Germany on Monday pointed to a 5 percent drop when U.S. markets open as investors reacted to Chief Executive Elon Musk’s decision to abandon plans to take the luxury electric car maker private.
Musk said in a blog post late on Friday that consultations done with the help of Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley had shown most of Tesla’s existing shareholders opposed the deal he proposed on Twitter three weeks ago to widespread shock on Wall Street.
Earlier this month, Musk rattled the market by flippantly remarking that he was seriously considering taking the company private in a post on Twitter. Tesla investors have been on a roller coaster ride ever since, and it looks like there’s more volatility to come until the market puts this latest tidbit on the automaker behind it.
We’ll have to wait and see if Musk lessens his engagement on social media after this latest batch of Tweet-inspired drama.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Decides To Remain A Public Company
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) shocked the investing world a couple weeks back when CEO Elon Musk took to Twitter to announce he was strongly considering taking his company private.more
The infamous “Funding secured” tweet set off a firestorm of controversy, including lawsuits and an SEC investigation.
Well, it appears it was all for naught. After a board meeting on Tuesday last week, the company decided to stay a public company. As the BBC News reports, however, the fallout is far from over:
Earlier this month, Elon Musk shocked investors by announcing on Twitter that he had funding secured to take Tesla private at a value of $72bn (£57bn).
It later transpired that he had not closed a deal with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, with unhappy investors launching a lawsuit against him after the news.
The lawsuits are still continuing against Mr Musk despite his cancellation of the privatisation plan, as is an investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission to see if the tweet broke securities laws.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $322.82 on Friday, up $2.72 (+0.85%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 3.68%, versus a 8.66% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Option, Bond Traders Aren’t Optimistic About a Buyout Happening
body:
Will Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) actually go private? That question is still looming in the air, which only adds to the usual volatility that surrounds the automaker. We can add many traders from one group of market watchers to the category of those who are doubtful about a deal.  more
Reuters has the news on Tesla.
Investors in the debt and in the equity options of electric carmaker Tesla (TSLA.O) are betting the take-private deal described by Chief Executive Elon Musk will not materialize.
Like its stock price, Tesla bonds have given up all of the gains they made after Musk shocked investors with a tweet on Aug. 7, saying he had “funding secured” for a possible buyout deal at $420 per share.
Geoffrey Dancey, managing partner and portfolio manager at Cutler Capital Management, provided some perspective he has been able to glean from the bond markets. “If these bonds were priced for a takeover, they would trade at a serious premium to the conversion value compared to when the deal was announced,” he said. “The convertibles are certainly not trading as if this company is going to be taken private at $420 and they never did.”
As is always the case with Tesla, we’ll have to patiently wait and see what transpires while keeping an eye on Twitter for unexpected updates.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $321.05 per share on Friday morning, up $0.95 (+0.30%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 3.12%, versus a 8.36% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Severely Underpriced
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is going to run into problems over the way it has priced its Model 3 sedan. That’s the take from UBS, which has reiterated its claim that the automaker is going to lose money on the vehicle. more
CNBC shares the firm’s critique of Tesla’s strategy.
Buyers waiting for that long-promised $35,000 Tesla Model 3 sedan probably shouldn’t hold their breath.
After UBS recently pulled apart a Model 3 and compared its quality and estimated costs with two competitors, UBS analyst Colin Langan said he thinks Tesla will never be able to make money at the $35,000 the company originally planned to charge for an entry-level model designed for the masses.
During an appearance on CNBC’s ‘Power Lunch,’ Langan explained what the problem is as the firm sees it. “This car needs to sell in the low $40,000’s to break even, and I think they’re a long way from the 25 percent growth margin target, unless they can sell it well over $50,000,” he explained.
No comment has been forthcoming from Tesla as of yet.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $323.83 per share on Thursday morning, up $2.19 (+0.68%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 4.01%, versus a 8.39% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Refuses to Pull Back from Intense Work Schedule
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk raised some eyebrows with several revelations made during an interview with the New York Times, including the fact that his hectic work schedule is beginning to take a toll on him. While numerous of observers have opined that he should seriously consider cutting back if it’s getting to be too much, Musk doesn’t see that as a viable option at the present time.   more
CNBC has some additional insight on the Tesla chief’s current plight.
Arianna Huffington is calling on Elon Musk to adopt a healthier work-life balance, but the Tesla CEO says that’s not an option.
In a tweet early Sunday after arriving home from a late night at a Tesla factory, Musk told the Huffington Post founder that his electric car company and Ford are the only two American automakers that have avoided bankruptcy.
Huffington shared an open letter calling for Musk to take some time to “refuel and recharge.” In response, Musk shared the situation as he see it. “You think this is an option. It is not,” he wrote.
While Musk sees burning the candle at both ends as the only option at the moment, considering Huffington’s suggestions and working towards a goal of scaling back gradually wouldn’t be the worst idea in the world. “Working 120-hour weeks doesn’t leverage your unique qualities, it wastes them,” she added. “You can’t simply power through — that’s just not how our bodies and our brains work.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $320.03 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $11.59 (+3.76%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 2.79%, versus a 8.32% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Waiting Too Long to Raise Capital
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk and company would be wise to figure out what the overall game plan is in terms of the company’s financial path ahead. That’s the gist of Citi Research’s recent take on the electric vehicle maker that’s considering taking itself private.  more
CNBC shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
Tesla’s finances may be hurt by the negative ramifications of CEO Elon Musk’s controversial plan to take the company private, according to Citi Research.
The firm reiterated its “neutral/high risk” rating on Tesla shares, citing the company’s deteriorating balance sheet.
Analyst Itay Michaeli is sticking to his $356 price target for Tesla for the time being, but it’s safe to say he would feel a lot better if there was a clear direction from the company. “Ultimately, credit risk is a function of confidence, without which a company’s financial position can quickly spiral into distress. Though we don’t think Tesla has necessarily entered such a spiral, the current state of affairs heightens the focus,” he said. “If a go-private transaction is looking less likely, we think it’d be wise for Tesla to at least try to raise significant new equity capital sooner rather than later.”
Shareholders of Tesla have been on a roller coaster ride for some time now, and we can safely assume that something resembling clarity would be a welcome development for them as well.

heading: Saudi Arabian Sovereign Wealth Fund to Invest in Tesla Inc (TSLA) Rival
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is reportedly in talks with a Saudi Arabian sovereign wealth fund about potentially taking the company private, but a new report has emerged that the latter isn’t going to be sitting on its hands in the interim. The same fund is also looking to invest in one of Tesla’s key rivals.   more
CNBC has the scoop on Tesla’s competition.
PIF, the Saudi Arabian sovereign wealth fund that Tesla Inc CEO Elon Musk has said could help him fund an offer to take his electric car maker private, is in talks to invest in aspiring Tesla rival Lucid Motors Inc, people familiar with the matter said on Sunday.
The talks between privately-held Lucid Motors and PIF underscore the latter’s appetite to invest in electric car makers to diversify the oil-rich Middle Eastern kingdom’s investment portfolio.
The report indicates that PIF’s initial investment in Lucid could be for as much as $500 million, but there could be additional investments to come if the vehicle maker reaches certain milestones. Sources note that there’s no guarantee a deal will be reached.
As for Tesla, CEO Elon Musk shook up the markets when he casually shared his thoughts on taking the company private on Twitter, but there’s also no guarantee a deal will be reached between the two sides.
Tesla Inc shares fell $9.78 (-3.20%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.88%, versus a 7.73% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Production Is On Schedule
body:
If you haven’t heard by now, the fate of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) rests on its ability to produce its electric cars at a much higher scale.more
The automaker has fallen under fire for constantly missing self-imposed production deadlines, but there appears to be a light at the end of the tunnel. As CNBC notes, one analyst recently toured Tesla’s factory, and came away with a bullish conclusion:
“Tesla seems well on the way to achieving a steady weekly production rate of 5,000 to 6,000 units per week,” Evercore ISI analyst George Galliers said in a note following an inside tour of the company’s facilities.
“We are incrementally positive on Tesla following our visit. We have confidence in their production. We did not see anything to suggest that Model 3 cannot reach 6,000 units per week, and 7,000 to 8,000 with very little incremental capital expenditure.”
Despite the upbeat note, Tesla shares took a heavy dive late last week following a blockbuster New York Times interview with CEO Elon Musk. The executive admitted that the last year has been the most stressful of his life, and even raised concerns about his physical and mental health.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $305.50 on Friday, down $29.95 (-8.93%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.88%, versus a 7.73% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Report: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Searches For Second In Command Amid Musk Health Concerns
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is a company in flux.more
The electric automaker continues to struggle to boost production of its in-demand Model 3 sedan, faces major cash flow issues, and its stock is under constant pressure from a barrage of short sellers.
In a recent New York Times interview, CEO Elon Musk opened up about just how difficult the past year has been:
In an hourlong interview with The New York Times, he choked up multiple times, noting that he nearly missed his brother’s wedding this summer and spent his birthday holed up in Tesla’s offices as the company raced to meet elusive production targets on a crucial new model.
Asked if the exhaustion was taking a toll on his physical health, Mr. Musk answered: “It’s not been great, actually. I’ve had friends come by who are really concerned.”
Meanwhile, Musk — ever the bombastic showman — tweeted last week that he want to take his company private, and supposedly has massive Saudi-led financial backing to do so. This prompted an SEC investigation, and likely even more stress for Musk.
Tesla reportedly has been looking for a true second-in-command behind Musk for years, with no success. That search is no doubt reaching a crescendo these days, as the executive’s judgement and health fall under question.
