heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Going Private Could Cause Investors a Capital Gains Headache
body:
If Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) actually does wind up going private, shareholders could find themselves with an unexpected situation to deal with. CEO Elon Musk wants to give existing shareholders a chance to remain invested, and that could lead to a tax bill.  more
CNBC has the details on the situation at hand for Tesla shareholders.
There’s another reason Tesla’s faithful investors might want to scrutinize CEO Elon Musk’s public musings on taking the company private: Shareholders would likely face a tax bill.
Musk’s surprise announcement last week — which is under review for possible violations of securities laws, according to various published reports — included his hope to let shareholders remain invested in a special fund if the company were to go private. He also said he would offer $420 per share.
Bill Smith, managing director at CBIZ MHM’s National Tax Office in Washington, explained how Musk’s plan would work for shareholders. “It would be like buying a mutual fund, only the fund only invests in one stock,” Smith explained.
To make that happen, shareholders would be selling their shares of Tesla to purchase shares in the fund. That’s a taxable event, and both long and short-term shareholders would be on the hook for taxes on profits.
Tesla Inc shares fell $8.07 (-2.41%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 7.74%, versus a 7.35% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Has a Whistleblower Situation On Top Of Everything Else Going On
body:
Yet another situation involving Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is playing out on Twitter. A former employee has been tweeting out various details about alleged problems with Tesla vehicles and parts.more
CNBC has the news on the Tesla whistleblower.
A former Tesla process technician, Martin Tripp, is tweeting internal emails, photos and vehicle identification numbers that he says are evidence of flawed manufacturing practices at Tesla’s battery factory, and of product sold by Tesla that is imperfect, and could put drivers’ lives at risk.
Tesla has characterized Tripp as a disgruntled ex-employee and saboteur in the past.
Tripp has previously spoken out about problems at Tesla’s Gigafactory, and he claims that CEO Elon Musk knew all about it. Musk has denied those claims, and a company spokesperson has once again refuted what Tripp’s allegations.
“As we’ve said before, these claims are false and Mr. Tripp does not even have personal knowledge about the safety claims that he is making,” the spokesperson said. “No punctured cells have ever been used in any Model 3 vehicles in any way, and all VINs that have been identified have safe batteries. Notably, there have been zero battery safety issues in any Model 3.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $334.49 per share on Thursday morning, down $4.20 (-1.24%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 7.43%, versus a 7.11% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Big China Rival to IPO in the U.S.
body:
A Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) rival from across the Pacific is prepared to throw its hat into the ring of the US stock market. Chinese startup Nio has filed for a a $1.8 billion initial public offering. more
Investor’s Business Daily has the news on the Tesla rival.
Chinese electric-car startup Nio aims to become the first Chinese automaker to have a U.S. initial public offering, after filing for a $1.8 billion IPO.
The IPO will help the luxury-car maker compete with Tesla (TSLA). Ironically, Tesla CEO Elon Musk is exploring taking his company private.
Nio launched its first vehicle back in December, a fully electric SUV that checks in at a lower price point than the Tesla Model X sport utility. The Shanghai-based firm intends to have an autonomous electric vehicle for the American market by 2020.
Backers of the startup include Chinese internet giants Baidu and Tencent.

heading: SEC Turns Up Heat on Tesla Inc (TSLA), CEO Elon Musk
body:
There has been plenty of speculation about whether or not Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk broke any security laws by taking to Twitter to share news that he was close to taking the company private. A new report suggests we may have clear answers on that before too long. more
Wall Street Journal has the news on Tesla.
Federal regulators have subpoenaed Tesla Inc., ramping up an investigation into Chief Executive Elon Musk’s tweet last week that he had secured funding to take the electric-car maker private.
The subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission seeks information from each of Tesla’s directors, according to a person familiar with the matter. It isn’t known what information is being sought.
Musk casually tweeted the news last week, and the markets were unexpectedly jolted. It got to the point that trading in shares of Tesla had to be halted due to the gyrations Musk’s commentary inspired. Reporters, analysts, observers, and shareholders have been scrambling ever since in a bid to make sense of it all.
A subpoena is generally the first step towards a formal inquiry. No response from Musk has emerged on social media as of yet.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.76 (-0.22%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 8.78%, versus a 6.49% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Board Looking to Rein in CEO Elon Musk’s Approach to Social Media
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has long had a proclivity for taking to Twitter to share what’s on his mind, and that has led to a number of awkward instances through the years. He took things in a new direction last week with posts about sensitive company information, and Tesla’s board appears to have finally perked up and taken notice.  more
CNBC shares the scuttlebutt surrounding Tesla’s board.
Elon Musk, the electric-car maker’s co-founder and chief executive, stirred up a public storm by announcing on Twitter last week that he wanted to turn Tesla into a private company. In recent days, according to people familiar with the matter, some of his fellow board members delivered a stern message: Stop tweeting.
Mr. Musk hasn’t heeded that advice. He has continued to post messages on Twitter, publicly plotting the company’s strategy and in some cases making assertions of dubious accuracy. That has only added to the chaos engulfing the struggling company.
According to a report from the New York Times, Tesla’s outside directors have hired a pair of powerful legal firms to represent them. One is tasked with navigating potential fallout with the Securities and Exchange Commission over Musk’s tweets, while another will advise them on proposals from Musk about taking the company private.
It’s unclear if Musk intends to ease up on his Twitter habit in the wake of the latest spectacle he created.
Tesla Inc shares fell $3.40 (-0.98%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.68%, versus a 6.65% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Cramer: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Tweet Will Not Receive SEC Disciplinary Action
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk will likely walk away from his latest Twitter controversy unscathed. That’s the take from CNBC’s Jim Cramer, who doesn’t believe Musk will be penalized for his tweet about taking the company private.  more
CNBC passes along what Cramer had to say about Tesla.
CNBC’s Jim Cramer warns Tesla critics about getting their hopes up that the federal government will penalize Elon Musk for his tweet about taking the electric auto maker private.
“If you’re waiting for the [Securities and Exchange Commission] to hammer Tesla, well let me just tell you, we’ll be on Mars” by then, Cramer said Tuesday on “Squawk on the Street.”
Last week, Musk raised eyebrows by sharing in a tweet that he was looking to take the company private at a certain price, and he also hinted that he had secured funding. While it’s an unconventional approach to delivering a major piece of news that raised a ton of eyebrows, Cramer notes that it’s par for the course when it comes to Musk.
“We keep expecting a certain level of convention, and [Musk’s] not going to give it to you,” Cramer said. “Therefore, you should stop looking for it.”

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Working With Several Investment Groups on Going Private Transaction
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) may in fact become a privater company before too long. Just a week after roiling the markets on social media, CEO Elon Musk headed back to Twitter to provide an update on where things stand. more
CNBC passes along what the Tesla chief had to say.
Elon Musk said Monday that he is working with Goldman Sachs and Silver Lake on taking Tesla private.
In a Twitter post, Musk said those two firms are acting as financial advisors, and he’s also working with Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and Munger, Tolles & Olson as legal advisors.
Musk provided additional insight into what’s going on in a blog post on Monday. “I continue to have discussions with the Saudi fund, and I also am having discussions with a number of other investors. … It is appropriate to complete those discussions before presenting a detailed proposal to an independent board committee,” Musk wrote.
The Tesla honcho has received a ton of criticism for last week’s tweet on potentially taking the company private, and questions are still circulating about whether or not he violated any regulations while doing so.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Media Buzz Could Vanish If It Goes Private
body:
As a money-losing company, Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has long relied on shareholders and bondholders to buy into its future growth potential to fund its operations.more
That means the company needs lots of media buzz to keep interest flowing. So for, CEO Elon Musk has done an incredible job of that, but now he’s talking about taking the company private.
Without the daily share price fluctuations — not to mention earnings reports, analyst notes, and the like — how will that affect media buzz? Cullen Roche over at MarketWatch has some interesting thoughts on the matter:
Tesla has a $0 marketing budget. It relies entirely on word of mouth and organic news to generate buzz about the business. This is really interesting in the scope of the stock market because nothing generates buzz quite like Tesla’s stock and the way Musk talks about the stock. You could make a strong argument that Tesla’s most valuable asset is actually its public stock price because it is a near daily source of media attention.
Whether Tesla goes private or not is still up for debate. However, it does seem like a significant amount of attention will be lost if the company does go that route, and that would mean giving up a huge part of what brought the company here in the first place: hype.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $355.49 on Friday, up $3.04 (+0.86%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 14.18%, versus a 7.01% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) New A.I. Chips Just Months Away
body:
On last week’s earnings call, Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk shared some insight on the company’s upcoming artificial intelligence processor. We now have an indication on when it will be released, courtesy of a tweet from Musk.   more
CNBC has the news on Tesla’s new processor.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk said that the next generation of hardware for autonomous driving will probably be available by early next year.
On last week’s earnings call, Musk touted the strengths of the coming Autopilot hardware, which will include an artificial intelligence processor developed by Tesla. But he didn’t say when the technology, which the company started working on about three years ago, would be available to car owners.
Musk provided the update in the form of an answer to a question posed on Twitter about when it would be released. “Probably 4 to 6 months. Those who order full self-driving get the upgrade at no cost. It isn’t needed just for enhanced Autopilot,” he wrote.
There’s no word on how the new hardware upgrades will be implemented as of yet.

heading: SEC May Come Knocking on Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk’s Door
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk may have to pencil in a meeting with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the near future. Musk’s tweet about potentially taking the company private opened up a bunch of questions, including whether or not he violated any laws on the books.   more
CNBC has the news on Tesla.
Elon Musk’s lawyers are probably pouring over rule 14e-8 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 right about now.
That regulation is the one the Tesla CEO may or may not have violated when he sent the markets into a frenzy and halted trading in Tesla’s shares after nonchalantly tweeting Tuesday that he was thinking about taking the electric car company private and had “funding secured,” securities lawyers say.
A number of former SEC enforcement lawyers have speculated that the agency has already opened up a probe on the matter. “I can’t imagine that the enforcement division hasn’t opened a file, that they are not calling his counsel or him and saying ‘we would like whatever papers you have about this, if you have written anything down, if you have talked to lenders, if you have materials about that we would like to see them,'” explained attorney Tom Gorman.
The aforementioned rule prohibits public announcements that are intended “to manipulate the market price of the stock of the bidder or subject company,” among other things.
Tesla Inc shares fell $4.31 (-1.16%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 18.95%, versus a 7.88% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Runs Into Solar Production Issues
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) keeps running onto production issues, and we’re not just talking about with its vehicles either. There are problems afoot at its solar production facility as well, and that’s led to some delays. more
Reuters has the details on the problems Tesla is facing with solar production.
Tesla Inc’s (TSLA.O) production of solar roof tiles has been delayed by assembly-line problems at its new publicly subsidized factory and difficulties producing a product that satisfies the aesthetic demands of CEO Elon Musk, eight former and current employees of both companies told Reuters.
Repeated hold-ups since the Buffalo, New York plant opened last year have forced Tesla’s partner in the joint venture, Panasonic (6752.T), to seek other buyers for the components it had built to sell to Tesla, according to a Panasonic employee, a former Panasonic employee and a former Tesla employee. The issues have also rattled the faith of state officials in Tesla’s ability to deliver on investment and employment promises it made in exchange for $750 million in state subsidies.
Tesla has not offered up any specifics on the troubles it has faced at the Buffalo facility, but the company notes that tweaks are certainly needed before production is ramped up. “We are steadily ramping up Solar Roof production in Buffalo and are also continuing to iterate on the product design and production process,” the company explained to Reuters. “We plan to ramp production more toward the end of 2018.”
We’ll have to wait and see how that turns out, but the report from Reuters casts even more shade in the direction of Tesla’s often-criticized solar wing.

heading: Trying to Understand if Tesla Inc (TSLA) Board is Liking the Go-Private Scenario
body:
All seemed well on the Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) front in the wake of last week’s positive earnings report, but that was just the calm before the storm. CEO Elon Musk hopped on the Twitter machine yesterday to hint that the company was going private, and the market is still trying to make sense of it.  more
Marketwatch shares some insight on the situation surrounding Tesla.
A statement from Tesla’s board members on Wednesday raises further questions following the shock tweet from Elon Musk that he wants to take the auto maker private.
The brief news release from Tesla board members—Brad Buss, Robyn Denholm, Ira Ehrenpreis, Antonio Gracias, Linda Johnson Rice, and James Murdoch—consisted of three sentences:
“Last week, Elon opened a discussion with the board about taking the company private. This included discussion as to how being private could better serve Tesla’s long-term interests, and also addressed the funding for this to occur. The board has met several times over the last week and is taking the appropriate next steps to evaluate this,” the brief release said.
So what does that mean for the future of Tesla as a publicly-traded company? That remains unclear, and the head-scratching and brow furrowing is continuing on the street as a result.

heading: Social Media as a Weapon of Mass Destruction for Short-Sellers and Investors
body:
Like you may have been doing, I was monitoring the markets and minding my own business yesterday when suddenly Tesla (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk decided to launch a nuclear strike against short-sellers in the form of a tweet. On Twitter, Musk stated he is considering taking the company private at $420 and that he has secured the funding. Just like that, Tesla shares took off. Now I have no skin in the game as to being long or short Tesla, but my concern is about what the standard has become for basically “anything goes” when it comes to what gets said on social media. The SEC has been rather quiet to all the things we have seen in the past. Perhaps a symptom of the complacency of the markets and its participants, but my guess is we will see some major fraudulent activity that begins to impact investors, albeit in the form of insider information, pump and dump, or what have you. I’m not saying Tesla’s CEO is doing something illegal, but when some not so honorable folks see how much stock prices can be manipulated through social media, it will be a free-for-all of bad news/info for shady characters.more
Notes From Tuesday’s Action
Relative strength standouts – Broadridge Financial Solutions (BR) – earnings pop, Factset Research Systems (FDS), Five Below (FIVE) – positive analyst commentary, Mosaic Company (MOS) – earnings pop, Twilio (TWLO) – earnings pop, Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) – earnings pop, Biomarin Pharmaceutical (BMRN) – gained in reaction to Spark Therapeutics’ SPK-8011 trial updates, SodaStream International (SODA), Tesla (TSLA) – shares spiked on CEO Elon Musk tweeting about taking the company private, Boeing (BA), EPAM Systems (EPAM), RingCentral (RNG) – earnings pop, Five9 Inc. (FIVN) – earnings pop, Inogen Inc. (INGN) – shares rally ahead of Tuesday afternoons’ earnings results, Rapid7 Inc. (RPD) – earnings pop, but did close off the highs of the day, Ligand Pharmaceuticals (LGND) – earnings pop, Biogen (BIIB) – positive analyst commentary, Constellation Brands (STZ), Madison Square Garden Co. (MSG), Haemonetics (HAE) – earnings pop, Avanos Medical (AVNS) – earnings pop, DexCom Inc. (DXCM), II-VI Inc. (IIVI) – earnings pop, Google (GOOGL) (GOOG), Amazon.com (AMZN), Littelfuse (LFUS), SPS Commerce (SPSC), Jazz Pharmaceuticals plc (JAZZ), Berkshire Hathaway [[BRK.A]] [[BRK.B]], Cavco Industries (CVCO) – earnings pop, Bio-Techne Corporation (TECH) – earnings pop, Tactile Systems Technology (TCMD) – earnings pop, Teledyne Technologies (TDY) – positive analyst commentary.
Other notable names rallying nicely – LGI Homes (LGIH) – earnings pop, Mallinckrodt (MNK) – earnings pop, Dollar General (DG) – positive analyst commentary, Dollar Tree (DLTR) – positive analyst commentary, NVR Inc. (NVR).
Notable names lagging during the session – Credit Acceptance Corporation (CACC), Spark Therapeutics (ONCE) – negative response to updates from the co’s SPK-8011 trial for treatment of hemophilia A, Tenet Healthcare (THC) – earnings-related selling, Weight Watchers (WTW) – earnings-related selling, Zillow Group (ZG) – earnings-related selling, Expeditors International (EXPD) – earnings-related selling, Dentsply Sirona (XRAY) – earnings-related selling, Enanta Pharmaceuticals (ENTA) – company losing Express Scripts position for its Hepatitis C drug, 2U Inc. (TWOU), ANI Pharmaceuticals (ANIP) – earnings-related selling, Pepsico (PEP), ICUI Medical (ICIU) – recent M&A chatter coming apart, TransDigm Group (TDG) – earnings-related selling, Baidu Inc. (BIDU), Marriott International (MAR) – earnings-related selling, Medifast (MED), Teleflex (TFX).
Better Know How to Handle Your Bullpen
Being a New York sports fan (Mets when we’re talking baseball – yes I accept all condolences), I like to listen to the sports radio action online whenever I get a chance. Listening to Mike Francesa (who has made a triumphant return to WFAN after a multi-month quasi-retirement) is always a lot of fun and I enjoy the Yankee phone callers’ drama as much as listening to fellow Mets’ fans moan everyday. One thing that is being brought up is how new Yankees’ manager Aaron Boone has to do a better job with his bullpen or the team could struggle down the stretch. Mike Francesa often likes to point out how good a job the previous manager, Joe Girardi, did with the pen. Girardi spent 10 seasons as manager of the Yankees, leading the team to a 910-710 record and a World Series title. Joe wasn’t always known as the biggest players’ coach and that is what likely made the organization move on, but he was great with his bullpen. If you run a business or manage people, you know there are plenty of levers to pull to get the best out of each and every person in your organization. You don’t want to see them burn out prior to the biggest moments a company could face (new product rollout, market expansions, etc.). The key to long-term success is to know what each person can give you and how far you can take that person with the talent they possess. Just like a baseball manager who has to be able to assess his pitchers and where they are in terms of gas left in the tank, as well as what spots some thrive in better than others. Life is like sports in many ways, even if it’s without those big paychecks in most cases!

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Takes it to Short-Sellers With “Going Private” Tweet
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk was back at his favorite past time again today, but at least this time his words of wisdom had a positive impact on the company’s share price. Shares of Tesla spike when Musk dropped a flippant remark about taking the company private. more
Marketwatch has the details on what the Tesla chief had to say.
Tesla Inc. shares jumped as much as 8% midday Tuesday after Chief Executive Elon Musk tweeted that he was “considering” taking the Silicon Valley car maker private at $420 a share.
Shares were halted about one hour later for pending news.
“Am considering taking Tesla private at $420. Funding secured,” Musk wrote. He would follow that up with yet another tweet to explain that a sale wouldn’t be happening. “I don’t have a controlling vote now & wouldn’t expect any shareholder to have one if we go private. I won’t be selling in either scenario,” Musk shared.
In the interim, trading has been halted on shares of Tesla.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $367.25 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $25.26 (+7.39%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 17.95%, versus a 8.01% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #7 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Warned Short-Sellers They Would Be in for Financial Pain
body:
Short sellers can’t claim that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk didn’t warn them. Musk has predicted that those wagering on his company’s demise would wind up being profoundly disappointed, and a recent spike in shares of the automaker have proven him to be correct for the time being. more
Marketwatch has the details on the pain for Tesla short sellers.
Investors who are betting that Tesla Inc. shares are poised for a fall were sitting on a paper loss of nearly $2 billion Thursday, after the stock rallied more than 16% following its latest quarterly earnings.
Tesla short sellers were down $1.7 billion in mark-to-market losses on the 35.1 million Tesla shares that they have shorted, according to S3 Partners LLC, a company that has access to and tracks real-time short interest data.
While Tesla posted an adjusted loss that was larger than anticipated by analysts – $3.06 a share vs. analyst expectations of $2.88 – Musk impressed on the earnings call. There were positive notes about the path ahead for the company, good news on the production front, and he reiterated that he has no intention to raise additional capital anytime soon.
He also apologized for his behavior on a previous call with analysts in which he engaged in boorish behavior. The market liked what it heard, and short sellers are reassessing their positions as a result.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $352.25 per share on Monday morning, up $4.08 (+1.17%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 13.14%, versus a 7.19% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #7 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Cramer Reiterates Bullish Tesla Inc (TSLA) Call, Agrees With Wall Street’s Take
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is the toast of the town on Wall Street – at least for the time being. A ton of effusive praise has been sent in the direction of the automaker and CEO Elon Musk in the wake of a solid earnings call, including from CNBC’s Jim Cramer. more
CNBC passes along Cramer’s bullish assessment of Tesla.
CNBC’s Jim Cramer gives billionaire entrepreneur Elon Musk high marks for recognizing the need to apologize to the Tesla analysts he dissed three months ago.
On Wednesday’s post-results conference call, Musk said, “My apologies for not being polite on the prior call.”
The Tesla chief struck an apologetic tone with analysts for his rude behavior on a previous earnings call. He also promised profitability was an achievable goal for the electric vehicle maker while reiterating he foresees no need to raise additional funds at this time.
“Damn this was a good call,” Cramer said.” “This was the most thorough, most reasoned, most sane conference call he’s ever given.”

body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is feeling the love from Wall Street in the wake of earnings. That’s true on both the share price front and with enthusiastic takes from those who are tasked with covering the automaker.  more
Investor’s Business Daily has some insight into the positive vibe surrounding Tesla.
Tesla stock soared Thursday after the electric-car maker received upgrades and a price-target increase on quarterly results that indicated Model 3 production will bring profits and help the company avoid further cash infusions.
Shares of Tesla (TSLA) jumped 12.7%, near 339.25, during afternoon trading on the stock market today. Tesla stock rose above its 50-day and 200-day moving average, which are bullish indicators.
Oppenheimer analyst Colin Rusch is among those that have upgraded Tesla in the wake of Wednesday’s earnings. He moved his rating from perform to outperform and boosted his price target to $385.
“While we have been cautious on Model 3 ramp, we believe gross-margin performance on Model 3 will carry the stock over the next 12 months,” he wrote. “With higher volumes and slower spending, we believe Tesla has reached a critical inflection point in its development.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $344.81 per share on Thursday afternoon, up $43.97 (+14.62%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.75%, versus a 6.66% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Former Solar City Employees Accuse Tesla Inc (TSLA) of Accounting Shenanigans
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is facing a wrongful-termination suit from a trio of former Solar City employees. The aggrieved ex-workers are also claiming that Solar City’s accounting practices leave a whole lot to be desired.   more
Marketwatch has the details on the suit that Tesla is facing.
Three former SolarCity Corp. employees have filed a wrongful-termination suit against the company and Tesla Inc., alleging they witnessed wrongdoing that included the practice of creating fake sales accounts to inflate the books.
The San Diego-area plaintiffs, two men and a woman who said they worked as energy consultants, allege that the fake accounts created were used to justify bonuses for those employees involved, and also to justify “an unreasonably high valuation of SolarCity,” according to a copy of the complaint, filed last week in San Diego Superior Court.
Tesla, which acquired Solar City in 2016 for $2.6 billion, has denied the allegations. The company contends that it fully investigated the claims of false sales records and didn’t find any facts to support the allegations.
The former workers have brought a litany of other claims to the table via the suit, including allegations that they were harassed and discriminated against.
Tesla Inc shares rose $30.16 (+10.03%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 6.27%, versus a 5.60% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #7 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Doesn’t Expect to Raise Capital, Eyes China Gigafactory Start
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk struck an apologetic and optimistic tone with analysts on the company’s second quarter earnings call, and that helped to offset the news that the company posted a larger than expected loss. Among the many tidbits that Musk had to share were some that reaffirmed that the company is doing alright on the cash flow front for now.  more
CNBC has the news on Tesla’s earnings call.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk sees no need for his electric car company to raise cash by selling stock and said that a new factory in China will likely be funded with a loan from a local bank.
“We will not be raising equity at any point,” Musk said during Tesla’s second quarter earnings call on Wednesday. “I have no expectation of doing so, do not plan to do so.”
The automaker has a massive cash burn rate, and that has naturally been a point of concern for investors. Musk indicated that the company will be cash flow positive in Q3, and added that the company continues to improve margins while cutting costs.
Musk also explained that the planned gigafactory in China will be funded with “local debt.” That factory would be operational in two years in a best case scenario, and Tesla believes it will produce 500,000 vehicles a year at full efficiency.
Tesla Inc shares rose $26.65 (+8.86%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.38%, versus a 6.14% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #9 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Reports Model 3 Production is on Pace
body:
While delivering its quarterly earnings report, Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) noted that its stated Model 3 weekly production goal is being consistently met. The company is now looking to kick things up a notch as a result. more
CNBC shares the details of Tesla’s new plans.
Tesla said in a second quarter earnings update on Wednesday that it has repeatedly produced 5,000 Model 3 electric sedans in a week. Previously, the company said it would have to hit a weekly run-rate of 5,000 Model 3’s to become profitable, long-term.
Tesla made 53,339 vehicles in the second quarter, delivering 22,319 Model S and Model X vehicles and 18,449 Model 3 vehicles to customers, totaling 40,768 deliveries, according to the earnings release.
The company announced that it’s now shooting for a target of 6,000 Model 3’s per week by the end of August. Tesla also notes that it will be able to hit that mark without building any additional production lines, but they will need to tend to bottlenecks in the current configuration.
Tesla’s optimism on the future was enough to offset a larger than expected loss for the quarter in the eyes of investors.
Tesla Inc shares rose $24.66 (+8.20%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.38%, versus a 6.14% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #9 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Guidance on Profitability Has Investors Excited
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) delivered its quarterly earnings report after the bell on Wednesday, and the automaker posted a bigger loss than expected. However, that bad news was offset by an optimistic look at the future. more
CNBC has the details on Tesla’s earnings report.
With a pledge of future profitability and an apology for past bad manners, Tesla CEO Elon Musk was upbeat in his conversation with analysts during a second-quarter conference call Wednesday.
Tesla shares soared as much as 11 percent in after-hours trading. The stock has been under pressure for some time as investors have worried about the cash the company was burning and whether it would be able to sustain its profitability.
Tesla recorded a loss of $3.06 per share for the quarter. Thomson Reuters estimates called for a loss of only $2.92 per share. The company notes that it has been able to consistently achieve its stated production goal of 5,000 Model 3’s per week, and it now has its sights set on hitting 6,000 per week.
In other positive news, CEO Elon Musk struck an apologetic tone while offering up a mea culpa for his rude behavior on a previous call with analysts. He also notes that the company has no plans to raise additional capital “at any point,” a comment that should put speculation on the company’s cash flow issues to bed for the time being.
Tesla Inc shares rose $25.16 (+8.36%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.38%, versus a 6.14% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Earnings Preview: Stakes High Again as Tesla Inc (TSLA) Gets Set to Report Earnings
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is scheduled to report earnings after the bell today. As per usual with heavily-watched company, there are a whole lot of questions that need answering, including much-anticipated updates on production goals.  more
Marketwatch has a preview of what to expect from Tesla.
The question for Tesla investors may not be asked during the post-results call but it’s increasingly pertinent: Are Musk’s outbursts against analysts, the media, critics and others mere distractions for Tesla, or are they signs of more serious problems at the Silicon Valley auto maker?
Tesla long has been a polarizing stock, and the bear vs. bull needle is unlikely to move much either way when it releases second-quarter numbers on Aug. 1.
Musk has a proclivity for taking to Twitter to get things off of his chest, and critics are typically quick to pounce on him even harder after he does so. It’s unclear if that’s going to change, but we will have some clarity on where things stand with the company as a whole once earnings are in.
FactSet estimates are calling for the company to report sales of $3.99 billion and an adjusted loss of $2.88 per share for the quarter.
Tesla Inc shares rose $0.86 (+0.29%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.24%, versus a 6.32% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Once Again Ramps Up Production as Earnings Loom
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is due to report earnings on Wednesday, and that comes as the company continues to ramp up efforts to sustain its lofty production goals. Reports indicate that Tesla is taking an all hands on deck approach towards making that happen. more
CNBC has the news on Tesla’s production push.
Electric vehicle maker Tesla is taking urgent steps to add workers to its vehicle and battery plants, including flying employees in from out of state and putting them up in hotels, and temporarily enlisting employees from unrelated divisions.
Extra hands are welcome at the factory as Tesla strives to produce 5,000 or more Model 3 sedans each week — a number the company says it must sustain to become profitable long-term. However, shifting employees to work in the factory strains budgets and other business units, according to seven current and former employees. Some of these people requested anonymity because they were not authorized to talk to press.
As production questions continue to loom large over the company’s collective head, so to do inquiries about the company’s fiscal health. There have been a ton of negative headlines out there that suggest Elon Musk and company will be raising cash again before too long. As for reports about the increased production efforts, the automaker released a statement acknowledging what it was doing.
“We’ve historically encouraged employees from around the company who want to assist in delivering vehicles or helping out in the factory towards the end of the quarter,” the statement read in part. “This is purely voluntary and intended to help give employees in different departments a firsthand look at what goes into building and delivering our vehicles.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $296.03 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $5.86 (+2.02%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.92%, versus a 6.28% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Exploring First Production Facility in Europe
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is considering building a gigafactory in Europe. That’s the word from a new report that has hit the wire, which indicates that the electric vehicle maker has already had discussions with two different countries.  more
Reuters shares the report making the rounds about Tesla.
Tesla Inc (TSLA.O) is in talks with authorities in Germany and the Netherlands to build its first major European factory, the Wall Street Journal reported on Monday, citing officials involved in the matter.
The electric vehicle maker has had preliminary discussions with two German states vying to host its Gigafactory in Europe to build cars and their batteries under one roof, the Journal reported.
The report notes that the talks are in the early stages and that there’s no guarantee a deal will be reached. Tesla’s European ambitions have already been acknowledged, including via one of CEO Elon Musk’s tweets from back in June.
“Germany is a leading choice for Europe. Perhaps on the German-French border makes sense, near the Benelux countries,” Musk wrote.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $290.17 per share on Monday afternoon, down $7.01 (-2.36%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.80%, versus a 5.80% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst Stays Committed to Tesla Inc (TSLA) Sell Call Ahead of Earnings
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) checks in with earnings on Wednesday, and one Wall Street firm is reaffirming its rating in anticipation of that. UBS is sticking to its sell rating for the electric vehicle maker. more
CNBC shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
Tesla shares will fall significantly because the company will not be profitable in 2019, according to UBS.
The firm reaffirmed its sell rating for Tesla shares, predicting the carmaker will report second-quarter earnings per share below expectations.
Analyst Colin Langan shared additional insight into the firm’s feelings on Tesla in a note to clients. “We are cautious on TSLA Q2 results … Q2 results [will] likely highlight cash flow and profit challenges,” he wrote. “The market should not ignore fundamental headwinds that persist with regards to TSLA’s Model 3 profitability, stationary storage, and solar … we believe TSLA will eventually need additional outside funding.”
The firm has also reaffirmed its price target of $195 for shares of Tesla.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $290.35 per share on Monday morning, down $6.83 (-2.30%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.74%, versus a 6.08% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Goldman Sachs: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Customer Data Trending Negative Ahead of Earnings Report
body:
Customers and potential buyers just may not be that into Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) any longer. That’s one of the assessments of Goldman Sachs, which has taken a look at the electric vehicle maker in advance of earnings.  more
Street Insider shares Goldman’s take on Tesla.
Goldman Sachs analyst David Tamberrino previewed Tesla Motors (NASDAQ: TSLA) Q2 earnings due on Wednesday 8/1. The analyst said key focus areas revolve around (1) sustainability of Model 3 production, (2) pace and demand-variants of Model 3 order conversion, (3) margin improvement potential, and (4) FCF burn.
Tamberrino also highlighted that in collaboration with the Goldman Sachs Data Works team they introduce a new analysis on Model 3 sentiment based off social media posts. The data potentially points to waning customer enthusiasm for the vehicle as order availability and test drives have increased, he said.
Goldman Sachs has found that weekly posts on the Model 3 have declined from roughly 4,400 per week in 2016 to about 3,000 per week so far this year. Positive skew has also declined precipitously during the same period, from 18 percent to 4.5 percent.
The firm is standing by its sell rating and $195 price target for shares of Tesla.
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.92 (-0.98%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.55%, versus a 6.35% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Cash Problems Appear To Be Getting Worse
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has had cash flow problems for a while, but these issues appear to be coming to a head.more
The electric automaker recently asked suppliers for a refund of a portion of its payment. As CNBC reports, this isn’t the sort of action that a financially secure company typically takes:
While automotive companies asking investors for cash back to support operations is a standard part of the negotiating process, Tesla has repeatedly said it doesn’t need the cash. However, the Sunday memo, in which the company asked investors to return a “meaningful amount of money of its payments since 2016,” suggests otherwise and leaves market watchers wondering if Tesla is being truthful about its cash position.
The company lost about $2 billion last year and burned about $3.4 billion in cash after capital investments. At the end of March, Tesla had about $2.7 billion in cash.
Explaining the move, Tesla commented that “We asked fewer than 10 suppliers for a reduction in total capex project spend for long-term projects that began in 2016 but are still not complete, and any changes with these suppliers would improve our future cash flows, but not impact our ability to achieve profitability in Q3.”
Still, analysts don’t believe this one-time windfall will lead to sustainable profits. That could take several more years, in fact — if it happens at all.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $297.18 on Friday, down $9.47 (-3.09%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.55%, versus a 6.35% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #9 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Author of “The Big Short” Sees Trouble Ahead for Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
We can add another name to the list of those who are short shares of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA). A legendary portfolio manager who nailed the financial crisis well before many others even knew there was a storm a brewing has come forward with his concerns about the company. more
CNBC shares his take on Tesla.
Steve Eisman, the investor whose prescient financial crisis forecast was featured in “The Big Short,” is shorting electric automaker Tesla.
The portfolio manager called the company’s founder Elon Musk a “very smart man” but raised concern about the CEO’s ability to follow through on lofty ambitions.
Eisman is a portfolio manager at Neuberger Berman, and he recently shared some thoughts with Bloomberg Television. “He’s got execution problems,” Eisman said. “He’s nowhere in autonomous driving, as far as I can tell, and big competition is coming in his space next year.”
Eisman bet big bet against subprime mortgage securities before the market imploded in 2008, and he was proven to be right on the money with his call.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $302.44 per share on Friday morning, down $4.21 (-1.37%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.86%, versus a 7.04% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Morgan Stanley: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Has Become Untradeable as Volatility Explodes
body:
The volatile swings in Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) share price makes trading the stock not worth the trouble at the moment. That’s the take from Morgan Stanley, which has shared some thoughts on the automaker’s unpredictability in a note to clients. more
Marketwatch shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
Volatility surrounding Tesla Inc. is making it “extremely challenging” to come out with a coherent trading strategy for the stock at the moment, analysts at Morgan Stanley said in a note Tuesday.
The analysts, led by Adam Jonas, kept their rating on Tesla TSLA, -1.90% stock their equivalent of neutral, saying the stock trades near its fair value amid recent volatility and that they’d “wait for the market to create better opportunity for investors to take a directional view.”
Morgan Stanley analysts explained that they have been peppered with inquiries from investors “about the unpredictable nature of Tesla management’s communications strategy.” Among the trouble spots that investors are looking for insight on are CEO Elon Musk’s highly-questionable behavior on social media, which the firm acknowledges is part of what makes the environment around Tesla so volatile.
“In recent weeks, the subject matter seems to have, at times, strayed away from the business and, as such, has become increasingly difficult for investors to defend,” the analysts wrote.
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.93 (-0.99%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.46%, versus a 6.23% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Odd Request for Suppliers to Return Monies Raises Eyebrows
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is dealing with the aftereffects of yet another memo that has made its way into the hands of the press. The latest leak has to do with the vehicle maker requesting retroactive discounts from a supplier.   more
CNBC has the details on the latest scuttlebutt surrounding Tesla.
In its report Sunday, The Wall Street Journal cited a Tesla memo asking a supplier last week to return a “meaningful amount of money of its payments since 2016.”
The memo said all suppliers were being asked to help Tesla become profitable, the newspaper said, but added that it was unclear how many were asked for retroactive discounts.
There have been plenty of rumblings that suggest Tesla is hemorrhaging cash, and this report isn’t going to help quell those concerns. The WSJ notes that other suppliers were contacted for its report, and none of them indicated awareness of the request.
No comment has been forthcoming from Tesla as of yet.

heading: U.S. Sanctions Could Begin to Impact Tesla Inc (TSLA) Battery Supply Ecosystem
body:
Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) batteries could become collateral damage of ongoing US trade issues and sanctions. Concerns have emerged over the sourcing of a key battery component, and that may throw a wrench into the supply chain. more
CNBC has the details on a potential storm that’s looming on Tesla’s radar.
Panasonic said it was unable to determine how much of the cobalt used in batteries it makes for Tesla cars comes from Cuba, a country subject to U.S. sanctions, and that it had suspended relations with a Canadian supplier as a result of its concerns.
The Japanese electronics giant, the exclusive supplier of batteries to Tesla, made the comments following questions from Reuters about whether the batteries contained Cuban cobalt.
Panasonic receives some of the cobalt it uses to make Tesla’s batteries from a Canadian supplier, which mines for the component in Cuba. The electronics heavyweight isn’t sure how big of an issue this may turn into “due to co-mingling of sources by its suppliers in several phases of manufacturing processes,” but the company is investigating.
“Panasonic has sought guidance from the U.S. Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Controls (OFAC) regarding its interpretation of the scope of the U.S. ban on Cuban-origin imports,” a spokesperson for the company said.
Tesla Inc shares fell $13.08 (-4.17%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 0.72%, versus a 5.70% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: JPMorgan: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Will Crater 40% By The End Of 2018
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is by far the most expensive automaker in history from a valuation standpoint, and JPMorgan sees major downside risk for the stock this year.more
CNBC has more details on the very bearish call that came this week:
The firm reaffirmed its underweight rating on Tesla shares, saying other automakers may price their electric cars aggressively.
Tesla has a “highly differentiated business model, appealing product portfolio, and leading-edge technology, which we believe are more than offset by above-average execution risk and valuation that seems to be pricing in a lot,” analyst Ryan Brinkman said in a note to clients Friday. “We have highlighted more concerns regarding increased competition, including from automakers looking to use the sale of battery electric vehicles to subsidize their more lucrative internal combustion engine portfolio vehicles from a legal, regulatory, and compliance perspective, rather than trying to generate profit on the sale of these battery electric vehicles in and of themselves.”
Brinkman has a $180 December 2018 price target on TSLA, which suggests a 44% downside from Thursday’s closing price. He sees downside risk in the automaker’s second quarter earnings numbers, which are due out on August 1, despite the fact that Tesla was finally able to reach its production target goal for the Model 3.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Earnings Preview: Stakes Are Higher Than Ever
body:
As always, there are a ton of questions swirling around in regards to Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA). Analysts are looking ahead to the company’s Q2 earnings report as the next potential spot to gain additional clarity on the company’s progress – or lack thereof. more
Marketwatch has a preview of what to expect from Tesla.
The question for Tesla investors may not be asked during the post-results call but it’s increasingly pertinent: Are Musk’s outbursts against analysts, the media, critics and others mere distractions for Tesla, or are they signs of more serious problems at the Silicon Valley auto maker?
Tesla long has been a polarizing stock, and the bear vs. bull needle is unlikely to move much either way when it releases second-quarter numbers on Aug. 1.
CEO Elon Musk is consistently in the headlines for commentary he shares on social media, and it’s getting to the point that observers are questioning his ability to lead the company due to some of the outbursts and other talking points he shares. Perhaps a solid quarter of results with muted commentary from Musk to boot will help to calm detractors for the short-term.
As for earnings results, analysts surveyed by FactSet are expecting sales of $4.10 billion and an adjusted loss of $2.77 a share.

heading: Another Wall Street Firm Turns Bearish on Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has fallen out of favor with another Wall Street firm. Needham & Co has downgraded the stock and noted that it worries there may be a rise in cancellations for Model 3 orders. more
CNBC shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
Tesla shares fell on Thursday after Needham & Co downgraded the stock to sell from hold, citing a possible pick-up in Model 3 cancellations.
“Based on our checks, refunds are outpacing deposits as cancellations accelerate,” wrote analyst Rajvindra Gill in the note Thursday. “The reasons are varied: extended wait times, the expiration of the $7,500 credit, and unavailability of the $35k base model.”
The automaker made headlines earlier this month when opened up Model 3 sales to anyone that placed a $2,500 deposit, foregoing reservations in the process. While some observers believe that will lead to a boon in Model 3 sales, the Needham & Co. see things differently.
“In August ’17, TSLA cited a refund rate of 12%. Almost a year later, we believe it has doubled and outpaced deposits. Model 3 wait times are currently 4-12 months and with base model not available until mid-2019, consumers could wait until 2020,” Gill continued.
Tesla Inc shares fell $6.55 (-2.02%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 4.01%, versus a 6.22% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Short-Seller Chanos Continues to Bash Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO
body:
Short seller Jim Chanos has once again taken the time to share some thoughts about Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk. Let’s just say that his impression of the billionaire entrepreneur hasn’t improved in the slightest. more
CNBC shares what Chanos had to say about the Tesla honcho.
Short seller Jim Chanos hit back at Elon Musk on Wednesday, accusing the billionaire entrepreneur of over-promising on Tesla and The Boring Co.’s capabilities.
“What bothers me is not so much the personal stuff and the personal attacks. I’m used to that. It’s the willingness to say things that I think he knows are a stretch, to be polite,” said Chanos, who has been betting against Tesla for years.
Earlier this month, Musk implied in one of his many posts on Twitter that Chanos was a source for some of the negative stories that have made the rounds about the company. Chanos has taken exception to that contention as well.
“We talk to journalists all the time. We have never received insider information from any journalist at any time, including Tesla. And we’ve never paid any journalists,” Chanos said. “These are serious charges. When you make serious charges, you ought to bring serious evidence.”

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Tightening The Grip on Employees
body:
Just weeks after announcing plans to streamline its US workforce, Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has made some tweaks to its attendance policy. Specifically, the electric vehicle maker has clarified its attendance policy for hourly workers. more
CNBC has the details on the changes that Tesla has implemented.
Tesla rolled out a new attendance policy for all U.S.-based hourly employees on July 1st, according to documentation shared with CNBC. The policy spells out specific penalties for lapses in attendance, and Tesla says it is meant to make it fairer — for instance, employees who are 10 minutes late won’t be penalized as harshly as those who are one hour late.
The changes to Tesla’s attendance policy come weeks after the electric vehicle maker announced plans to slash its salaried workforce by at least 9 percent, or about 4,000 workers. The company is pushing hard to ramp up the production of its Model 3 electric sedans, and to achieve positive cash flow and profitability in the second half of this year.
In a nutshell, the policy changes clarify expectations while outlining when managers can impose discipline for workers that are late. The company shared some additional insight when questioned about a leaked memo outlining the new policy by CNBC.
“Based on employee feedback, we’ve recently updated our attendance policy to be more fair and flexible. We’re appreciative of the hard work by our production teams, and regularly review policies to work for our employees. The policy update has been in the works for nearly two months and is similar to what you would find at other companies,” the company said.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.81 (+0.87%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 3.64%, versus a 5.99% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shares in Focus Following Unfortunate CEO Remarks
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk is back in the spotlight yet again, and it has absolutely nothing to do with progress or lack of progress being made by the company. Instead, it once again has to do with Musk’s choice of words on social media. more
CNBC has the details on what the Tesla honcho said this time around.
Tesla’s stock fell Monday after a British diver involved in the mission to save 12 Thai boys and their soccer coach said he is considering legal action against Elon Musk because the company’s boss labeled him “pedo guy.”
Spelunker Vernon Unsworth had called a submarine crafted by a team of Musk’s technicians a “PR stunt.” Billionaire Musk suggested the vessel — made out of a SpaceX rocket part — could be used to assist rescuers in freeing the soccer team from a flooded cave system in Chiang Rai.
During an interview with CNN, Unsworth expressed his displeasure with Musk’s contribution. “He can stick his submarine where it hurts,” he said. “It just had absolutely no chance of working. He had no conception of what the cave passage was like.”
Unsworth was also less than pleased with Musk’s reply and choice of words, and he hasn’t ruled out considering legal action.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $309.51 per share on Monday morning, down $9.36 (-2.94%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -0.59%, versus a 5.62% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Tax Breaks Getting Close to Winding Down
body:
Consumers that were hoping to benefit from a tax break for purchasing a new Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) vehicle had better get a move on. Those breaks will be phased out soon, and that could have impacts on a number of different fronts. more
Motley Fool has the details on what that means for Tesla.
Americans who are hoping to buy a new Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) are now on notice: The fat tax incentive that has helped boost Tesla’s U.S. sales will soon start winding down. According to an update from Tesla, the tax break will start phasing out at the beginning of 2019.
That has implications for car shoppers — and for Tesla’s shareholders. Here’s what we know.
Currently, US buyers of electric vehicles are eligible to receive a federal tax credit worth $7,500. However, that break begins to phase out once the maker of the vehicles sells 200,000 electric vehicles in the US.
Tesla expects to hit that mark sometime this year, which means the tax break will phase out two calendar quarters afterwards. While we don’t know exactly when that will be, we know that the break will be phasing out sometime in 2019 as a result.
Tesla Inc shares fell $7.62 (-2.39%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -0.27%, versus a 5.66% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Stories Of Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Production Hell Continue To Trickle Out
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) originally planned to produce 200,000 Model 3 sedans by the end of 2017.more
When the year ended, it had only made 2,700 of them. Instead of producing a futuristic army of fast-working robots to assemble the electric cars, Tesla has relied heavily on manual labor — even fabricating parts by hand — in order to get the job done.
Now, as Bloomberg reports, it appears that workers endured some extremely tough conditions in order to meet a recent quota:
To battle exhaustion, employees drink copious amounts of Red Bull, sometimes provided free by Tesla. New employees develop what’s known as the “Tesla stare.” “They come in vibrant, energized,” says Mikey Catura, a Tesla production associate. “And then a couple weeks go by, and you’ll see them walking out of the building just staring out into space like zombies.”
Four current employees say the pressure they felt to avoid delays forced them to walk through raw sewage when it spilled onto the floor.
Meanwhile, Tesla’s employees are considering unionizing. Considering the conditions they’re forced to work in, that seems like a really good idea — and a potentially dangerous development for a company that doesn’t appear close to making a profit on the Model 3 any time soon.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $318.87 on Friday, up $2.16 (+0.68%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 2.42%, versus a 5.66% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Has a Whistleblower Situation
body:
A former Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) employee alleges there are serious problems afoot with his former employer. This isn’t just sour grapes from a disgruntled ex-worker being distributed to random news outlets either, as the former employee has escalated the situation substantially.  more
Business Insider has the details on the latest trouble spot for Tesla.
Former Tesla employee Martin Tripp has filed a whistleblower tip with the Securities and Exchange Commission in which he alleges the company lied about Model 3 production numbers and put unsafe batteries in its cars, The Washington Post reports.
According to the Post, which spoke with Tripp’s attorney Stuart Meissner, the complaint repeats claims Tripp had previously made to Business Insider, including that Tesla used batteries with puncture holes in vehicles meant for consumers. Tesla has previously denied this claim.
In addition, the Post reports that Tripp is asserting that the electric vehicle maker inflated Model 3 production numbers by as much as 44 percent. No comment has been forthcoming from the SEC or Tesla as of yet.
Back in June, Tesla filed a suit against Tripp which alleged he hacked and distributed confidential company information.
Tesla Inc shares rose $3.53 (+1.11%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 2.44%, versus a 4.63% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Opens Sales of Model 3 Cars to All North American Customers
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has announced a change in plans that could result in additional interest in its Model 3 vehicles. The electric vehicle maker has scrapped reservation requirements while opening up sales throughout North America. more
CNBC shares the news on Tesla’s changes.
Tesla is taking orders for its Model 3 electric sedans throughout the U.S. and Canada, no reservations required.
Previously, would-be Model 3 owners had to put down a $1,000 deposit to secure a place in line to buy the car. Now, anyone in North America can order one via Tesla’s website.
New customers and reservation holders alike will still need to place a $2,500 deposit to move their orders forward. Those deposits become non-refundable once a VIN number is assigned to the ordered vehicle, which typically happens within a few days of ordering.
Tesla has also announced that orders for the Model 3 will be fulfilled in priority order based on a mix of factors, including date of order.
Tesla Inc shares fell $6.27 (-1.94%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 1.23%, versus a 4.67% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Has Ambitious China Production Plans
body:
There have been some rumblings that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) was looking towards substantially ramping up production in China, and we now have another clue that suggests the same. A report has emerged that Tesla is inching closer to committing to build a factory in Shanghai. more
CNBC has the details on Tesla’s reported plans.
Telsa is planning to build large new plant in China, Bloomberg News reported Tuesday.
Bloomberg said the company is due to sign a memorandum of understanding on the factory with “local entities” in Shanghai, according to its sources. The plant will have a capacity to make 500,000 vehicles per year, the media outlet reported.
Reuters followed up on that report by citing a local media report that says the electric vehicle maker has put pen to paper on agreements with the Shanghai municipal government, Shanghai Lingang Area Development Administration, and the Lingang Group. Those agreements would essentially provide a green light for the factory to open its doors.
No confirmation has been forthcoming from Tesla as of yet on its plans for the factory.
Tesla Inc shares rose $7.87 (+2.47%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 4.71%, versus a 5.18% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Forced to Raise Prices in China as Tariffs Begin
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is already a major exporter of electric vehicles to China, and the company has designs on exporting even more. However, the company now finds itself caught in the middle of the looming trade war between the US and China.   more
As Electrek reports, the automaker has decided to increase prices as a result.
Over the weekend, the prices of the Model S and Model X were increased by 150,000 yuan to 250,000 yuan (~$22,600 to ~$37,600) depending on the version.
Those are significant price increases as the original 25% tariff was supposed to be reduced to 15%, but it was instead increased to 40% in retaliation for the US’s latest list of tariffs for Chinese products.
Tariffs have been increased to a whopping 40 percent as the trade war escalates. Tesla sold more than $2 billion in vehicles in China last year, and that number was only expected to go up. Now that prices have been increased, those expectations may change.
The company reportedly has designs on building a factory in China in the future.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.85 (+0.92%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -0.79%, versus a 4.09% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Bear Market For Tesla Inc (TSLA) Could Be Just Beginning
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) shares dropped around 10% last week alone, and one prominent equity strategist believes there’s more trouble ahead.more
Matt Maley, equity strategist at Miller Tabak, explained his outlook on CNBC recently:
“If you go back two weeks it’s down about 17 or 18 percent and that’s been a second yellow flag for the stock,” Maley told CNBC’s “Trading Nation” on Thursday. “The first one came in the first quarter when the stock broke down below its multiyear trend line going all the way back to 2012.”
Tesla first started selling off in March, breaking below an upward trend line stretching back to 2012 when its shares first began to accelerate. A recovery rally brought its stock up to a year-to-date high of $373.73 on June 18, but it has since dropped 17 percent. Its June rally took it back up to its trend line dating back to 2012 but did not break above it.
That failure to hit new highs is a major factor in the stock’s subsequent technical breakdown, Maley notes. However, TSLA still has a long way to drop before true red flags begin to emerge. If the shares break down below the $250 level, he says, then it will be time to panic.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $308.90 on Friday, down $0.26 (-0.08%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -0.79%, versus a 4.09% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Cramer: Naysayers Be Warned: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Remains a Crowded Short
body:
Shares of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) may get beaten up and battered around from time to time, but long-term shareholders consistently lift the stock back up off of the mat. That’s the take from CNBC’s Jim Cramer, who notes that the company has an innate ability to weather the constant storms that it faces. more
CNBC shares Cramer’s take on Tesla.
Tesla seems to be able to weather negative headline after negative headline without any substantial decline because there are no “real sellers,” CNBC’s Jim Cramer said Thursday.
While the stock was under pressure Thursday after Tuesday’s 7 percent decline, Tesla has gained more than 200 percent in the past five years.
Tesla still stands as one of the most shorted stocks on Wall Street. In recent times, there has been an absolute barrage of negative headlines on the company, and CEO Elon Musk hasn’t been shy about drawing a correlation between those two tidbits.
As Cramer notes, long-term shareholders of Tesla have been “unshakable” to date, and that’s bad news for the plethora of short sellers that are betting big against the company.

heading: Consumer Reports is the Only Critic Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Pays Attention To
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk isn’t shy about pushing back against critics, but a recent instance demonstrates that he knows how to take his medicine as well. However, for that to happen, those that are dishing out the medicine need to bring a certain amount of credibility to the table.  more
CNBC shares the details on something that made the Tesla chief perk up and pay attention.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk has no reluctance in lashing out at journalists. Or Wall Street analysts. Or employees.
But when Consumer Reports opened its mouth about Tesla’s Model 3 sedan, Musk listened. He quickly went to work to resolve the issues the 82-year-old magazine raised with the latest Tesla model. The response was notable for its swiftness, and it spoke volumes about Consumer Reports’ influence.
Back in May, the publication noted that could not recommend the Tesla Model 3 over a braking issue. After a back-and-forth on Twitter, Musk assured CR that he would have it fixed, and he invited the mag to review the vehicle once some tweaks had been made.
That serves as a testament to the sway that the publication continues to hold over the car-buying public, but it should also serve as notice that Musk will play ball when he feels the criticism is warranted.
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.16 (-0.70%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.02%, versus a 3.00% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk’s Battle with Financial Media and Wall Street Analysts Intensifies
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has kicked his war with the press up a notch. Musk has taken umbrage with another batch of negative reports that have made the rounds about his company, and he claims that some outlets and analysts are intentionally propagating negative stories.    more
CNBC has the details on the Tesla chief’s war of words with the press.
The Tesla CEO sounded off on Twitter at media organizations Reuters, Business Insider and CNBC. Musk accused both Reuters and Business Insider of publishing false or misleading stories. He also suggested that CNBC features analysts with poor prediction records.
Musk has criticized journalists in the past and has even said he plans to start an organization that rates reporters. The CEO has had a contentious history with the media and bristled at the amount of attention trained on Tesla from both reporters and investors.
Musk unloaded on Twitter to poke holes in a number of different stories that have been making the rounds. In one instance, he wondered aloud if a Business Insider reporter also happens to be a source for a noted short seller. “Sounds very sketchy if true. @lopezlinette, is it possible you’re serving as an inside trading source for one of Tesla’s biggest short-sellers? An ex-Tesla employee just went on record formally claiming you bribed him & he sent you valuable Tesla IP in exchange,” he shared. “Is this true?
None of the outlets in question offered up comments in response to Musk’s tweets.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $307.41 per share on Thursday afternoon, down $3.45 (-1.11%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.27%, versus a 3.13% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Safety Concerns Surround Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Production Rush
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) was able to meet its latest production goal, but a new report has emerged that says the company skipped a step in the testing phase while doing so. The company contends that it did so only because the test was redundant. more
CNBC has the details on the latest flap surrounding Tesla.
As it pushed to hit its electric vehicle production targets for the quarter, Tesla decided to skip “brake-and-roll” testing for its Model 3 sedans in its Fremont factory.
The news was first reported by Business Insider.
The company managed to meet a self-imposed deadline to produce 5,000 Model 3 cars in a week after several quarters of missing its goals.
The company explained to CNBC that it recently did away with this specific test. “Every car we build goes through rigorous quality checks and must meet exacting specifications, including brake tests. To be extremely clear, we drive *every* Model 3 on our test track to verify braking, torque, squeal and rattle,” the company said. “There are no exceptions.”
The company also confirmed that all vehicles are tested on-site for brakes and alignment after assembly is completed.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.72 (+0.87%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -0.16%, versus a 2.38% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Goldman Sachs Still Says to Sell Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is celebrating the fact that the company has reached its latest Model 3 production goal, but a number of firms are less than impressed. We can include Goldman Sachs in that camp, as the investment giant has reiterated its sell rating. more
CNBC has the details on the lack of enthusiasm surrounding Tesla.
Several Wall Street firms are playing down Tesla’s Model 3 production milestone, remaining skeptical over the carmaker’s finances and demand trends.
Tesla said Monday it reached its one-week production goal of 5,000 Model 3 cars for the last week of the June quarter. But the company fell short on its second-quarter deliveries by posting 40,740 vehicles delivered versus the Wall Street consensus expectation of approximately 51,000.
Goldman Sachs analyst David Tamberrino is standing firmly by his sell rating and $195 price target for Tesla. He explained the reasoning for his bearish sentiment in spite of the recent positive news in a note to clients.
“Model 3 deliveries did miss our bearish estimates and we see the incremental color on Model 3 net reservations (where the company showed its first declining data point) as incrementally negative,” he wrote.
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.10 (-0.63%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 6.92%, versus a 3.14% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Will Hit Profitability by September
body:
Now that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has successfully met its latest production goal, the automaker is on the road to profitability in the coming months. That’s the word from Gene Munster of Loup Ventures, who shared with CNBC his prediction for how the next few months will go for Tesla. more
CNBC shares the analyst’s insight on Tesla.
Loup Ventures’ Gene Munster predicts the embattled automaker will be profitable by September.
CEO Elon Musk announced Tesla aims to produce 6,000 Model 3s per week by August, but Munster says September is a safer bet.
“This 5,000 production number was the first time in about nine months he’s gotten one right. I think it’s safe to always dial back what he’s saying, that’s why we think [Tesla’s] going to meet the production number by the end of the September quarter,” he said. Munster believes that Tesla will become profitable at that time, but he was also careful to temper expectations.
“If they hit that number, it’s going to equate to 48,000 model 3s produced in the September quarter. That should get them to profitability, slightly profitable,” he added. “It’s not going to be wildly profitable in September, I just want to warn everyone, but… it moves them in the right direction.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $3.82 (-1.14%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 7.62%, versus a 2.74% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Sell Tesla Inc (TSLA), Production Spike is Unsustainable
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has reached its goal of producing 5,000 Model 3 sedans in a single week, but one firm doesn’t believe the company will be able to sustain the pace. In fact, CFRA Research is so convinced of that theory that the firm has dropped its rating on the electric vehicle maker. more
CNBC shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
CFRA Research does not believe Tesla will be able to maintain its Model 3 production rate over the short term.
The firm lowered its rating to sell from hold for Tesla shares, citing the stock’s valuation.
Despite his assumption that Tesla will not reach its goals, analyst Efraim Levy is maintaining his $300 price target for the company. He has outlined his reasoning in a note to clients.
“After Herculean efforts and albeit a few hours after a self-imposed deadline, Tesla finally achieved its latest goal to reach production of 5,000 Model 3 sedans per week,” he wrote. “In the interim, we do not see this production rate as operationally or financially sustainable.”

heading: In Tesla Inc (TSLA), Wall Street Continues to Love Disruption Over Profits
body:
Several rough patches in 2018 have done a number on shares of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) this year, but the electric vehicle maker has bounced back each and every time. The company has been on an upward trajectory since its 2010 IPO, and the growth of its share price has been nothing short of staggering.     more
CNBC shares some insight into Tesla’s remarkable growth.
The company’s stock is up nearly 2,000 percent from its $17 per share initial public offering, which was held eight years ago on June 29, 2010.
The stock market is rewarding companies that have a believable narrative on how to survive in a rapidly changing world versus focusing on near-term profit streams. Companies’ current earnings are of little consequence, if their businesses get crushed by tech juggernauts like Amazon or Netflix in a few years.
The company has yet to record a profit on an annual basis, and its cash burn rate has been a regular point of concern. When you add in the various hits and misses on production goals, and it’s easy to see why there are some wicked stretches of volatility for Tesla shareholders.
However, long-term holders have been rewarded handsomely for sticking it out through the company’s various hiccups.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $360.72 per share on Monday morning, up $17.77 (+5.18%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 15.86%, versus a 1.90% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
