heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Finally Hits Model 3 Production Deadline (Barely)
body:
After several missed production goals, Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) finally hit a self-imposed deadline on its Model 3 production line.more
That’s according to an exclusive Reuters report that broke on Sunday:
Tesla Inc nearly produced 5,000 Model 3 electric sedans in the last week of its second quarter, with the final car rolling off the assembly line on Sunday morning, several hours after the midnight goal set by Chief Executive Elon Musk, two workers at the factory told Reuters.
The 5,000th car finished final quality checks at the Fremont, California factory around 5 a.m. PDT (1200 GMT), one person said. It was not clear if Tesla could maintain that level of production for a longer period.
As is his custom, CEO Elon Musk took to Twitter to thank his employees for hitting another milestone of 7,000 Model S and Model X vehicles in a week:
7000 cars, 7 days♥️ Tesla Team ♥️
— Elon Musk (@elonmusk) July 1, 2018

The question now becomes: is this feat repeatable? Workers have reported round-the-clock “all hands on deck” conditions at the factory to hit the goals. We’ll have to wait and see.
Tesla Inc shares rose $18.05 (+5.26%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.15%, versus a 2.52% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Report Suggests Tesla Inc (TSLA) Lagging to Meet Production Results
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is due to provide an update on Model 3 production numbers soon, and the floodgates of speculation have been open for weeks at this point. Sources at the company’s assembly plant have chimed in with their take, and those that believe Tesla will fall short now have some new ammunition for their arguments as a result.  more
Reuters has the scoop on what the Tesla employees had to say.
Tesla Inc is not producing enough Model 3s per shift to reach the 5,000 per week target that Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk said it would reach by Saturday, three line workers at the company’s Fremont, California, assembly plant told Reuters this week.
The company was able to assemble and paint 210 Model 3s during the first of two 12-hour shifts on Wednesday, one worker told Reuters. On one of two Monday shifts, the company produced 305 of the vehicles, another worker told Reuters. The number of vehicles assembled per shift is displayed for line workers in the plant.
There have been a countless number of reports that suggest Tesla is going to miss the mark, as well as a number of predictions from analysts that hit the same note. Musk has dismissed those takes several different times, and he contends that those predicting doom and gloom are off base.
The company had no comment on this latest report. We will have zero concrete clarity on whether or not Tesla is reaching its production goals until the company delivers its update.
Tesla Inc shares rose $5.07 (+1.45%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 12.39%, versus a 2.37% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Not Worried About Missing Production Estimates
body:
Another analyst has chimed in to speculate that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) will probably miss production targets for its Model 3 sedan. CEO Elon Musk has responded on social media, and let’s just say that he expects a different outcome. more
Investor’s Business Daily has the details on the Tesla chief’s latest war of words.
Tesla (TSLA) stock was up for the second straight day Wednesday after Chief Executive Elon Musk hit back at a Goldman Sachs report saying the electric-car manufacturer is likely to miss production numbers for its Model 3 sedan.
“They are in for a rude awakening :)” Musk wrote in response, in an email Tuesday. The only other text in the email was a link to the CNBC story about the report, CNBC said.
Goldman Sachs analyst David Tamberrino offered up his opinion that Model 3 deliveries are tracking below consensus estimates. As he sees it, the electric vehicle maker will deliver 22,000 Model 3’s in Q2, less than expectations of 28,000.
The analyst has a sell rating and a $195 price target on sales of Tesla. Musk hasn’t been shy about pushing back on analyst speculation and projections in recent times. Tesla is expected to report Q2 production and delivery numbers in the beginning of July.
Tesla Inc shares rose $4.50 (+1.31%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.65%, versus a 1.79% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #3 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Opportunity in India to Go Beyond Just Cars
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) may very well have a massive opportunity at hand in India, and it may go beyond electric vehicles. CEO Elon Musk has indicated he’s leaning on the company’s Indian-born chief financial officer, Deepak Ahuja for clarity on when to enter the market and in what form, and scuttlebutt suggests the latter has his eyes on a different approach for the massive market. more
CNBC has some insight on Tesla’s potential plans.
A Tesla spokesman put it more simply, saying Ahuja has an important role in these types of strategic decisions, including whether and when Tesla expands into new markets.
Wadhwa said he had urged Musk to accelerate the move to India but not to rush into selling cars. Instead, he thinks India has a sizeable need for Tesla’s Powerwall home battery, and that’s a more attractive business proposition for Tesla in India than its cars. “This is where the biggest opportunity is,” he said. “The battery when combined with solar cells can solve one of the biggest problems that Indians face — the lack of reliable power.”
On Twitter recently, Musk shared some thoughts on what the future may hold for the company in India. “Would love to be in India. Some challenging government regulations, unfortunately. Deepak Ahuja, our CFO, is from India. Tesla will be there as soon as he believes we should,” he wrote.
However, it should be noted that Musk has recently taken the time to explain that his posts shouldn’t be treated as gospel. “Don’t take my Tweet too seriously,” he shared. “For one thing, it’s called a “Tweet”.”
Tesla Inc shares rose $3.01 (+0.88%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.97%, versus a 2.95% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #3 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Goldman Sachs: Sell Tesla Inc (TSLA) Amid Yet Another Expected Model 3 Delivery Miss
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is likely to miss expectations for Model 3 production and deliveries for the second quarter, and investors should avoid the stock as a result.more
That’s according to Goldman Sachs, which reiterated its Sell rating on the electric automaker this week. CNBC has more details on the bearish call:
Tesla is expected to release its second-quarter production and delivery numbers in the first few days of July. Goldman analyst David Tamberrino expects the company to report it delivered 22,000 units of its Model 3 mid-size electric sedan, which is up from his previous estimate of 19,000 cars, but still several thousand units below an analyst consensus of 28,000. He bases this estimate on data from InsideEVs.com, GreenCarReports.com, and registration bureaus in various European countries.
And though Tesla CEO Elon Musk has said it is “quite likely” the company will hit its goal of making 5,000 Model 3 sedans in a single week by the end of June, Tamberrino wonders how sustainable that rates is.
The good news is, Tamberrino expects deliveries of the Model S and Model X — Tesla’s higher-priced vehicles — to rise 4% and 5% respectively over last year’s levels. That estimate is slightly ahead of the Wall Street consensus estimate.
Still, investors are likely to focus almost solely on Model 3 numbers. The low-priced EV represents all the hopes of the company’s mass market future, and until Tesla’s able to demonstrate solid production gains, the stock will likely endure a major cap on its upside.
Tesla Inc shares fell $3.01 (-0.88%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 9.84%, versus a 2.64% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #3 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Sues Ex-Employee Over Software Hack
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is suing a former employee, Martin Tripp, for allegedly stealing MOS factory software and transferring massive amounts of data to outside sources.more
Tripp denies the charges, which could land him in jail if found guilty. So, what is MOS software, anyway? CNBC has the answer:
First, this is not software that’s installed in Tesla’s vehicles. If anyone modified MOS code, they were not changing the code embedded on chips in Tesla’s cars.
Rather, Tesla built its MOS software to automate factory processes for assembling the Model 3, its newest vehicle. In general, MOS is used to track where a Model 3 is in the process of manufacturing, repairs and testing.
It’s important to note that the software in question has nothing to do with Tesla’s vehicles themselves. Instead, it’s factor software used to manufacture the cars — not operate the cars’ systems or self-driving capabilities.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $333.63 on Friday, down $13.88 (-3.99%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 7.16%, versus a 3.83% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #6 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Analyst: Don't Bet On Tesla Inc (TSLA) Services Unit To Drive Meaningful Growth
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) investors hoping for its burgeoning services unit to drive meaningful upside in coming years might be disappointed.more
That’s according to one prominent Wall Street analyst, who issued some cautious commentary about the electric automaker’s shrinking margins within the segment. CNBC has more details:
Bernstein reiterated its market perform rating on Tesla shares, citing its concerns over the electric car maker’s declining profit margin in its “Services and Other” business segment.
“Tesla reports revenues and gross margins each quarter for its ‘Automotive’ and ‘Services and Other’ segments. Interestingly, ‘Services and Other’ gross margins have steeply plunged in recent quarters,” analyst Toni Sacconaghi said in a note to clients Friday entitled “Services margins are plummeting… does this mean automotive gross margins could be overstated?” “The worry/key question, of course, is whether COGs that should be (or historically have been) booked in the Automotive Segment are now being booked in the ‘Services and Other’ reporting segment, given that investors focus nearly exclusively on Automotive GMs & generally disregard ‘Services and Other’ GMs [gross margins].”
Sacconaghi also reiterated his $285 price target on Tesla shares, which suggest a 24% downside from current levels. He noted that Tesla’s gross profit margin for its Services and Other united plunged to a negative 45 percent in its first quarter of 2018, versus a positive 5 percent Q3 of 2016.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $333.63 on Friday, down $-13.88 (-3.99%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 7.16%, versus a 3.83% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #6 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: 2019 Will Bring Heavy Competition for Tesla Inc (TSLA) in EV Market
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is in line to face stiff competition in the electric vehicle market next year. As analysts from Oppenheimer point out, a number of legacy car makers will be entering the market next year.  more
Marketwatch has the details on the competition Tesla will be facing.
Tesla Inc. will face the first true test of its position in the electric vehicle market in 2019, as competition from legacy car makers, including Jaguar, Porsche, BMW and Mercedes, heats up.
That’s the view of Oppenheimer analysts in a note published ahead of two Tesla bull/bear lunches that they plan to host in New York this week.
Analysts led by Colin Rusch shared their take on what it means for Tesla in a note to clients. “We continue to believe that sustainable disruption in the transportation market both from the fuel and autonomy perspectives is what is at stake for Tesla shares,” the analysts wrote. “In other words, is Tesla going to be the dominant force in the transport market or one of many actors?”
Oppenheimer currently has a perform rating on shares of Tesla, and the firm will be watching closely to see how the electric vehicle maker navigates its way through the remainder of 2018.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) is Reported to Make Cuts in its Solar Division
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) made headlines last week with the announcement that it would be reducing its workforce by nine percent. A new report has emerged that points out the job cuts aren’t just happening at the company’s electric vehicle division. more
Business Insider has the details on where the cuts are happening at Tesla.
Electric car maker Tesla’s move last week to cut 9 percent of its workforce will sharply downsize the residential solar business it bought two years ago in a controversial $2.6 billion deal, according to three internal company documents and seven current and former Tesla solar employees.
The latest cuts to the division that was once SolarCity – a sales and installation company founded by two cousins of Tesla CEO Elon Musk – include closing about a dozen installation facilities, according to internal company documents, and ending a retail partnership with Home Depot Inc that the current and former employees said generated about half of its sales.
Tesla has not provided confirmation on what percentage of the solar workforce would be losing their jobs or which installation locations were on the chopping block. However, the company did provide a basic statement about its plans to Reuters.
“We continue to expect that Tesla’s solar and battery business will be the same size as automotive over the long term,” the statement read in part.
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.56 (-0.74%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 11.61%, versus a 3.64% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Eyes Germany for Europe Gigafactory
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has a habit of dropping company news on Twitter, and he just shared another interesting tidbit in response to a user question. Musk has shared which country is the leading candidate to be home to the company’s planned gigafactory in Europe. more
Marketwatch has the news on where Tesla may be headed.
Elon Musk, apparently undeterred by President Donald Trump’s warnings of rising crime, said Tuesday he is eyeing Germany as a potential site for Tesla Inc.’s planned European Gigafactory.
In a Tweet response to a question from a follower, the Tesla TSLA, -0.05% chief said Germany is a leading choice for the factory, which is expected to produce lithium-ion batteries that can be used in electric cars.
“Germany is a leading choice for Europe. Perhaps on the German-French border makes sense, near the Benelux countries,” Musk shared in response to a question. The company is still building out its US gigafactory in Nevada.
No specific timeline has been unveiled for Tesla’s European factory ambitions.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Suing Former Employee Over Trade Secret Information Theft
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has filed a lawsuit against a former employee over trade secret theft. The suit alleges that the former worker hacked confidential company info and shared it with third parties. more
Techcrunch has the details on Tesla’s case.
Tesla is suing a former employee for $1 million, alleging the man hacked the company’s confidential and trade secret information and transferred that information to third parties, according to court documents. The lawsuit also claims the employee leaked false information to the media.
The lawsuit against the former process technician Martin Tripp was filed Wednesday in Nevada. Tesla declined to comment on the lawsuit, which was first reported by CNBC.
According to the suit, Tripp “admitted to writing software that hacked Tesla’s manufacturing operating system (“MOS”) and to transferring several gigabytes of Tesla data to outside entities.” CEO Elon Musk has recently shared some ominous posts on social media about rogue employees, and he shared another today that indicates there could be more revelations to come.
“There is more, but the actions of a few bad apples will not stop Tesla from reaching its goals. With 40,000 people, the worst 1 in 1000 will have issues. That’s still ~40 people,” Musk shared.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $362.22 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $9.67 (+2.74%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 16.34%, versus a 3.84% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #5 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Employee Sabotage Just the Latest Controversy at Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
If nothing else, the news surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) tends to fall on the interesting side. Another story has emerged that certainly falls into that category, as it includes references to conspiracy and sabotage that have impacted the electric vehicle maker’s operations.   more
CNBC shares the details on this eyebrow-raising story about Tesla.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk sent an email to all employees on Monday morning about a factory fire, and seemed to reference possible sabotage.
Now, CNBC has learned that Musk also sent an e-mail to all employees at Tesla late on Sunday night alleging that he has discovered a saboteur in the company’s ranks.
According to Musk, the rogue employee is responsible for “quite extensive and damaging sabotage.” In the email to employees, he accuses the unnamed employee of “making direct code changes to the Tesla Manufacturing Operating System under false usernames and exporting large amounts of highly sensitive Tesla data to unknown third parties.”
Musk explained to employees that the investigation is ongoing and that he will keep them posted on developments as they arise.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Issues New Warning to Short-Sellers
body:
As Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk sees it, short sellers are playing with fire by betting against his company. He hopped on social media over the weekend to advise that their positions may be in peril over the next few weeks. more
CNBC shares Musk’s warning for Tesla short sellers.
Tesla CEO and chairman Elon Musk went after shorts on Twitter over the weekend. He generally warned investors selling his electric vehicle venture short that they have about 3 weeks to cover if they don’t want to lose their money.
Tesla stock has rallied more than 20 percent since the company’s early June annual shareholder meeting at which Chairman and CEO Elon Muskpromised profitability in the third quarter, and trended more than 4 percent higher through last week after Tesla announced layoffs on Tuesday June 12th. Last week, Elon Musk bought around 72,000 Tesla shares, spending nearly $25 million to do so.
“They have about three weeks before their short position explodes,” Musk wrote. There has been a lot of volatility in Tesla share prices this year, much of which has been a direct result of negative headlines.
Musk hasn’t been shy about pushing back against those headlines, and the market seems to be agreeing with him lately. We’ll have to wait and see if that lasts if another batch of negative headlines hits the wires.

heading: Cramer: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk a Master in Fighting Short-Sellers
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) remains one of the most shorted stocks on the street, but CEO Elon Musk hasn’t been shy about pushing back against those bets. According to one financial pundit, what he’s been doing is working like a charm.  more
CNBC has some insight into the Tesla CEO’s response for short sellers.
Elon Musk is “masterful” in the way he fights back against the short sellers of Tesla stock, CNBC’s Jim Cramer said Thursday.
“You can’t lay a glove on him [Musk]. He floats like a butterfly, stings like a bee,” said Cramer, paraphrasing the famous quote from the late boxer Muhammad Ali.
Just last week, an SEC filing revealed that Musk had snapped up another 72,500 shares of the electric automaker. This comes in the wake of a number of negative headlines, many of which Musk has personally pushed back against, including questions about the company’s productivity and cash flow position. As Cramer sees it, Musk has been providing a clinic on how to respond to shorts.
“I remember when I was a hedge fund manager there periodically would be these companies where they knew how to handle the shorts,” Cramer added. “No one has been as masterful. Elon Musk is masterful. He’ll take the shorts up there with his rocket to Mars.”

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Layoffs All About the Company’s Cash Crunch
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has announced that it will be reducing its workforce by 9 percent, and reaction has been mixed. CEO Elon Musk has referred to it as a simple restructuring, but some critics believes it has more to do with the company’s cash problems. more
Business Insider has some insight into the situation at hand for Tesla.
The layoffs Tesla announced Tuesday shouldn’t come as a surprise. Similarly, you shouldn’t be shocked if the company makes other dramatic moves in the coming months.
You see, Tesla CEO Elon Musk is caught in a kind of bind. His company is hemorrhaging cash as it has been struggling to ramp up production of its new Model 3 car. The company has said it won’t start generating profits from the vehicle until it’s making 5,000 of them a week; at last check, it could sustainably make only 3,500 a week.
Investors have taken notice of Tesla’s seemingly unquenchable thirst for cash, and plenty of concerns have been raised about whether the company will be able to continue at its current cash burn rate. That’s led to a belief that the company will have to raise capital again, but Musk believes the company will be generating positive cash flow by Q3.
Only time will tell which perspective is correct on Tesla, but you can rest assured that a ton of analysts have their eyes on the company to pounce on red flags as they emerge.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $355.64 per share on Friday morning, down $2.08 (-0.58%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 14.23%, versus a 3.78% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Short-Sellers Remain Defiant in Battle Against Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
There has been plenty of volatility in shares of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) this year, but the negative sentiment that surrounded the company for much of it seems to be leveling out. However, some investors are standing firm in their position that all is not well with the electric vehicle maker.  more
CNBC has the details on short seller sentiment on Tesla.
It’s been a rough few weeks for investors betting against Tesla, one of the most-shortedstocks in the United States.
Tesla stock has rallied almost 17 percent since the company’s early June annual shareholder meeting at which Chairman and CEO Elon Musk promised profitability in the third quarter. Shares kept trending higher this week, rising slightly after Tesla announced plans to lay off 9 percent of its workforce. Musk added $25 million worth of shares to his personal holdings.
Tesla’s recent restructuring and layoffs has been viewed as a positive by the market as a whole, but short sellers see another red flag. As they see it, it’s just further evidence that the company is in a cash crunch. What’s more, some short sellers believe Tesla will have a hard time getting their cash calls answered if they need to go that route.
Kynikos Associates founder Jim Chanos is among those in the bearish camp on Tesla, and he explained to CNBC what his concerns are with the company. “The company is not profitable from operations. The company will … do a lot of one-time items, we believe, to show a GAAP profit in the third quarter. But they are just that, one-time items,” he said. “The basic problem is that [Musk] is making the cars at not enough of a gross margin to make money — and that’s before the competition rolls out, which is late this year and early next year.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $353.60 per share on Friday morning, down $4.12 (-1.15%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 13.57%, versus a 3.98% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of B (Buy), and is ranked #8 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Cancellation Rate Worse Than Wall Street Imagines
body:
While the general sentiment surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) seems to be trending back in the positive direction, not all analysts are completely convinced. We can add Vertical Group’s Gordon Johnson to the camp of the thoroughly unconvinced, as he has dropped his already street-low price target even lower. more
Zero Hedge passes along the analyst’s incredibly bearish take.
One main reason: according to Johnson’s calculations, the cancellation rate on Model 3 is a disastrous 66%, up 33% YTD, or as Gordon says, “Boy… that’s a Lot of Model 3 Cancellations.” Here are the details from Gordon:
Our work (Ex. 1) implies a 66% cancellation rate for the “euphoric” day-1 Model 3 reservations of ~140K. When applying this figure to our est. for 582K in gross reservations through mid-Apr. (i.e., 518K in gross reservations 7/31/17 + 7.55K/month in new reservations 7/31/17-to-4/15/18 [or 64K] to account for a monthly cancellation rate of 1% as of 7/31/17), we calculate sales from 582K in early Model 3 reservations of just 197K – we remind our readers that in mid-Apr. ’18, TSLA sent out configuration invites to US-based non-owners who made reservations one day after reservations opened up to the public (i.e., 4/1/16); from this, one can imply in mid-Apr. ’18 TSLA had fully exhausted Model 3 reservations made 3/31/16 (i.e., day one); furthermore, as of mid-Apr. ’18, all US-based owner reservations were complete.
In addition to showing his math for his estimated cancellation rate, Johnson has also provided a new valuation target for the electric vehicle maker. “Applying a 0.725x multiple to our new 2020 rev est. of $21.7bn (Street $34.7bn), our year-end 2019 price objective edges modestly lower to $93/share (-73% downside from today’s closing price) from $99/share previously.”
That would be a stunning drop – to say the least – from Tesla’s current price point. We’ll have to wait and see if Johnson’s crystal ball proves to be accurate or not.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $357.72 per share on Thursday afternoon, up $12.94 (+3.75%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 14.89%, versus a 4.87% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Demand for Nickel Booming for Tesla Inc (TSLA), Other EV Manufacturers
body:
As Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) and other automakers roll electric vehicles off the assembly line, demand for minerals used to make batteries naturally soars. That’s having a ripple effect in the mining industry, and one company is taking steps to deal with the spike. more
Investor’s Business Daily has the news on a mineral that has been flying off the shelves.
As Tesla (TSLA), General Motors (GM), Ford Motor (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) accelerate electric vehicle production, Brazilian mining giant Vale (VALE) will invest roughly $1.54 billion to launch underground nickel mining operations in Canada to meet booming demand for minerals used in EV batteries.
Vale’s Voisey’s Bay nickel move came as that project was nearing the end of its open-pit life, Bloomberg said. The bet on underground mining will extend the life of the mine by 15 years and create 1,700 direct jobs. Construction is likely to start this summer, with operations kicking off in April 2021.
At the present time, electric vehicles account for roughly three percent of the auto market. According to industry forecasts, that number will surge to between 40 and 50 percent on a worldwide basis by 2040.
That should be good news for miners, and Vale is proactively getting ready.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $343.19 per share on Wednesday morning, up $0.42 (+0.12%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.23%, versus a 5.04% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Pulls Out of Home Depot Solar Partnership
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has announced another change, and this one has nothing to do with its electric vehicles or solving any production issues. This time around, changes are coming to the solar side of the business. more
CNBC has the details on Tesla’s move.
Tesla is ditching Home Depot as a sales partner for its residential clean energy products, CEO Elon Musk revealed in an e-mail to his employees on Tuesday. The move is part of a broader restructuring of the company which also entails layoffs of about 9 percent of the Tesla workforce, not including hourly production associates involved in manufacturing.
Company CEO Elon Musk explained the decision in an email to employees. “In addition to this company-wide restructuring, we’ve decided not to renew our residential sales agreement with Home Depot in order to focus our efforts on selling solar power in Tesla stores and online,” he wrote. “The majority of Tesla employees working at Home Depot will be offered the opportunity to move over to Tesla retail locations.”
As for the layoffs, they are expected to begin this week and be wrapped up rather quickly.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.77 (-0.22%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.09%, versus a 4.94% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Restructuring Will Lead to Job Cuts
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has hinted that changes are coming to Tesla, and we now have clarity on what he meant by that. A big round of layoffs is on the horizon for the electric vehicle maker as it attempts to become leaner and more efficient.  more
Electrek has the news on Tesla.
Last month, Tesla CEO Elon Musk announced a vague plan to “restructure” the company in order to achieve profitability during the second half of the year.
Following the announcement, Electrek has now learned of a round of layoffs currently ongoing at Tesla, which could see as much as 9% of the workforce leave the company.
For round numbers, Tesla has more than 30,000 employees, which means that around 3,000 jobs could be eliminated when all is said and done. Musk provided more clarity on the decision making process in an email to employees.
“We made these decisions by evaluating the criticality of each position, whether certain jobs could be done more efficiently and productively, and by assessing the specific skills and abilities of each individual in the company,” he wrote. “As you know, we are also continuing to flatten our management structure to help us communicate better, eliminate bureaucracy and move faster.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $342.77 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $10.67 (+3.21%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 10.09%, versus a 4.94% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Rebound Continues on Analyst’s Optimistic Model 3 Expectations
body:
The sentiment seems to be shifting around sentiment Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA). Another firm has climbed on board the momentum train to share a positive note about the automaker. more
Marketwatch shares what the firm had to say about Tesla.
Tesla Inc.’s stock TSLA, +3.22% ran up 2.3% in premarket trade Tuesday toward a three-month high, after KeyBanc Capital raised its revenue expectations for the current quarter, citing evidence of a “meaningful ramp” in Model 3 volumes. “Based on our conversations with 20 sales centers across the U.S. (18% of total), we believe weekly run-rate volumes have moved from the high teens per store per week to the low 30s since our last checks in April,” analyst Brad Erikson wrote in a note to clients.
Erikson was initially expecting revenue of $3.91 billion for Tesla in Q2, but he has kicked those expectations up several notches to $4.37 billion. According to FactSet, consensus estimates are calling for  $4.23 billion.
“With three weeks to go in the quarter, we estimate the company is tracking to something between 30,000 and 35,000 Model 3 deliveries in the quarter versus our prior view of 20,000-25,000,” Erikson added.
Tesla Inc shares rose $10.37 (+3.12%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 6.66%, versus a 4.80% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Vehicles to Become All Self-Driving Following Upcoming Software Update
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has dropped a rather bold piece of news about an upcoming update in nonchalant fashion. Chief executive Elon Musk has shared what sounds like a major update for Tesla vehicles in a post on Twitter. more
Yahoo passes along what Musk had to say.
The next major Tesla software update will give all versions of the electric car “full self-driving features,” chief executve Elon Musk has announced.
In response to comments on Twitter from Tesla owners about suggested features, Mr Musk said the update would fix issues with the system understanding lane merging and go even further.
Musk is no stranger to dropping interesting tidbits on social media. The hardware is already there for the vehicles to have full self-driving capabilities, and it sounds like the software has caught up.
“That issue is better in latest autopilot software rolling out now and fully fixed in August update as part of our long-awaited Tesla Version Nine,” Musk shared. “To date, autopilot resources have rightly focused entirely on safety. With V9, we will begin to enable full self-driving features.”

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Could Be Hurt By GM/Honda EV Battery Alliance
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has owned a near monopoly on EV batteries over the past several years, but some new competition is stepping up soon.more
As Investor’s Business Daily reports, Japan’s largest automaker and America’s largest automaker are teaming up to make sure they both have enough supply to power a new generation of cars:
Honda will “source” battery cells and modules from GM, the companies jointly announced in a news release Thursday. GM’s next-generation battery system will deliver more energy, be smaller than current technology, and charge more quickly, according to the release.
The battery will power both Honda’s future electric vehicles (EVs) and GM’s own, mainly for the North America market.
The move will no doubt reignite the rivalry between GM and Tesla, which produce the lion’s share of EVs sold in America. GM’s Chevy Volt has proven a solid — and perhaps more importantly, readily available — alternative to Tesla’s Model 3, which continues to have production issues. Both companies are angling to dominate the battery production market, which is seen as the key cog in the wheel of EV production in general.

heading: Technical Analyst Sees Bullish Move Ahead for Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
It has been a volatile ride for shareholders of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) in recent months, but one analyst has a take that will bring a smile to their faces. According to the analyst, there’s a big bullish move ahead for the carmaker. more
CNBC shares the analyst’s take on Tesla.
A surge this week has Tesla racing back to levels not seen in three months and reversing a sell-off that had wiped out a year’s worth of gains. The charts suggest its comeback is just getting started, one technical analyst says.
“Tesla likes to consolidate and then thrust higher,” TradingAnalysis.com’s Todd Gordon told CNBC’s “Trading Nation” on Thursday. “What we’ve seen over the last couple of years is Tesla’s big-time consolidation.”
Over the past three years, Tesla has come under heavy selling pressure on two separate occasions over concerns about the company’s fundamentals. Share prices navigated their way through both rough patches, and Gordon is targeting a move above $400 now that the latest rough patch seems to have subsided.
“As everyone was really coming down on Telsa on the fundamentals you can see that all we did was a 37 percent decline which was very much in line with the last decline, which was 34 percent. It’s actually very symmetrical, very technical, and very expected,” he added.
Tesla Inc shares rose $3.11 (+0.98%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 2.14%, versus a 4.17% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Short Sellers Humbled By Another Stock Rally
body:
Shorting Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) can sometimes be a profitable venture, but boy is it risky.more
The electric automaker’s stock had been a laggard for much of 2018, and actually hit a new 52-week low back in April. But a vote of confidence for CEO Elon Musk from shareholders at Tesla’s annual meeting late Tuesday, combined with Musk’s claim that it’s “extremely likely” Model 3 production will finally hit the 5,000 car per-month goal by the end of June, spiked the shares by almost 10%.
As CNBC reports, that move led to a lot of pain for short sellers:
Investors betting against Tesla lost more than $1 billion Wednesday as the company’s shares rallied the most in over two years, according to estimates from financial technology firm S3 Partners.
Tesla stock closed Wednesday up 9.7 percent at $319.50 per share, meaning investors who sold the stock short lost a collective $1.07 billion in a single day, estimates S3. Tesla bears have lost nearly $5 billion in mark-to-market losses since 2016, S3’s head of predictive analytics Ihor Dusaniwsky told CNBC.
Despite the risks, Tesla remains the most heavily shorted stock in the United States. Second on that list is Amazon, followed by Apple, Netflix, and Alphabet — a veritable who’s who of technology juggernauts.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.85 (-0.58%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 2.62%, versus a 4.37% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #11 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shareholder Meeting Update Helps Stock Move Higher
body:
The negative headlines that have been surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) in recent times have pointed to a company that appeared to be at a cross roads. We now have some clarity on what the path forward will be, and the market is reacting accordingly.  more
CNBC has the news that has led Tesla shares to pop.
Tesla stock rose more than 8 percent Wednesday, on track for its best day of trading in over two years, after the company revealed it is nearing its Model 3 weekly production rate and shareholders backed Elon Musk as chairman and CEO.
Musk told shareholders it is “extremely likely” Tesla will hit a weekly Model 3 production rate of 5,000 cars by the end of the month. Tesla has been struggling with production issues and faces concerns about its finances.
Reaching production goals for the Model 3 has been challenging for Tesla thus far, and Musk has had to adjust forecasts a number of different times as a result. Based on his comments at the shareholder meeting, it sounds like the troubles are a thing of the past.
To further bolster the enthusiasm surrounding the company at the moment, Tesla has announced plans to open a factory in Shanghai, its first outside of the US.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $316.51 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $25.38 (+8.72%). Year-to-date, TSLA has gained 1.66%, versus a 4.24% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Having to Come Up With More Model 3 Customer Refunds
body:
While anticipation remains high for Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) Model 3, enthusiasm has being tempered among some early reservation holders. In fact, nearly a quarter of deposits have been refunded as of April, according to one data analytics firm.  more
Investor’s Business Daily has additional details on Tesla’s deposit situation.
Reservation holders for a Tesla (TSLA) Model 3 are having second thoughts, as nearly a quarter are asking for their deposits to be refunded, according to a report Monday by data analytics firm Second Measure.
“Investors have good reason to be interested,” the company said in a blog post. “As of last quarter, more than a third of Tesla’s cash holdings were customer deposits.”
At the end of December, Tesla had $663.8 million in customer deposits on its balance sheet. Fast forward to Q1, and that number dropped to $616.4 million. According to Second Measure, 23% of deposits for the Model 3 have been refunded as of April.
However, eight percent of reservation holders have gone ahead and forwarded an additional $2,500 to Tesla for configuration options, a step which also locks in the initial deposit.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.87 (-0.63%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.69%, versus a 3.43% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: CEO Elon Musk Control Over Tesla Inc (TSLA) Faces Big Test on Tuesday
body:
If nothing else, the news surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is generally not boring. It may get even more interesting on Tuesday, as Tesla chief Elon Musk could find himself in the hot seat. more
CNBC has the details on what could be an interesting day for Tesla shareholders.
Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk faces votes at Tuesday’s shareholder meeting that will challenge his grip on the electric carmaker, but he may be able to count on some powerful friends: big fund managers likely to be fans.
These stockpickers would have weighed Musk’s forceful public persona in their decisions to buy and hold Tesla shares in the first place, and likely are ready to back him at the meeting to be held in Mountain View, California, said analysts, corporate governance experts, and investors.
Overall concerns about the company’s production and other flaps regarding Musk’s management style have been in the headlines an awful lot in recent months. The question comes down to whether or not his vision outweighs the trouble at this point in time, as well as if he’s the right one to be guiding the ship through turbulent waters. According to Morningstar analyst David Whiston, the big investors will likely side with Musk.
“I doubt they would vote against Elon because if you don’t believe in Elon, why are you in the stock?” he said.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $296.80 per share on Monday afternoon, up $4.98 (+1.71%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.67%, versus a 3.41% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Is Tesla Inc (TSLA) Hiding Safety Problems At Its Fremont Plant?
body:
Some Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) workers are reporting multiple undisclosed fires at the electric automaker’s factory, perhaps calling into question the company’s dedication to safety and disclosing negative incidents.more
CNBC has more details on the interesting development:
Tesla has had at least four fires in the paint shop at its Fremont, California, factory since 2014, according to five people familiar with operations at that plant.
One previously reported fire, in April, was serious enough to stop Model 3 production for multiple shifts that week, these people said. Another fire took place in January 2016 and caused at least a day of suspended vehicle production. Both fires damaged expensive equipment.
The workers reportedly blame the fires on inadequate cleaning, insufficient maintenance, and a lack of proper training for new employees. These issues have grown amid extreme pressure from executives to meet lofty production goals, the people said.
For its part, Tesla downplayed the severity of the fires, and said it’s doing more to improve safety. “In recent months, we have further enhanced the safety and efficiency of our paint shop, including significant upgrades to equipment, as well as an extensive maintenance effort involving cleaning and calibration,” the company said in a statement.
TSLA shares closed at $291.82 on Friday, up 2.49% on the day.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Inches Toward Profitability
body:
Tesla Inc (TSLA) is famous for burning through cash at a rapid rate (and may have to raise more money very soon), but a new report notes that Model 3 profitability may be much closer than previously thought.more
BGR has more details on the interesting development:
Interestingly enough, if Tesla can really boost Model 3 production, the company may be able to generate more of a profit than most analysts seem to be expecting. To this point, Electrek points us to a new Model 3 teardown which reveals that the total cost of putting together a Model 3 (parts + labor) is approximately $28,000.
Margins in the auto-industry are notoriously slim, but the Model 3 could prove to be incredibly profitable for Tesla if production sees a massive boost. As Elon Musk intimated via Twitter recently, Model 3 shipments thus far are low enough that Tesla would lose money if the company only focused on delivering the minimum cost ($35,000) Model 3 as opposed to focusing on more expensive variants.
That means if and when Tesla can actually significantly ramp up Model 3 production, profitability could soon follow. The company has over 400,000 reservations for Model 3s waiting in the wings, so demand isn’t the issue — it’s that pesky production bottleneck that has been the bane of Elon Musk’s existence for the past several months.
Tesla shares closed at $291.82 on Friday, up 2.5% on the day.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Back in Good Spirits With Consumer Reports Following Software Update
body:
Consumer Reports took a look at Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) Model 3 a few weeks back, but the publication decided that it wouldn’t be able to slap a recommendation on the vehicle. Tesla responded by making some tweaks and asking CR to take another look, and that has proven too be a solid decision.    more
CNBC passes along a positive note for Tesla.
Consumer Reports said Wednesday it now recommends the Tesla Model 3, reversing an earlier decision over the car’s long stopping distance and other issues. The group said Tesla’s ability to fix the issue with a remote software update was a first for a carmaker.
Tesla improved the car’s braking distance by about 20 feet through a remote software update, placing the car within the typical stopping distance for its class, the group said. Consumer Reports had previously said the Model 3 had the longest stopping distance of any contemporary car it tested, including the much larger Ford F-150 full-size pickup.
Consumer Reports director of automotive testing Jake Fisher refers to the reversal of course as an “industry first.” CEO Elon Musk wasn’t real pleased that CR didn’t give the vehicle the nod, and that led to him essentially asking for a do-over if problems were addressed. The publication agreed, and CR is now comfortable enough to recommend the vehicle to its readers.
“Really appreciate the high quality critical feedback from @ConsumerReports. Road noise & ride comfort already addressed too,” Musk shared on Twitter. “UI improvements coming via remote software update later this month.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $291.28 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $7.52 (+2.65%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.45%, versus a 2.68% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #17 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Pulling Out All Stops to Keep Model 3 Battery Production Going
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has its hands full with navigating its way through a number of different issues at the moment, but the company is taking a proactive approach towards making sure they can cross one potential problem off of the list. Reports indicate that the electric vehicle maker is about to shore up battery production in a big way. more
CNET has the news on the steps that Tesla is taking.
Tesla is allegedly pulling out all the stops in an effort to remove every possible roadblock that could stymie Model 3 production.
Tesla has flown six planes’ worth of battery production equipment from Europe in order to bolster efforts at its Gigafactory plant in Nevada, Reuters reports, citing people familiar with the matter. CEO Elon Musk has claimed in the past that improvements in battery production will provide a solid boost to the Model 3’s production efforts.
Reuters notes that sources claim that “money seems to be no obstacle” in terms of making sure this initiative goes off without a hitch. While it’s admirable that the company is going out of its way to be proactive when it comes to battery production, there’s a rather large elephant in the room when it comes to dropping a ton of cash to make it happen.
There have been a number of concerns raised over Tesla’s cash burn rate as it is, and pricey transport costs aren’t going to help that situation. That said, perhaps it’ll all balance out in the end if the company can insure that Model 3 production isn’t impacted in the future.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.31 (-0.46%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -9.71%, versus a 1.73% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #17 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Pays Out Autopilot Lawsuit Claims
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has been facing a class action suit for problems related to its Autopilot feature, and the company has taken a big step towards putting the issue in the rear view mirror. The electric vehicle maker is prepared to pony up and pay in a bid to satisfy aggrieved customers.  more
Techcrunch has the details on Tesla’s decision.
Tesla has paid out $5 million to settle a 2017 class action lawsuit that originally alleged that the Autopilot feature shipped in 2016 in the company’s cars was “essentially unusable and demonstrably dangerous.” The settlement does not admit this, but rather compensates owners for delays in delivering the promised functionality; owners who paid $5,000 for Autopilot will be reimbursed for as little as $20 or as much as $280 according to how long they had to wait.
Although Tesla claimed that the semi-autonomous driving software would improve safety and reduce the possibility of collisions, it was in practice erratic and unreliable. “Contrary to what Tesla represented to them, buyers of affected vehicles have become beta testers of half-baked software that renders Tesla vehicles dangerous if engaged,” read the initial complaint.
“We want to do right by those customers, so as part of a proposed settlement agreement for a class action lawsuit filed last year, we’ve agreed to compensate customers who purchased Autopilot on Hardware 2 vehicles who had to wait longer than we expected for these features,” a statement fro Tesla reads in part. The company has decided to pay up to put the matter to rest, and it has even decided to take the step of kicking things up a notch for other affected consumers.
“Although the settlement is specific to customers in the US, if it is approved by the court, we’ve decided to compensate all customers globally in the same way. There’s no legal obligation to do so, but it’s the right thing to do,” the statement continued.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $283.76 per share on Tuesday morning, up $4.91 (+1.76%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.86%, versus a 1.77% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Flies Costly Equipment In From Europe To Ramp Battery Production
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) continues to have trouble producing its Model 3 sedan in large numbers, and a big part of the problem is a lack of batteries.more
To address this issue, as Reuters reports, the company is apparently going to extreme measures:
Tesla Inc has flown six planes full of robots and equipment from Europe to California in an unusual, high-stakes effort to speed up battery production for its Model 3 electric sedan, people familiar with the matter told Reuters this week.
Transporting equipment for a production line by air is costly and hardly ever done in the automotive industry, and the move underscores Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk’s urgency to get a grip on manufacturing problems that have hobbled the launch of the high-volume Model 3 and pushed Tesla’s finances deep into the red.
Model 3 production has repeatedly missed the company’s own estimates, and investors are beginning to wonder if the automaker can ever live up to its lofty goals of escaping the niche market to become a major player in the industry. CEO Elon Musk has promised that Tesla would stop burning cash in the third quarter of this year, but that seems highly unlikely at this juncture.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $278.85 on Friday, up $1.00 (+0.36%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -10.44%, versus a 2.39% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #17 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Analyst: Recent Media Headlines on Tesla Inc (TSLA) Are Overblown
body:
The recent wave of negative headlines surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) doesn’t matter all that much in the grand scheme of things, according to one Wall Street analyst. Baird still anticipates a substantial rally from the carmaker, and the firm has reiterated its rating to get that point across. more
CNBC shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
The deluge of recent negative media coverage on Tesla is missing the real story, according to one Wall Street firm.
Baird reiterated its outperform rating for Tesla shares, predicting the electric car maker will make significant progress in raising its Model 3 production volumes.
“We think we have hit a peak in negative coverage/sentiment, and believe shares could appreciate significantly with execution, which should coincide with an improvement in sentiment,” shared analyst Ben Kallo said in a note to clients.
He’s sticking by his $411 price target for Tesla as well. Interestingly, CEO Elon Musk hopped on Twitter to share some sentiments about media coverage of his company. “The holier-than-thou hypocrisy of big media companies who lay claim to the truth, but publish only enough to sugarcoat the lie, is why the public no longer respects them,” he shared.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $279.07 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $4.06 (+1.48%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -10.37%, versus a 2.85% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Quickly Takes Advantage of China Tariff Cuts
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is among the carmakers that will benefit substantially from China’s decision to slash tariffs, and the company has decided what it’s going to do with at least some of the savings. Prices are going to be coming down, and that could lead to the electric vehicle maker gaining even more traction in the massive market.  more
Reuters has the details on Tesla’s price cut.
Tesla Inc has slashed up to $14,000 off its Model X in China after Beijing announced major tariff cuts for imported automobiles, a potential sales boost for the U.S. firm as the world’s largest auto market pivots towards electric cars.
The carmaker will lower prices of its Model S and Model X cars by just over 6 percent, a Beijing-based sales representative told Reuters on Wednesday.
While that’s a substantial savings for consumers, a top-of-the range Model X will still set customers back 1.3 million yuan ($203,830). For comparison sake, the priciest Model X in the United States checks in with a price tag of  $140,000.
Automotive Foresight’s Yale Zhang predicts that “imminent price adjustments in the higher-end segment, that will over time lead to a pricing adjustment for the entire market.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.93 (-0.70%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -11.67%, versus a 2.56% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Consumer Reports to Test Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Model 3 Again
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) received a less than flattering review from Consumer Reports for its Model 3 sedan, but it looks like the company is going to get a rare do-over. The publication says it’ll be happy to conduct a re-test if the company fixes the issues as promised. more
Reuters passes along a positive piece of news for Tesla.
Consumer Reports said Tuesday it will retest brakes on Tesla Inc’s new Model 3 sedans after Chief Executive Elon Musk promised a software update, but the potential hit to sales from the magazine’s negative review weighed on Tesla stock.
A review by the influential magazine on Monday said the car, despite many positives, had “big flaws,” including braking slower than a full-sized pickup truck. That criticism adds to headaches for Musk, already facing pressure over a series of crashes, production issues, and the company’s finances.
After the CR review made headlines, CEO Elon Musk took to Twitter to explain that the issues could be fixed. “Looks like this can be fixed with a firmware update,” he shared. “With further refinement, we can improve braking distance beyond initial specs.” He indicated that it will be fixed ASAP, and encouraged CR to test an updated model.
Jake Fisher, Consumer Reports’ director of automotive testing, noted that “if Tesla can update the brakes over the air – an industry first – we’d be happy to retest our Model 3.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $275.32 per share on Tuesday afternoon, down $9.17 (-3.22%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -11.57%, versus a 2.81% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Says Fix to Address Consumer Reports Concerns is Coming
body:
The hits keep on coming for Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) Model 3 sedan – and we’re not even talking about production troubles this time around. Consumer Reports dropped a less than flattering review on the car that indicates a potential braking issue, but CEO Elon Musk insists the problem will be promptly addressed. more
Reuters has the details on Tesla’s latest troubles and response.
Tesla Inc’s Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk admitted late on Monday there was a braking issue with the Model 3 sedan, pointed out by Consumer Reports, and said it can be fixed with a firmware update that the electric car maker will be rolling out in a few days.
“With further refinement, we can improve braking distance beyond initial specs. Tesla won’t stop until Model 3 has better braking than any remotely comparable car,” Musk wrote in a tweet.
The influential publication notes that it simply can’t recommend the Model 3. While it heaped praise on certain features, Consumer Reports walked away concerned that the car braked slower than a full-sized pickup truck during its testing. Musk also indicated that the tests were run on an early production model, and that he was going to request that CR take a newer model and give it the same once-over.
“Model 3 now has improved ride comfort, lower wind noise & many other small improvements,” Musk added.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.36 (+0.83%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.63%, versus a 2.85% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Model 3 Falls Short in Latest Consumer Reports’ Review
body:
Expectations are high when it comes to Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) Model 3, but it can be tough to get a straight answer on what exactly to expect due to the various production troubles and other happenings at the company. However, we now have a take from one respected name that consumers turn to, and the results are a mixed bag for the electric vehicle maker.   more
Consumer Reports shares it’s assessment of the highly-anticipated Tesla vehicle.
Tesla’s Model 3 represents the electric automaker’s first attempt at a more affordable mass-market car. In Consumer Reports’ tests, we found plenty to like about the luxury compact sedan (which starts at $35,000 but goes all the way up to $78,000), including record-setting range as well as exhilarating acceleration and handling that could make it a healthy competitor to performance-oriented cars such as BMW’s 3 Series and the Audi A4. Our testers also found flaws—big flaws—such as long stopping distances in our emergency braking test and difficult-to-use controls.
These problems keep the Model 3 from earning a Consumer Reports recommendation.
In the braking test, Consumer Reports found that Tesla’s “stopping distance of 152 feet from 60 mph was far worse than any contemporary car we’ve tested.” A Tesla spokesperson disagreed with the findings and noted that they came up with 133 feet. The spokesperson also pointed out the different variables that can affect results. Jake Fisher, director of auto testing at CR, explains that the publication followed the same procedures it has always followed in vehicle tests.
“Before each test, we make sure the brake pads and tires have been properly conditioned,” Fisher explained. “We’ve conducted it on more than 500 vehicles, and we are always looking for consistent, repeatable results.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $282.05 per share on Monday afternoon, up $5.23 (+1.89%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -9.41%, versus a 2.77% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Model 3 Profits Will Wildly Exceed Expectations
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is going to shock the world with how profitable its Model 3 will be. That’s the general take from one Wall Street firm that has come forward with a very bullish price target for the electric vehicle maker.  more
CNBC shares the firm’s prediction for Tesla share prices.
The hand-wringing over Tesla’s ability to generate profits on the Model 3 is overblown, according to Berenberg.
The firm raised its price target for Tesla, predicting the electric car maker will be able to meet its 25 percent gross profit margin forecast for the Model 3. Berenberg also reiterated its buy rating for the stock.
Berenberg analyst Alexander Haissl has boosted his price target for Tesla from the already lofty $470 to $500. He explained the reason for his optimism in a note to clients.
“Model 3 gross margin to positively surprise. The widespread assumption that Model 3 margins can be directly inferred from Model S/X is inherently and almost totally flawed,” he wrote. “Substantial gains from lower labour content, as well as capital and material use efficiencies, should allow Tesla to comfortably achieve a margin above 25% throughout the product cycle.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $285.26 per share on Monday morning, up $8.44 (+3.05%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.38%, versus a 2.96% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: George Soros Makes Bet On Tesla Inc (TSLA) Binds
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) bonds have attracted the interest of billionaire investor George Soros. His investment firm scooped up $35 million worth of the bonds in the first quarter of 2018.   more
CNBC has the news on Tesla’s new backer.
George Soros’ investment firm bought a large amount of Tesla bonds in the first quarter of 2018, giving the under pressure electric carmaker a major backer, a regulatory filing shows.
Soros Fund Management bought $35 million worth of convertible notes, which are bonds that can be converted into a specified number of common stock, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filing released on Tuesday. The convertible bond is due in March 2019.
In general, Tesla has leaned pretty heavily on the debt markets to raise capital, and there has been speculation that the company will need to go that route again soon. It has been a challenging start to the year for the electric carmaker, and share prices have been volatile as a result.
There seems to be a pretty mixed sentiment about the company as a whole. On the one hand, we have Tesla devotees that continually proclaim that all is well regardless of what the headlines may say. On the other hand, a number of Tesla critics view the plethora of red flags as a clear sign of a sinking ship.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.04 (-0.01%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.60%, versus a 2.14% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Goldman Sachs Estimates Tesla Inc (TSLA) Needs $10B Capital Raise
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is going to need to raise a ton of cash to make it through to 2020, according to Goldman Sachs. The investment banking giant is holding firm on its sell rating for Tesla, as it expects the carmaker to continue struggling to reach its goals.  more
Marketwatch shares Goldman’s thoughts on Tesla.
Tesla Inc. will need about $10.5 billion in fresh capital through 2020 to keep operating and meet its own targets, Goldman Sachs analysts said Thursday.
That’s the sum needed from external capital raises and debt refinancing for the electric-car maker to fund its current operations and finance new product spend and capacity additions, Goldman analysts led by David Tamberrino wrote in a Thursday note. Goldman is assuming that Tesla TSLA, -0.20% will go ahead with a plan to launch a new vehicle manufacturing plant and gigafactory in China.
Tesla has been besieged with negative headlines in recent times, and there have been plenty of rumblings that the company will be hitting the capital markets before too long. Goldman doesn’t anticipate Tesla having any trouble raising the capital, but the firm is not all that optimistic that temporarily improving cash flow will serve as a magic bullet.
“We see several options available to the company to refinance maturing debt and raise incremental funds, which should allow Tesla to fund its growth targets,” the analyst wrote. “Our preference is to express long views via the front-end convertible credit — and we continue to express a bearish view on the equity,”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $286.41 per share on Thursday afternoon, down $0.07 (-0.02%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.01%, versus a 2.44% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst Praises Tesla Inc (TSLA) Production Shutdown Decision
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has raised plenty of eyebrows with its decision to halt production of the Model 3 for six days in order to work out some kinks, but one observer thinks it’s a capital idea. Tech analyst Gene Munster is on board with the company’s decision and gave it a thumbs up during a recent appearance on CNBC. more
CNBC shares Munster’s take on Tesla’s decision.
Tesla’s move to shut down production of its Model 3 for six days is a “big deal” but it’s not necessarily a bad thing, tech analyst-turned-venture capitalist Gene Munster told CNBC on Tuesday.
The electric car maker plans to pause production at its California factory at the end of May to work on fixes to its assembly line, sources inside the company told Reuters.
“This manufacturing shutdown is evidence that things are moving in a good direction,” said Munster. Tesla has been plagued with production problems, so perhaps the shutdown will prove to be the elixir that’s needed to ultimately boost productivity. As for the rash of executive departures from the carmaker in recent times, Munster is also less than concerned.
“I’m comfortable that they are moving things in a good direction,” he added.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Is Approaching Critical Technical Levels
body:
Shares of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) took a hit on Tuesday, and there could be more pain to come if prices hit a critical level. That’s the take from one equity strategist that has outlined what he sees as a “line in the sand” for Tesla investors. more
CNBC passes along the strategists’ take on Tesla share prices.
While a few key levels are holding the stock together, any more pain might push investors to their breaking point, according to one market watcher.
“It has two key support levels that we’re watching,” Matt Maley, equity strategist at Miller Tabak, told CNBC’s “Trading Nation” on Tuesday. “First was the $285 level. That had been the double-top high from 2014 and 2015 and once it got above that, that became new support.”
There has been a good amount of volatility in Tesla shares over recent weeks. A number of negative headlines hasn’t helped matters, and there’s a general sense of leeriness surrounding the stock at the moment. For Maley, there’s danger ahead if a key support level is breached.
“Now that we’re breaking below that, that’s creating some problems, so we got to watch out. It could be a quick move back down to its $250 level. That was the low back in March,” he said. “That’s the kind of line in the sand — investors are going to get really concerned. A lot of the momentum money is going to leave the stock if you break below that level.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.18 (-0.42%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -9.30%, versus a 1.78% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Morgan Stanley Losing Patience With Tesla Inc (TSLA), Slashes Price Target
body:
Negative news and Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) seem to be going hand-in-hand in recent times, but the company still has plenty of loyalists and fans that are expecting big things from the carmaker in the future. We can count one less analyst on that list, and that analyst was formerly a pretty big cheerleader for the company.  more
Zero Hedge has the details on the analyst that’s changing his tune on Tesla.
In a world in which Elon Musk found himself with increasingly fewer friends, one thing was certain: Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas, always eager for that lead left spot in the next Tesla convertible, would stick with Tesla and Musk through thick and thin, no matter what.
Well, that ended this morning when Jonas appears to have had enough, slashing his price target on the car maker from $376 to $291, stating that following 1Q18 results, he is making significant cuts to his near-term and long-term auto margin forecasts, while forecasting greater equity dilution, i.e. another stock offering. Jonas now sees “Tesla as trading near fair value with a balanced risk-reward.”
Among Tesla’s recent negative headlines have been concerns over production goals, inquiries about vehicle safety in the wake of a pair of high-profile crashes, fears over the company’s cash burn rate, and an unusual earnings call with CEO Elon Musk. Jonas is among those that’s a bit concerned with the plethora of red flags, and he’s lowering his price target as a result.
“We believe there is significant potential strategic value within Tesla, including its invested capital, design, brand, technology, relationships with key stakeholders (suppliers, governments, commercial partners) and its people,” Jonas added.
Tesla Inc shares fell $5.27 (-1.80%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.22%, versus a 2.70% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Report: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Battling Management For Additional Safety Sensors
body:
Among the many reasons that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has been in the spotlight of late is concerns over its Autopilot feature. A pair of recent high-profile crashes while the feature was engaged have brought additional scrutiny on the carmaker, and a new report paints a less than flattering portrayal of the company’s decision-making process.  more
CNBC has the details on an apparent disagreement between Tesla management and its engineers.
Tesla engineers repeatedly argued in favor of adding more sensors to the carmaker’s vehicles, but top executives, including CEO Elon Musk, rejected the idea, saying the devices were ineffective or would annoy drivers too much, says a new report from The Wall Street Journal.
Engineers wanted to add sensors to the company’s Autopilot system that would have alerted drivers when they took their eyes off the road or took their hands off the wheel, but senior executives, including Musk, concluded they weren’t necessary.
The recent crashes – one in Florida and one in California – proved to be fatal, and they occurred while the Autopilot system was engaged. While there’s no guarantee that additional sensors would have prevented the tragedies, the report is still another body blow for a company that has been dealing with more than its share of them of late.
A Tesla spokesperson explained to the WSJ that the company “explored many technologies and opted for the combination of a hands-on-wheel torsion sensor with visual and audio alerts, and we will of course continue to evaluate new technologies as we evolve the Tesla fleet over time.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $291.97 per share on Monday afternoon, down $9.09 (-3.02%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.22%, versus a 2.69% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Billionaire Investor Continues To Bang The Tesla Inc (TSLA) Drum
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has been in the headlines an awful lot of late, and it’s often for the wrong reasons. However, the company continues to have plenty of loyalists, including one billionaire investor that believes he’s in line to make even more cash as a result of his investment in the company. more
CNBC passes along the investor’s take on Tesla.
Buy and hold billionaire Ron Baron is defending his investment in Tesla, saying he doesn’t care that he hasn’t made much money from the electric car maker yet.
“I think we’re going to make 20 times our money because the opportunity is so enormous,” the 75-year-old founder of Baron Capital told CNBC’s “Squawk Box” on Monday. “People say, ‘Gee, they’re spending a lot of cash.’ Of course, they’re spending a lot of cash. They’re building factories.”
Among the negative headlines surrounding Tesla of late have been concerns about production goals, the company’s cash flow, and the behavior of CEO Elon Musk. Baron, whose firms stake in Tesla amounts to 1.62 percent of its total assets under management, is undeterred by the red flags.
During his appearance, Baron said that “you have to expect when you’re doing something entirely different than what anyone has done before” that not everything is going to go along swimmingly.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.19 (+0.73%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.34%, versus a 2.83% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Maneuvers For Upcoming China Rule Change
body:
From concerns about cash flow and debt load to questions about production goals and delivering on expectations, Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has more than enough items on its plate at the moment. The carmaker’s full plate is not just limited to our shores either, as evidenced by this proactive move the company was forced to take in China.   more
Reuters has the details Tesla’s move.
Tesla Inc has registered a new electric car firm in Shanghai, as China prepares to scrap rules on capping foreign ownership of new-energy vehicle (NEV) ventures.
The new company, Tesla (Shanghai) Co Ltd, was registered on May 10, according to a filing with the National Enterprise Credit Information Publicity System seen by Reuters.
According to the filing, the new company will be focused on batteries, electric cars, and spare parts. Tesla has reportedly been going back and forth with officials in Shanghai to set up its own plant in the region, but it’s unclear if the new firm is somehow related to those talks.
When approached for comment by Reuters, a Tesla spokeswoman noted that the company doesn’t “have anything new to add on this registration for now.”
Tesla Inc shares rose $3.04 (+1.01%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.30%, versus a 2.65% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Activist Investor Looks To Unseat Three Tesla Inc (TSLA) Board Members
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) needs some fresh eyes and minds in its board of directors, if it’s going to reach its lofty electric vehicle and energy goals.more
That’s according to one activist investor group, which is pushing to oust some Tesla board members soon. MarketWatch has more details:
An activist investor is urging Tesla Inc. shareholders to unseat three members of the company’s board of directors, saying they lack independence, knowledge, and a track record in corporate governance, in the first fallout from last week’s erratic post-results conference call.
CtW Investment Group, which is tied to union pension funds, is lobbying for a “no” vote at the company’s shareholder meeting on the reelection of Antonio Gracias (a VC guy), Kimbal Musk (Elon Musk’s brother), and James Murdoch (CEO of 21st Century Fox).
“We admire Tesla as successful innovator with an environmental mission; however, its continuing success looks more tenuous than ever,” CtW said in a regulatory filing. The group claims that Gracias and Kimbal Musk share “multiple” ties with Tesla’s CEO, which prevents them from being impartial board members. Meanwhile, CtW believes Murdoch and Kimbal Musk both lack “relevant industry experience.”
“Tesla shareholders need to let the board know that it must raise its game and begin the long-overdue process of renewing its membership and processes by adding currently missing industry, governance, and human capital management expertise,” the group concluded.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.02 (-0.01%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.03%, versus a 2.34% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
