heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Teases Another Vehicle Model
body:
While Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) seems to have more than enough balloons in the air at the moment, there could be another one added to the party before too long. A new video has been making the rounds on You Tube that suggests yet another Tesla model is in the works. more
CNBC shares the buzz on Tesla.
A new video Tesla posted to YouTube shows an image of an unnamed vehicle partially hidden by a sheet, and footage of passengers reacting to the acceleration of Tesla’s planned second-generation Roadster.
The video, posted Wednesday, first pointed out by electric vehicle blog Electrek, is a stab at generating hype around Tesla’s brand days after CEO Elon Musk behaved antagonistically toward Wall Street analysts during the company’s first-quarter earnings conference call.
While it’s unclear from the video what may be behind the sheet, many observers are speculating that it could simply be the planed Model Y. That model is a crossover that’s based on the Model 3, and Musk indicated that progress has been made on it during the contentious call.
“There’s no question we could have made the Model 3 much easier to produce than we have,” he said. “I think Model Y is going to be a manufacturing revolution.”

heading: Good News Could Be Coming For Tesla Inc (TSLA), Courtesy Of Potential California Mandate
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has been slapped around with a gaggle of bad headlines in recent times, but there could be some good news on the horizon. The state of California is set to vote on a plan that could lead to a boon for Tesla solar sales in the future.  more
CNBC has the details on what could be good news for Tesla.
California is poised to become the first state in the nation to mandate solar panels on most new homes as part of a program to harness clean technology and reduce the impact of new homes on the environment.
The California Energy Commission is expected to vote on the plan Wednesday. If approved by the five-member board, it would become effective Jan. 1, 2020, on most single-family homes as well as multi-family residential buildings of three stories or less, including condos and apartment complexes.
Sean Gallagher, VP state affairs for the Solar Energy Industries Association, is among those that’s on board with the plan. He explained that the state is already a leader in the adoption of solar, so it’s a natural evolution for it to continue leading the way.
“California is taking a step further basically recognizing that solar should be as commonplace as a front door welcoming you home,” he said.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $304.50 per share on Wednesday morning, up $2.53 (+0.84%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.20%, versus a 0.76% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: New Accounting Rules Work To Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Benefit
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) was able to deliver Q1 revenues that were better than analysts expectations, but the automaker may not have been able to do so without recent changes to accounting rules. On January 1, new revenue recognition rules went into effect, and that gave Tesla’s numbers a lift.  more
Marketwatch has the details on how the changes affected Tesla.
A new accounting rule helped electric car maker Tesla Inc. to post a first-quarter revenue beat, and the company also used the change to book a stealth adjustment to its running total of accumulated losses.
Tesla reported revenues of $3.4 billion compared with analyst expectations of revenues of $3.2 billion, up from $2.7 billion a year ago.
In short, the rules impact the way the company accounts for vehicle sales. Certain transactions can now be recorded directly as sales as opposed to operating leases as they were before, and that leads to an acceleration of how revenue gets reported by the company.
To be clear, Tesla is following the rules when it comes to accounting, but its loss for the quarter would likely have been far worse absent the recent changes.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $306.70 per share on Tuesday morning, up $3.93 (+1.30%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.49%, versus a 0.17% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Bonds Paint Murky Picture
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has been going through a ton of cash and that’s likely to continue, according to analysts from CreditSights. The firm believes that Tesla’s burn rate could even double in the coming months. more
Marketwatch shares the analysts’ take on Tesla.
Tesla Inc.’s “cash bleed” will likely double in the second quarter as the Silicon Valley car maker attempts to ramp up production of its Model 3 sedan, analysts at CreditSights said Monday.
Liquidity at Tesla TSLA, -0.63% will remain “tight” before its cash situation improves in the second half of the year, said the analysts, who analyze company debt. Tesla is banking on a steady production rate for the Model 3 and product turnover in the second half to rebuild its cash balance, they said.
As a result, analysts Hitin Anand and Brendan Keevan are pointing out that the risk-reward rate on Tesla bonds are “still not attractive.” They have the equivalent of a sell rating in place for the bonds, and they also expect the company will be looking for funding again before too long.
“Further capital raise for Model 3 possibly can be avoided, but Tesla will most certainly need debt/equity funding for future growth projects,” the analysts wrote.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.77 (-0.58%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.76%, versus a 0.42% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Musk Takes Fight To Short Sellers With Big Tesla Inc (TSLA) Inside Purchase
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has more than its fair share of doubters on Wall Street.more
The electric automaker remains one of the most heavily shorted stocks on earth, despite its strong performance over the past several years.
Now, as MarketWatch reports, the company’s enigmatic CEO, Elon Musk, is taking the fight directly to the short sellers that are betting on a big decline:
The chief executive officer of the electric auto maker TSLA bought about $9.85 million worth of Tesla shares, his biggest purchase since March 2017, according to a regulatory filing.
Musk has now grown his stake to near 20%, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
Musk last week promised to “burn” those betting against the company, which hasn’t earned a yearly profit in its 15-year history and who analysts believe will continue to “bleed cash.”
Musk’s move comes amid what many consider to be erratic behavior in a recent earnings call. The executive went completely off script during the call last week, insulting analysts, the media, federal regulators, and even drivers of his cars that had died behind the wheel, allegedly as a result of their own negligence.
He also warned anyone worried about volatility to not invest in his company, which is probably very good advice.
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.52 (-0.83%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.76%, versus a 0.42% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Disagrees With Warren Buffett
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has been in the headlines quite often in recent times. From concerns about the company’s financial health to last week’s bizarre earnings call, Musk has certainly got people talking. He’s managed to do it again, and this time it was for some words of wisdom he had for Warren Buffett.    more
CNBC has the details on another way the Tesla CEO sees things differently.
Warren Buffett disagrees with Elon Musk’s assessment of one of his main investing tenets.
Buffett has long advised investors to look for companies that have a “moat,” or enough of a buffer around them to maintain a competitive advantage over industry peers in terms of brand strength and business model.
Buffett’s advice about companies with a strong moat has become a part of investing lore, but it doesn’t appear that Musk puts a whole lot of stock into that. As Musk sees it, “moats are lame.” From his perspective, “what matters is the pace of innovation.” Musk dropped those little gems on social media, but Buffett has resisted any urge he may have felt to share additional wisdom with the Tesla CEO.
“There are some pretty good moats around. Being the low cost producer for example is a terribly important moat,” Buffett said at this weekend’s Berkshire Hathaway shareholder meeting.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.91 (+0.99%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.73%, versus a 0.39% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Here's How A Tesla Inc (TSLA) Bankruptcy Could Unfold
body:
A number of concerns about Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) have come to light for investors in recent times, and that’s led to plenty of speculation about how things are ultimately going to turn out for the company. Unfortunately, auto industry history suggests the company is playing a very dangerous game with its balance sheet.  more
Business Insider shares some insight into how the unthinkable could come to pass for Tesla.
It’s important to remember that like Tesla, GM and Chrysler were saddled with debt and failing to make money prior to the financial crisis. But nobody was seriously predicting Chapter 11 — until both carmakers had their access to debt funding cut off. Then bankruptcy arrived like a raptor swooping down on its prey.
Tesla is playing chicken with its balance sheet and has gotten away with it while the economy has been bubbly. In the car business, that works until suddenly it doesn’t.
Former General Motors vice chair Bob Lutz saw GM go bankrupt back in 2009, and he noted during a recent appearance on CNBC that he sees some troubling signs with Tesla’s appetite for dipping into the capital markets for funding. “That may work one more time, and then he’s going to run out of money again, and then he’s cooked,” he explained. “At this rate, Chapter 11 [bankruptcy] is a certainty.”
When you add in the unusual earnings call with CEO Elon Musk from last week, it’s pretty easy to see why investors and observers are a little worried about Tesla. That said, we’ll have to patiently wait and see how this all ultimately plays out.
Tesla Inc shares fell $0.79 (-0.27%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.54%, versus a 0.08% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Presses On With Ride-Sharing Initiative
body:
On yesterday’s rather interesting Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) earnings call, CEO Elon Musk confirmed that the company still has another iron in the fire that hasn’t been getting all that much attention. Tesla still has its sights set on some form of a ridesharing network, but details on what that means remain unclear.  more
Techcrunch has the details on another item on Tesla’s lengthy to-do list.
On Tesla’s Q1 2018 earnings call today, Tesla CEO Elon Musk shed some light on the company’s ambitions to launch an autonomous-vehicle ridesharing network. The short answer is that, from a technical standpoint, Tesla will be ready by the end of next year, Musk said. It’s not yet clear, however, when Tesla would actually launch the network.
The longer answer involves discussion about regulation and the need to have full autonomy in place. That is, Level 4 or Level 5 autonomy that doesn’t require human intervention.
As Musk sees it, the future points to “where you can own your car and have 100 percent usage of your car,” meaning that it’ll be possible for users to essentially share their cars when they’re not using them for their own purposes. Whether that means some kind of Uber or Lyft model – or perhaps an Airbnb for cars, if you will – is not crystal clear, but Musk indicates that his vision is a no-brainer.
“This is the obvious thing that’s going to happen,” he said.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $284.69 per share on Thursday afternoon, down $16.46 (-5.47%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.56%, versus a -1.18% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla CEO Comes Unhinged and Investors Follow
body:
If you haven’t heard the buzz by now, Tesla CEO Elon Musk grew frustrated with analyst questions during yesterday’s post-earnings call and responded a bit oddly. The story grew quickly. Before you know it, investors started to make a move toward the exits. The stock is down nearly $19 in the pre-market. The one key question about whether the company will be doing a capital raise was the breaking point. Wall Street would not be surprised if the company had to come back to the market once again, but Mr. Musk wasn’t having that conversation. The company has been rocked with numerous executive departures at the top, so the focus on the CEO’s behavior during the call has made some folks nervous as to the current environment. We all know talented folks who can sometimes be their own worst enemy. My guess is Mr. Musk could fall under that category.more
Notes From Wednesday’s Action
Relative strength standouts – Mastercard (MA) – earnings pop, Palo Alto Networks (PANW), CDW Corporation (CDW) – earnings pop, Zendesk (ZEN) – earnings pop, Beigene Ltd. (BGNE), Ferrari N.V. (RACE), Shutterfly (SFLY) – earnings pop, Littelfuse Inc. (LFUS) – earnings pop, Ultimate Software (ULTI) – earnings pop, Automatic Data Processing (ADP) – earnings pop, Apple (AAPL) – earnings pop, HollyFrontier Corporation (HFC) – earnings pop, Okta Inc. (OKTA).
Notable names on the downside – Paypal (PYPL) – concerns of Amazon looking to cut into company’s biz by offering fee discounts to businesses, Sodastream (SODA) – sell off on earnings results, C.H. Robinson Worldwide (CHRW) – sell off on earnings results, Yum Brands (YUM) – sell off on earnings results, Boeing (BA), Paycom Software (PAYC) – sell off on earnings results, Gilead Sciences (GILD) – sell off on earnings results, Molson Coors (TAP) – sell off on earnings results, Cummins Inc. (CMI) – numerous analysts out with ratings cuts, Google (GOOGL) (GOOG), Amazon.com (AMZN), Estee Lauder (EL) – sell off on earnings results, Lockheed Martin (LMT), Scotts Miracle-Gro (SMG) – sell off on earnings results, Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) – sell off on earnings results, Match Group (MTCH) – another weak day following news Facebook is entering the space, Humana (HUM) – sell off on earnings results.
Other notable names gaining ground – Wayfair (W) – earnings pop, Facebook (FB), Lumentum Holdings (LITE) – earnings pop.
Investing in Your Lane, But Not Always
You may have heard the expression “stay in your lane” when it comes to the work you know how to do, or sticking to the skills you possess in order to leverage them and not go off on a tangent. Investing can be said to be similar in nature. However, the issue arises when the investing lane you know isn’t working so well. When that happens, you have to force yourself to adapt to what is working. For many, the challenge can be insurmountable, but if surviving for the long run is your goal, you have to adapt. Some of my Italian relatives are “old school” when it come to where they want to keep their money. The bank and CDs in particular have always been their “peace of mind” strategy for investing. They have had various periods of time where this has worked out for them, but there have also unfortunately been plenty of periods where it hasn’t. Think post-2009 to current day and the example couldn’t be more glaring. Keeping money in bank CDs would have been brutal the last 9 years or so. We all know inflation doesn’t stop, so when you string together a bunch of years that underperform as Bank CDs have in terms of yield, it’s hard to make that back up. So you have to evolve as an investor and embrace new opportunities that are still considered fairly safe (stocks, bonds). If you don’t, the nest egg you may have accumulated will continue to lose buying power more and more when inflation eats away at it.
Tomorrow is More Important Than Yesterday (On Wall Street and In The Real World)
Stopping to smell the roses is a phrase we are reminded of when we are working real hard and the pleasure of doing big things appears to be lost. Happens to more people than you think. Celebrities long for days they can just walk down the street and no one is stopping them for a picture or autograph. Athletes go through it as well, and it can be even harder for them when they aren’t performing well in whatever sport they are in. However, if you can accept the fact that your wins will be nice to reflect on over time, you will escape the fixation with being too focused on what happened previously. We all have good days in our workplace or business, and then some days we simply wished we didn’t get out of bed. On Wall Street, analysts are always looking ahead to future earnings and adjusting stock prices based on what those expectations are. We ourselves would perform and look at things much different if we did the same. We would also not get hung up on the tough days.
Thanks for reading!

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Is Making -- And Losing -- More Money Than Ever
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is either performing like gangbusters or in a deep financial hole, depending on how you look at it.more
The electric vehicle maker reported better-than-expected first quarter earnings results late Wednesday, with revenue rising to record levels. However, its net losses also climbed higher than ever, to ($784.6 million). Its cash position has suffered as a result, and is now down to $2.7 billion — enough to cover only three and a half quarters of operations, if the trend continues.
However, as TechCrunch reports, the company attempted to paint a rosy picture based on strong production gains for its all-important affordable EV sedan:
In its letter to investors, Tesla provided some updates to its Model 3 production, noting it hit 2,270 cars produced per week for three straight weeks in April.
“Even at this stage of the ramp, Model 3 is already on the cusp of becoming the best-selling mid-sized premium sedan in the US, and our deliveries continue to increase,” Tesla CEO Elon Musk and CFO Deepak Ahuja wrote in a letter to investors. “Consumers have clearly shown that electric vehicles are simply more desirable when priced on par with their internal combustion engine competitors while offering better technology, performance and user experience.”
Still, investors sold the stock off hard after the report. They’re no doubt worried the company will have to raise more cash very soon, and the cost of doing so will be much higher this time around.
Tesla Inc shares fell $10.87 (-3.61%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.28%, versus a -0.98% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #9 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: German Automakers Are Gunning For Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) may get all of the headlines when it comes to the electric vehicle market, but that doesn’t mean that it’s the only company bringing anything to the table on that front. In fact, a number of automakers are set to debut their own offerings, and some observers believe that should make Tesla awfully nervous.   more
Bloomberg has some insight on the challengers that will be taking aim at Tesla.
Elon Musk started Tesla Inc. with a goal of accelerating the switch to electric cars by about a decade.
That wish is now catching up with him. Starting with Jaguar’s I-Pace crossover and later this year Audi’s Q6 e-tron, virtually every major carmaker is rolling out stylish, sporty electric vehicles in the mold of his Models S, X and 3. Unlike Tesla, they have roughly a century of experience launching models every few months and can spread development costs across a broad portfolio.
Mike Jackson, CEO of AutoNation, has gotten a look at what some of the other companies have up their sleeves, and we can color him impressed. “The vehicles I’ve seen are far superior to anything Tesla has,” he said.  “They are in a massive pivot and shift away from diesel investment into electrification in both pure electric and plug-in hybrid.”
That’s not welcome news for a company that is having serious problems realizing its production goals, but we will have to wait and see how things ultimately pan out in the growing electric vehicle market.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $302.43 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $2.51 (+0.84%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.86%, versus a -0.77% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Slapped With $2B Suit For Alleged Patent Design Theft Of Semi Trucks
body:
We can add another issue to the lengthy list that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) continues to work its way through. This one has to do with allegations of patent infringement, as the company has just been slapped with a suit alleging it ripped off the design for a much-heralded project that it has in the pipeline. more
Marketwatch has the details on the suit that’s been filed against Tesla.
Tesla Inc. is being sued for more than $2 billion by electric-hydrogen truck startup Nikola Motor Co., which is claiming its patents were infringed.
In a lawsuit filed Tuesday in Arizona, Nikola claims Tesla TSLA, -0.22% copied the design of its big rigs, which Nikola first unveiled in May 2016.
Nikola says that it sent a cease-and-desist letter pointing out the striking similarities between its design and the one that Tesla planned to unveil, and the company requested that Tesla hold off on its public unveiling. Tesla did not respond, and it also went ahead with a heavily-publicized event to tour the electric semi.
Nikola contends that Tesla’s unveiling has led to “confusion in the market,” and the company is seeking damages that are roughly equivalent to the jump in Tesla’s market cap following the debut of the semi. A Tesla spokesperson dismissed the significance of the claim, noting that it’s “patently obvious there is no merit to this lawsuit.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $2.92 (-0.97%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.67%, versus a -0.31% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #9 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Moving Away From Solar Leasing Finance Deals
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) acquired SolarCity back in 2016, and the natural expectation was that some changes would be coming to the residential solar industry as a result. Those expectations have been realized, but not necessarily in the way that some observers were expecting.  more
Bloomberg has the details on a Tesla-inspired change to the residential solar market.
U.S. residential solar surged this decade on the back of leasing deals that helped consumers get rooftop power systems with no money down. The financing arrangement accounted for the majority of the market after 2011 until being surpassed by cash sales and loans last year, according to a report Tuesday by GTM Research.
There are several explanations for the shift, notably the widespread availability of loans. The main factor: Tesla Inc. is pivoting away from leasing, according to Allison Mond, a GTM analyst.
For 2017, loans and cash sales accounted for 59 percent of residential solar deals, with leases and power-purchase agreements accounting for the remainder. As Mond explained to Bloomberg, there’s a clear cut reason why the trend in the industry has shifted.
“The single biggest driver of the quick emergence of customer ownership in 2018 is the contraction of SolarCity/Tesla as an installer,” she said via email.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $295.60 per share on Tuesday morning, up $1.70 (+0.58%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.06%, versus a -0.79% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Model 3 Production Huge Focus For Tesla Inc (TSLA) Earnings Report
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has been dealing with a slew of negative headlines in recent weeks, but they will all become moot points if the company is able to deliver the goods when it reports earnings on Wednesday. However, that whole scenario could be flipped upside down if additional troubling signs emerge from the report on the production front.  more
Marketwatch has the details on the situation that Tesla is facing.
Model 3 production updates are bound to dominate the subsequent conference call with investors, as they have been since the first Model 3s rolled off the assembly line in July.
And it is no wonder: The mass-market sedan, which starts around $35,000, is viewed as the engine of Tesla’s lofty ambitions, which include adding more passenger vehicles to its lineup, filling the preorders of its all-electric heavy-duty truck, and selling its solar roof tiles.
Analysts are expecting an adjusted loss of somewhere in the neighborhood of $3.20 to $3.54 per share. Those expectations seem to be baked into the cake that is the company’s stock price, but additional bad news on the production front may not be.
CEO Elon Musk has been doing his best to convince investors that any and all kinks are being ironed out, but that hasn’t resulted in the company’s production targets being realized as of yet. We should see some additional signs on Wednesday, and the market will react accordingly.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $297.33 per share on Monday morning, up $3.26 (+1.11%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.50%, versus a 0.70% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Some Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shareholders Want CEO Elon Musk Removed From Chairman Role
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) continues to struggle in its quest to reach the ambitious production goals laid out by CEO Elon Musk, and some observers and shareholders are pointing fingers over what the real troubles at the company are. That may all come to a head at the upcoming annual shareholder meeting, especially when you consider one of the proposals that has been floated out there.   more
Gizmodo has the details on the situation that Tesla is facing.
It was only a few months ago that Tesla signed Elon Musk to stick around as CEO for another ten years. Since then, the electric vehicle company has been going through some tough time and when shareholders hold their annual meeting in June, they’re set to vote on a proposal to remove Musk from his role as chairman.
Elektrek reports that a shareholder named Jing Zhao is behind the proposal, and he notes that a number of large companies across the globe have a separate and independent chairman of the board. “Tesla should not be exception,” Zhao states in his proposal.
In a statement accompanying the proposal, Tesla’s board dismissed the idea, and pointed to Musk’s “day-to-day exposure to the Company’s business” as a reason for its success.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.29 (-0.44%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.55%, versus a 0.29% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) May Use SpaceX Network to Manage Car Data
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has long been a leader in the autonomous driving space, but the robust technological needs of self-driving cars are still yet to be truly met.more
However, as CNBC reports, one prominent Wall Street mind envisions a potential tie-up with Elon Musk’s other company on that front:
Autonomous cars produce and consume extremely large amounts of data, said Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas in a note sent Friday. He estimates self-driving vehicles can produce 40 terabytes of data in an hour, for example. Today’s self-driving vehicles transmit about 500 times the amount of data as a typical smartphone contract.
“How will Tesla manage such a large quantity of data?” Jonas said. “In our opinion, leveraging the broadband network provided by its very own sister company seems like a plausible answer.”
Jonas noted that Tesla could thus become a “captive customer” for SpaceX. The rocket maker is currently developing a broadband network that leverages satellites to beam large amounts of data back and forth.
Tesla Inc shares closed at $294.07 on Friday, up $8.59 (+3.01%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.55%, versus a 0.29% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Chanos: Executive Exodus Bad Sign For Tesla Inc (TSLA)
body:
While many observers have expressed concerns about the executive turnover at Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), short-seller Jim Chanos seems to be particularly worked up about it. During an appearance on CNBC, he even went as far as to call CEO Elon Musk’s leadership into question.  more
CNBC passes along what he had to say about Tesla.
Musk “may be misleading investors,” he said Thursday on CNBC’s “Squawk Box.” “I think Elon Musk has crossed the Rubicon in terms of making statements to investors that he might rue later.”
The Kynikos Associates hedge fund manager, who confirmed his firm is short Tesla shares, cited Musk’s announcements about future products.
Chanos specifically called out Musk’s claims about the Roadster, which he said would be ready for the masses in 2020, and Tesla’s semi-truck, which Musk says will be entering production next year. “I don’t think either of those are going to happen,” Chanos said. As he sees it, there are serious problems afoot at Tesla, and he needs to look no further than the recent turnover for confirmation.
“The No. 1 sign of impending problems is mass executive departures,” he added. “This is becoming a torrent at Tesla. … [It is] stunning the accelerating rate of executive departures.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $283.60 per share on Thursday afternoon, up $2.91 (+1.04%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.91%, versus a 0.44% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Autopilot Chief Has Left The Building
body:
As Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) continues to navigate its way towards actually meeting its lofty production goals, its efforts will continue without another key executive. The company’s Autopilot chief is taking his talents elsewhere after two years with Tesla.  more
Bloomberg has the scoop on the latest exit from Tesla.
Tesla Inc.’s Autopilot chief Jim Keller has left the company, the latest in a rash of executive departures at the electric-car maker led by Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk.
Keller, who joined the auto maker two years ago and has a background in chip development, had his last day as a Tesla vice president on Tuesday, the company said in a statement. He’s going back to semiconductor engineering, Tesla said.
Tesla has shuffled the decks to account for Keller’s departure, as one person will now be lead Autopilot hardware, while another will be tasked with running Autopilot software. The company acknowledged that Keller was moving on in a statement.
“Prior to joining Tesla, Jim’s core passion was microprocessor engineering and he’s now joining a company where he’ll be able to once again focus on this exclusively,” the statement read in part. “We appreciate his contributions to Tesla and wish him the best.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $278.43 per share on Thursday morning, down $2.26 (-0.81%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -10.57%, versus a -0.51% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Gets A Big Fat 'F' For Resolving Customer Complaints
body:
The Better Business Bureau has offered up its assessment of how well Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) handles customer complaints. Let’s just say that the carmaker has another item to add to its lengthy to-do list. more
CNET passes along the BBB’s harsh assessment of Tesla.
Tesla just got a failing grade, and not from the many folks waiting for their Model 3 to come online. No, the Better Business Bureau gave the company an “F” for not resolving customer complaints, sometimes not even responding to complaints.
According to a report in the Mercury News, the BBB received 65 official complaints about Tesla, but only 23 were resolved satisfactorily. Of the remaining complaints, Tesla responded to 10 of them but didn’t offer an adequate solution and in 15 cases the company didn’t respond at all. In the remaining cases, the BBB says Tesla responded to the problem but either the customer rejected the response or didn’t notify the bureau that the issue had been resolved.
While some of the complaints examined appear to be of the trivial variety, others have to do with things such as warranty issues. As the BBB sees it, Tesla leaves a lot to be desired on the complaint resolution front. Tesla sees things differently, and the company has essentially dismissed the report.
“Tesla has the highest customer satisfaction ratings in the entire auto industry, and it’s not even close,” a spokesperson for the company said in a statement.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $283.46 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $0.09 (+0.03%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -8.96%, versus a -1.06% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #11 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Analyst: Intensifying Competition Means Stay Away From Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shares
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has faced a number of challenges in recent times, and even more are on the way in the form of increased competition. For J.P. Morgan, that’s even more of a reason to stay away from the company’s shares.
more
CNBC has some insight from the firm on Tesla.
Tesla’s electric car sales will suffer due to increased competition from German automakers, according to J.P. Morgan.
The firm reaffirmed its underweight rating on Tesla shares, citing the electric car pipelines from Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Audi.
Analyst Ryan Brinkman has also reaffirmed his $185 price target for Tesla. As he sees it, companies such as Daimler and Audi are going to have little trouble meeting their production goals in the electric vehicle market in the coming years, and that’s going to result in additional concerns for Tesla to deal with.
“When similarly priced high-end long-range electric vehicles become available from prestigious brands with strong reputations for both service and build quality, we believe this could represent a meaningful headwind for Tesla,” he wrote.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Could Fall Under "Too Big To Fail" Label
body:
Has Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) reached the point in which it’s simply “too big to fail?” Morgan Stanley analyst Adam Jonas indicates that may be the case, and he points to the size of the company’s U.S. workforce as the reason.  more
CNBC passes along his take on Tesla.
Morgan Stanley believes the size of Tesla’s U.S. workforce may become a big factor affecting the company’s long-term survival.
The firm’s analyst Adam Jonas noted Tesla employed 37,543 workers at the end of last year and predicted the number will increase to nearly 50,000 by 2019 or 2020.
In a note to clients, Jonas wrote that the company “may be more on the ‘too big to fail’ spectrum than the market realizes … the vast majority of [the company’s workforce is] in the United States, and across many states.” During the financial crisis, the U.S. bailed out a number of entities to insure their survival, including GM and Chrysler. While Tesla has reached nowhere near the level of productivity of either of those giants of industry, Jonas points out the trickle down effect inherent to auto-related jobs.
“Rule of thumb on the economic multiplier says that one auto-related job can support as many as seven other jobs throughout the economy,” he wrote.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.35 (-0.46%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.17%, versus a 1.43% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Batteries Are The Real Culprit For Tesla Inc (TSLA) Production Troubles
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) continues to navigate its way through various production setbacks, and there has been a ton of speculation as to what the real trouble is that prevents the company from reaching its goals. According to one firm, the carmakers battery production is the real culprit.  more
CNBC shares the firm’s take on Tesla’s troubles.
Tesla’s battery production for the Model 3 is the company’s real obstacle to putting cars on the road, not Model 3 assembly itself, said Oppenheimer analyst Colin Rusch on CNBC’s “Power Lunch.”
“The real concern for us ultimately is how many batteries they can make that fit the specs,” he said, adding that he thinks Tesla is having quality issues with the 2170 battery cells. The 2170 is a new cell found only in the Model 3.
Tesla has repeatedly gone public with production goals for its Model 3 and then failed to achieve them. CEO Elon Musk has reportedly emailed employees to inform them that round-the-clock production would be going into effect to get output where it needs to be. For Rusch, there’s a clear problem that the company needs to get a handle on.
“We think they have a quality issue with the move to the 2170s and the chemistry changes, and we think that is the real bottleneck here,” he added.
Tesla Inc shares fell $1.55 (-0.53%) in premarket trading Thursday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.78%, versus a 1.73% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: California Opens Investigation Into Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Workplace Environment
body:
That escalated quickly. Reports recently emerged alleging poor workplace safety practices at Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), and the state of California is now going to start poking around and see if there’s anything to it. more
Bloomberg has the details on a new item that has appeared on the plate of Tesla.
California’s Division of Occupational Safety and Health said it has opened a new investigation into Tesla Inc. following a report about worker protections at the company’s lone auto plant in Fremont, California.
The state agency “takes seriously reports of workplace hazards and allegations of employers’ underreporting recordable work-related injuries and illnesses” and “currently has an open inspection at Tesla,” said Erika Monterroza, a spokeswoman for the state’s industrial relations department.
The report from earlier this week emanated from the Center for Investigative Reporting’s Reveal, and it alleged that the company was fudging numbers to make its safety records look better than they actually were. What’s more, the report indicated that founder and CEO Elon Musk’s personal preferences held more weight in some cases over potential hazards.
For its part, Tesla pushed back on the report in a blog post, referring to it as “an ideologically motivated attack by an extremist organization working directly with union supporters to create a calculated disinformation campaign against Tesla.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $293.01 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $5.32 (+1.85%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.89%, versus a 1.91% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Will Ramp Production Up To New Highs
body:
Failure to reach production targets has led to a ton of criticism being leveled against Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), but the company is taking steps to to make those issues a thing of the past. In short, it sounds like business is about to pick-up at the automaker’s Freemont assembly plant.   more
Bloomberg has the news on Tesla’s plans.
Tesla Inc. jumped after Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk laid out measures to boost production of his most crucial electric car and rein in expenses to achieve profitability.
The automaker’s Fremont, California, assembly plant will begin around-the-clock production to accelerate Model 3 output, Musk told employees in an email Tuesday. He acknowledged criticism that Tesla is “not a real company” until it generates profit and said this is a goal now that Tesla has more scale.
Tesla’s previous goal has been to reach a 5,000-a-week production target for the Model 3, but Musk indicates he wants to reach 6,000 per week by the end of June. Gene Munster, a managing partner at venture capital firm Loup Ventures, believes this is the kick in the pants that the carmaker has needed.
“This makes us more confident in Tesla’s ability to ramp Model 3 production to a level that will satisfy investors,” he wrote in a note to clients.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $296.78 per share on Wednesday morning, up $9.09 (+3.16%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.68%, versus a 1.86% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Ongoing Production Delays Will Push Tesla Inc (TSLA) To Tap Capital Markets
body:
The chorus continues to grow louder that Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) will be hitting the capital markets before too long. Another team of analysts predicts that production delays will lead to Tesla having to raise funds before the year is through. more
Marketwatch shares the firm’s take on Tesla.
A second team of analysts now says that Tesla Inc. likely will raise equity or debt this year and face more production delays with its Model 3, despite the Silicon Valley car maker’s assurances to the contrary on both counts.
Analysts at Bernstein said they expect “production delays and the specter of a capital raise to dominate investor attention” on Tesla TSLA, +1.98% in the next two quarters. Further Model 3 delays would not necessarily “make or break Tesla,” they said, but they would intensify the company’s cash burn.
The analysts at Bernstein are holding firm on their price target of $265 for shares of Tesla, and they have the equivalent of a neutral rating in place. As they see it, the company needs to “materially” reduce near-term operational and capital expenses spending to avoid another capital raise.
Analysts at Goldman Sachs came forward to express similar sentiments about Tesla earlier this month, and the firm lowered its price target to $195 while doing so.
Tesla Inc shares rose $6.23 (+2.17%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -7.60%, versus a 1.65% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Halts Model 3 Production To "Improve Automation"
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is already well behind its initial production goals for its new low-priced Model 3 electric sedan.more
The EV maker originally planned on making 5,000 Model 3’s by the end of 2017. It later extended that goal to the end of March 2018, before slashing it to 2,500.
Now, it hopes to reach that original goal level by the end of July, but that seems impossible at this point. And as BuzzFeed News reports, Tesla has actually halted production right now in order to install some upgrades to its systems:
Just a few days after Tesla CEO Elon Musk said he’s feeling optimistic about his ability to speed up production on the company’s vehicles, the assembly line for the Model 3 in the company’s Fremont, California, plant has been temporarily shut down — again.
The announcement of the four- to five-day production pause for the Model 3 came without warning, according to Tesla employees who spoke with BuzzFeed News. During the pause, workers are expected to use vacation days or stay home without pay; a small number of workers may be offered paid work elsewhere in the factory.
The company says the move is aimed at improving automation, which seems strange, considering CEO Elon Musk tweeted the following just a few days ago: “Yes, excessive automation at Tesla was a mistake. To be precise, my mistake. Humans are underrated.”
Tesla temporarily paused Model 3 production for the first time back in February, with the goal of boosting output once its systems come back online.
Tesla Inc shares fell $3.24 (-1.11%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.47%, versus a 0.58% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) May Need To Revamp Autopilot Strategy
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has a number of items on its plate at the moment, ranging from production concerns to worries over its debt load, and the company may need to revamp another part of its strategy in the wake of recent developments. A recent fatal crash in California was followed by a public spat with the National Transporation Safety Board that shed a negative light on the carmaker, and the time may be now for Tesla to re-examine its autopilot ambitions.   more
Business Insider has some insight on what Tesla may need to do.
Autopilot is actually not Tesla’s biggest headache at the moment — sluggish production of the Model 3 sedan is. But Autopilot is turning into both a public-relations nightmare and an opportunity, a dynamic driven by the weak overall market performance of electric vehicles, which make up only about 1% of global sales. Self-driving cars are the cool new thing, and Musk isn’t going to miss out on that futuristic adventures, even as he has to yet again take to sleeping in Tesla’s factory floor in Fremont, CA to fix the Model 3’s problems.
David Friedman, Director of Cars and Product Policy and Analysis for Consumers Union, the advocacy division of Consumer Reports, notes that Tesla’s system may not be as good as offerings from rivals. “Their driver monitor system isn’t as good as some other systems in terms of assuring that someone is paying attention,” he notes.
While it’s unlikely the company would tap the brakes on autopilot completely at this point, it certainly seems like an appropriate time to make sure that any and all kinks have been worked out.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $291.44 per share on Monday afternoon, down $8.90 (-2.96%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -6.39%, versus a 0.67% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Report: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Has Been Underreporting Worker Injuries
body:
The hits keep on coming from Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), and we’re unfortunately not talking about the company suddenly knocking it out of the park on production goals. Yet another negative story has started making the rounds about the carmaker, and this one suggests there’s some creative record-keeping going on in regards to safety numbers.  more
CNBC passes along the details on a new report that paints Tesla in a negative light.
Electric vehicle maker Tesla has mislabeled and under-counted workers’ injuries to make its safety record look better than it was, according to a new investigative report by RevealNews.org.
“Company officials labeled toxic exposures, muscle strains and repetitive stress injuries as personal medical issues or minor accidents requiring only first aid, lowering its official injury count,” said the report.
Sources that spoke to Reveal indicate that there were safety compromises made at the company’s Fremont factory for incredibly curious reasons. According to the sources, CEO Elon Musk is not a big fan of the color yellow, and that resulted in the factory floor not having clearly marked pedestrian lanes. As opposed to the standard yellow, lanes were allegedly painted different shades of gray.
While the Reveal reporters seem to have done a thorough job with the investigation, Tesla has disputed the findings and notes that any past safety concerns have already been addressed and dealt with.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $293.70 per share on Monday morning, down $6.64 (-2.21%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -5.67%, versus a 0.27% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of C (Neutral), and is ranked #10 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Savagely Hints Company Will Be Cash-Flow Positive Ahead of Schedule
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk has demonstrated yet again that he’s not shy about speaking up when he disagrees with something. This time, it was a report from The Economist that caught his attention, and Musk felt the need to hop on the Twitter machine to respond.   more
CNBC has the details on what the Tesla CEO had to say.
Elon Musk gave detailed financial guidance for Tesla — in a tweet at 1:11 a.m. PT Friday — boosting the electric car maker’s stock.
The tweet was a reply to The Economist.
The Economist posted that “Tesla will need to raise $2.5bn to $3bn this year, according to Jefferies, a bank.” Many hours later, Musk caught wind of what the publication had to say, and he responded while taking a shot at the outlet’s interest factor.
“The Economist used to be boring, but smart with a wicked dry wit. Now it’s just boring (sigh). Tesla will be profitable & cash flow+ in Q3 & Q4, so obv no need to raise money,” Musk wrote.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $297.45 per share on Friday morning, up $3.37 (+1.15%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.46%, versus a 0.01% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Social Media Warning Signs
body:
It’s quite the job we have here at StockNews.com in covering the sudden starts and stops of a volatile market. But more and more, social media is taking what would be just another day in the markets and adding new sizzle. While it can be entertaining, it can also be profitable. However, one has to be ready to pounce. For example, Tesla CEO Elon Musk loves to use Twitter, almost as much as President Trump these days. Sometimes, Mr. Musk is mocking a brokerage for giving bad commentary. This morning, he called out The Economist magazine for reporting an analyst call that said the company would likely need to raise $2.5-$3B. Mr. Musk replied with “The Economist used to be boring, but smart with a wicked dry wit. Now it’s just boring (sigh). Tesla will be profitable & cash flow+ in Q3 & Q4, so obv no need to raise money.” Maybe it’s me, but I tend to get a bit nervous when the CEO of a huge company feels the need to vent publicly. I get it’s the thing to do these days, but it just doesn’t seem like the right thing to do.more
Notes From Thursday’s Action
Homebuilders – once again did not participate in the big rally. Interest rates jumping, along with commodity prices may be part of the story – NVR Inc. (NVR), LGI Homes (LGIH), Lennar (LEN).
Financials looked solid in the rally – Goldman Sachs (GS), JP Morgan (JPM), PNC Financial (PNC), and CME Group (CME).
Retailers have been solid but we did see some names stumble on news today – Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) – earnings disappointments, LBrands (LB) – weak March sales.
Names That Lagged the Rally – Tesla (TSLA), McDonald’s (MCD), Simon Property Group (SPG), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), Netease (NTES), Facebook (FB), Bristol-Myers (BMY),
Airlines caught a bid on unconfirmed Berkshire rumors may be taking a bid in some of the airline names – Delta (DAL), Southwest Air (LUV).
Relative strength plays outperforming – Autohome (ATHM), Agios Pharmaceuticals (AGIO), Burlington Stores (BURL), Inogen Inc. (INGN), Penumbra (PEN), Argenx SE (ARGX), CoStar Group (CSGP), Netflix (NFLX), Humana (HUM), Verisign (VRSN), PVH Corp (PVH), Nvidia (NVDA), Intel (INTC), Costco (COST), 51 Job, Inc. (JOBS), Nutanix (NTNX), NetApp (NTAP), Loxo Oncology (LOXO), Amazon.com (AMZN),
Software continues to be one of the main areas of momentum during any market rally – Adobe Systems (ADBE), Splunk (SPLK), Palo Alto Networks (PANW), F5 Networks (FFIV), Red Hat (RHT), Proofpoint (PFPT).
Defense group under even more buyer focus on war-related headlines – Lockheed Martin (LMT), Northrop Grumman (NOC), Raytheon (RTN), Boeing (BA).
Advice for the Needy: Don’t Take Another Penny
Families and money matters can often cause rough situations, whether it’s parents and kids, siblings, estate matters, etc. We may have some family members that tend to be more needy than others, but who are also the most outspoken (funny how that is). The way to solve money situations can come down to one main philosophy. The person that is giving the monies is the person that is dictating what it shall or shall not be used for. The receiver either understands this rule or has the option of not having to. How they determine this is simple: don’t take another penny and then you can choose your own path. Being self-reliant is the only way one can eventually decide the path he/she will want to take. Anything else, it falls back to the giver to allocate what funds will be dispersed and for what purpose. These are lessons that may not have investing implications as we normally discuss, but if these decisions are made properly, investing can then be introduced into the family in a much more defined process. If this approach is too harsh, there is always the universal basic income approach (a hot topic today) and that is you give a specific amount of money to those in need in your family that they can do with as they please, but anything above that should be dictated as to where the monies shall be used.
Facebook for Money/Investing Topics
With Facebook so much in the news, I thought about what if there was a Facebook-like platform for all things money and investing. What would the information look like? My guess is that it would be broken down into people asking a lot of questions on things they don’t understand and then people offering up answers to things they never do themselves. Not to mention folks would only be talking about stuff they want others to know while concealing the reality of their actual financial situation. In a nutshell, basically just like Facebook is today. Money and investing is best left to those who live and breath the topic on a day-in, day-out basis. Find the best sources and you will be on the right course. Anything else is a waste of time.
Thanks for reading!

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) In Hot Water With NTSB Following Comments
body:
Another curious piece of news has reared its head in regards to Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), and this time it has to do with the National Transportation Safety Board. Reports indicate that the NTSB asked the carmaker to step aside from its probe into a fatal crash with one of its vehicles, and that the conversation wasn’t exactly of the pleasant variety.   more
Bloomberg has the details on Tesla’s reported flap with the NTSB.
The National Transportation Safety Board told Tesla Inc. on Wednesday that the carmaker was being removed from the investigation of a fatal accident, prior to the company announcing it had withdrawn from it, according to a person familiar with the discussion.
NTSB Chairman Robert Sumwalt relayed the decision in a call to Tesla’s Elon Musk that was described as tense by the person because the chief executive officer was unhappy with the safety board’s action. NTSB is expected to make a formal announcement in a release later Thursday, said the person, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Reports indicate that the NTSB wasn’t pleased with Tesla’s public comments that the driver was at fault in the accident. While that may or may not be the case, the NTSB hasn’t wrapped up its investigation as of yet. Tesla has released a statement disputing that the call in question was testy in nature, and also explaining why it withdrew from the investigation.
“We believe in transparency, so an agreement that prevents public release of information for over a year is unacceptable,” the statement read in part.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $297.58 per share on Thursday afternoon, down $3.35 (-1.11%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.42%, versus a 0.16% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Shares Will Be Less Than $100 By 2019
body:
As Vertical Research Group analyst Gordon Johnson sees it, shares of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) are going to be on sale in rather dramatic fashion by next year. The analyst has offered up a sell rating and his expectation for a price target, and let’s just say he’s not painting a pretty picture for Tesla.  more
CNBC passes along the analyst’s take on Tesla.
With so much competition in the electric car industry, Tesla’s stock will drop to $84 by the end of next year, Vertical Research Group analyst Gordon Johnson said. Vertical issued a sell rating on the stock earlier this week.
“Year-end [20]19, we think the stock will be $84,” Johnson told CNBC on “Closing Bell” Wednesday. Tesla was priced at more than $300 by the end of trading Wednesday.
Johnson’s main concerns for Tesla have to do with increasing competition and the company’s proclivity for failing to meet delivery and production goals. “Time and time again [Telsa has] targeted production numbers that they haven’t hit,” he said.
CEO Elon Musk continues to brush aside the various bearish takes on his company, which is reportedly setting its sights on new release goals for its upcoming Model Y.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $297.92 per share on Thursday morning, down $3.01 (-1.00%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.31%, versus a 0.08% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Report: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Ambitious Goals For Model Y Are Coming Into Focus
body:
While Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) may have any number of issues that it’s sorting through on the production front at any point in time, there’s one area in which the automaker certainly isn’t lacking. That would be on the ambition front, and we can look to the latest scuttlebutt about the company’s goals for confirmation. more
CNBC has the details on Tesla’s future plans.
Tesla is targeting November 2019 as the start of production for its Model Y sport utility vehicle, with production in China to begin two years later, two sources told Reuters this week, shedding some light on the electric vehicle maker’s next project that could tax its resources and capacity.
Reuters has learned the Silicon Valley company led by Chief Executive Elon Musk is accepting preliminary bids for supplier contracts on the Model Y, a compact crossover companion to the Model 3 sedan. Tesla has given suppliers scant details about the program and had not provided a production time frame, but has now indicated the vehicle would begin to be built at its Fremont, California, plant in November of next year, the two sources with knowledge of the supply chain said.
Tesla has been the subject of a ton of criticism in recent weeks over issues with Model 3 production goals. Anticipation was high for the vehicle, as evidenced by 500,000 advance refundable targets, but the company is still trying to get to the point in which it can produce 5,000 units per week, or 250,000 Model 3’s per year.
As for the Model Y. Musk has previously hinted that the company would be shooting to produce 1 million units annually.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $300.93 per share on Wednesday afternoon, down $3.77 (-1.24%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.35%, versus a -0.77% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Battery Pack Continues To Perform Well For Energy Operators
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) has debuted several other massive energy storage projects in Australia in the wake of the success of its giant Powerpack system. The system has received high praise from energy operators, but critics still abound inside of the Australian government.  more
Electrek has additional details on the perception of Tesla’s system in Australia.
Nonetheless, the Australian Energy Market Operator praised the performance of the system in a new report this month.
Tesla’s 100MW/129MWh Powerpack project in South Australia, the largest in the world for now, has been demonstrating its capacity since going into operation in December.
The EMO called attention to the battery system’s efficiency, affordability, and ability to get things done with zero emissions. While the results of the report are impressive, Australian resources minister Matt Canavan is among the officials that is less than impressed with Tesla’s offering.
“It’s the Kim Kardashian of the energy world: it’s famous for being famous,” Canavan said. “It really doesn’t do very much.”

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Chief Exec Elon Musk Mocks Goldman Sachs Over Bearish Call
body:
Dissenting opinions on the future prospects of Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) are not a new phenomenon, but a bearish call on the stock from one of the street’s most respected names seems to have ruffled the feathers of CEO Elon Musk. Goldman Sachs views the stock as a sell, and Musk has publicly thrown shade on that assessment. more
CNBC shares the Tesla CEO’s take on the firm’s call.
Tesla chief executive Elon Musk is calling out Goldman Sachs after the bank encouraged investors to sell the carmaker’s stock.
“Place your bets,” Musk quipped on Twitter, appearing to challenge would-be sellers to exit at their own risk.
In a research note, analyst David Tamberrino called attention to a number of trouble spots for Tesla, including his belief that the company will fail to achieve production goals. “We believe the sustainable production rate for the second quarter of 2018 is most likely below the 2,000 vehicle mark the company achieved in the final week of the [first] quarter,” he wrote. “We see the company likely sustaining Model 3 production around the 1,400 per week mark.”
The carmaker is holding firm on its stance that it will reach a goal of 5,000 Model 3 sedans per week by the end of June.

heading: China Trade Gesture A Boon For Tesla Inc (TSLA), Other Automakers
body:
Trade tensions between the United States and China have led to concerns for automakers such as Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), but an encouraging sign has emerged in the wake of all the tough talk that has been making the rounds. Chinese President Xi Jinping has offered up some wiggle room when it comes imports from carmakers. more
CNBC has the details on the positive news for Tesla and others.
Chinese President Xi Jinping said his plans include “significantly” lowering import tariffs on foreign autos and decreasing duties of other products.
“We have a genuine desire to increase imports and achieve greater balance of international payments under the current account,” Xi said at the Boao Forum for Asia, according to a translation of the speech.
China is a key market for US car companies, and it’s only expected to get larger in the coming years. Last year, GM sold more than 4 million cars in China, while Tesla doubled its revenue in the country to $2 billion. Fears of an all-out trade war between the two powers are on the decline, and even the commander-in-chief has indicated that cooler heads will likely prevail.
“President Xi and I will always be friends, no matter what happens with our dispute on trade,” he tweeted on Sunday. “China will take down its Trade Barriers because it is the right thing to do.”
Tesla Inc shares fell $3.90 (-1.28%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -2.14%, versus a -0.24% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Goldman Sachs: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Is Still A Sell In Our Eyes
body:
Production targets remain elusive for Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), and there remains a ton of speculation as to whether or not the company will be able to meet any of the ambitious goals the company has outlined. We can count Goldman Sachs in the camp of those that believe that the reaching of goals will remain elusive for Tesla.  more
CNBC passes along the investment banking giant’s take on Tesla.
Goldman Sachs still isn’t convinced Tesla will be able to meet even its Model 3 production targets.
“We believe the sustainable production rate for the second quarter of 2018 is most likely below the 2,000 vehicle mark the company achieved in the final week of the [first] quarter,” Goldman analyst David Tamberrino wrote Tuesday. “We see the company likely sustaining Model 3 production around the 1,400 per week mark.”
Tamberrino has also dropped his price target for Tesla to $195 from $205, as he’s unconvinced that the company has worked its way through the numerous challenges on its plate at the present time.
“Although the company stated that is does not require a capital raise this year, we note that this is predicated upon a sustained 5,000 per week production rate achieved exiting the second quarter of 2018,” he added. “Beyond a required capital raise to continue to fund the launch of the Model 3 program, the company would likely still need outside capital in the future for capacity and product expansion.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $306.18 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $16.52 (+5.70%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.66%, versus a -0.04% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Report: 2018 Will See Breakout Production, Sales From Tesla Inc (TSLA) And Other EV Manufacturers
body:
If all goes according to plan, 2018 could be a banner year for Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) and other electric vehicle makers. That’s the assessment of consultancy firm McKinsey, which sees a clear path ahead for mass market adoption of EVs. more
Teslarati passes along that the firm believes Tesla and others need to do.
As Tesla continues to push the boundaries on automation in its factory production line, 2018 could be the year when the company and the electric vehicle (EVs) industry shifts from being seen as niche production to the mass market. Noting that roughly 1.3 million EVs were sold around the world in 2017, a 57 percent increase over 2016 sales, global consultancy McKinsey predicts that EVs’ share of total passenger vehicle sales could reach 30 to 35 percent in major markets like China, Europe, and the US by 2030. In partnership with automotive benchmarking specialist A2Mac1, McKinsey took a deep dive into EV technology, and identified four strategies that automakers should follow to remain relevant as the industry transforms itself.
McKinsey notes that exemplary progress has been made in driving range fro EVs, and the various automakers can now set their sights on reducing price points. To make that happen, McKinsey believes they will need to implement things such as design to cost strategies while also making sure they stay ahead of the curve in technology.
Of course, all of that is easier said than done. While there’s no doubt that Tesla and others have made impressive progress, it’s high time for the former to actually meet production goals before looking ahead to the days of mass market adoption.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $296.80 per share on Monday afternoon, down $2.50 (-0.84%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -4.67%, versus a -0.77% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Model 3 Frustrations Lead Some Tesla Inc (TSLA) Buyers to Back Out
body:
Tesla Inc’s (NASDAQ:TSLA) production worries are not just a concern for the company and its shareholders. There’s also the little matter of those that have plunked down deposits on the Model 3, and some are questioning their decisions.    more
Marketwatch passes along the take of Vitaliy Katsenelson, CIO at Investment Management Associates, who is reconsidering his choice to purchase a Tesla.
I share this experience because I’m probably not the only one thinking this way. As the dollar meets the road and a lot of Model 3 depositors visit Tesla showrooms, they will likely have similar second thoughts. Consequently, Tesla may discover that lower Model 3 production levels will be sufficient to meet declining demand after a raft of deposit cancellations.
I am not short-selling Tesla stock, and outside of my $1,000 unsecured loan (my deposit) neither my firm or I have a position in Tesla. But it is becoming difficult to see how the Model 3 will be the car that leads Tesla to profitability. As for my deposit, I’ll be getting it back before it’s too late.
Concerns over the production delays are leading to worries that there will be even more bugs and whatnot for early Model 3 customers to deal with. When you add in the fact that we’re not exactly talking about the most budget-friendly vehicle on the market, it’s easy to see why some depositors are suddenly feeling hesitant as negative Tesla headlines continue to swirl around.
It looks like we can count Katsenelson in the camp of those that are thinking twice, and he may get even more company if Tesla’s Model 3 production struggles continue.
Tesla Inc shares rose $1.84 (+0.61%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.32%, versus a -1.64% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Next Up For Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO: Solar City Debt Concerns
body:
Concerns over production goals have been front and center for Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk of late, but that’s not the only issue on his plate at the moment. There’s also the little matter of debts that are coming due, and we’re not just talking about for the carmaker that’s churning through cash at a healthy pace. more
Bloomberg has the details on an additional debt concern for Tesla.
With all the car-making troubles that are hounding Tesla Inc. these days — from the Model 3 bottlenecks to the furious cash burn — it’s easy to overlook the company’s SolarCity headache.
But 16 months after Chief Executive Officer Elon Musk kicked up controversy by acquiring the solar-panel installer founded by two of his cousins, its obligations are a strain on Tesla’s finances. The $2 billion purchase came with a $2.9 billion debt load, and a chunk of that is soon coming due. That’s bad timing for a company churning through about $6,500 a minute and trying to stave off the need for another capital raise.
According to the company, the solar business generated positive cash flow last year. While that may be the case, the debt load has still been a sore spot for shareholders, who are already concerned about the automaker’s own credit and debt concerns.
“SolarCity debt may not be the immediate cause of Tesla’s problems, but it certainly isn’t helping right now,” explained Covenant Review LLC analyst Alexander Diaz-Matos.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.44 (+0.82%) in premarket trading Monday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -3.87%, versus a -2.29% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Addressing Software Update Process for Users
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is rolling out a new feature that will make things easier for owners of its vehicles. Owners will now be able to directly request the latest firmware updates as opposed to waiting for them as they have in the past. more
Teslarati has the details on Tesla’s new feature.
Tesla owners will be given a feature that allows them to request the latest over-the-air firmware update for their vehiccles, according to Elon Musk.
Musk’s latest announcement came as a response to a Tesla owner and podcaster on Twitter. @teslatidbits stated that he spent half an hour poking around his car’s features due to Musk’s earlier references to the Tesla Easter Egg basket. The Tesla enthusiast also noted that he tried unsuccessfully to request an update for his car, especially since the new navigation and maps are currently being rolled out.
That post led to a direct response from Tesla head Elon Musk. “We will add a feature to allow request of latest software version,” Musk wrote. Reaction to the news was positive among Musk’s followers on Twitter.
Once the feature is offered up as Musk promised, Tesla owners will have greater control over when updates will arrive. Currently, updates are rolled out in a gradual manner across the fleet of Tesla vehicles.
Tesla Inc shares fell $7.73 (-2.53%) in premarket trading Friday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -1.81%, versus a -0.06% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #14 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Envisions China Growth, But CEO Believes Tariffs Are Necessary
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) is one of the many companies that could find itself caught in the middle if a trade war between the US and China intensifies, but CEO Elon Musk understands that tariffs may be a necessary part of the game. Musk envisions a future in which China is a huge market for electric vehicles, but he understands President Donald Trump’s concerns about the trade imbalance.  more
CNBC has additional details on how Tesla is somewhat caught in the middle of a potential trade war.
Tesla founder and CEO Elon Musk has long believed China will be a huge driver of electric vehicle sales, even outranking the United States one day. Wall Street analysts have expressed the same belief.
But as the trade war between the United States and China intensifies, Musk finds himself on both sides of the divide. The Chinese government is doing much more to support EVs than the U.S. government right now, but the 25 percent tariff that Tesla and other foreign automakers pay to sell in the Chinese market are steep.
In the past, Musk has come out in favor of the steps that the Chinese government has taken on the regulatory front to encourage the adoption of electric vehicles. However, he has also publicly come out to express support for Trump’s stance, and he noted that China imposes high tariffs on foreign automakers.
We’ll have to wait and see how a potential trade war will eventually play out, but signs continue to point to China being a massive potential market for Tesla regardless.
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $286.94 per share on Wednesday afternoon, up $19.41 (+7.26%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -7.84%, versus a -0.84% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #14 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Tesla Inc's (TSLA) Debt Load Is Eye-Opening
body:
There are plenty of concerns making the rounds about Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) these days, but one of the more eyebrow raising has to do with the amount of debt the company is carrying. While the amount of debt is eye-opening enough, the company’s reported cash burn rate and the fact that its credit rating was recently cut has led to even more questions from investors. more
Automotive News has the details on Tesla’s debt burden.
For Tesla Inc. investors, the question isn’t whether Elon Musk will meet his diminished target this week for Model 3 car production. They’re wondering how he’s going to finance the ones that come later.
Wall Street has pretty much disregarded Musk’s joking April Fools’ tweet over the weekend that the company “has gone completely and totally bankrupt.” But Tesla’s $10 billion debt load is turning into a real burden as cash dwindles and its bonds continue to slide after the electric car maker’s credit rating was cut.
Over the next 12 months, Tesla will reportedly burn through $2 billion in cash and see $1.2 billion of its debt mature. Bruce Clark, a credit analyst at Moody’s Investors Service, notes that the company is probably “going to have to go to the capital markets in the not-too-distant future.” However, he cautions that concerns about production milestones not being met could make raising cash even more difficult for Tesla.
“Their credibility has taken some hits,” he explained.
Tesla Inc shares fell $12.18 (-4.55%) in premarket trading Wednesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -14.07%, versus a -1.89% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
TSLA currently has a StockNews.com POWR Rating of D (Sell), and is ranked #14 of 24 stocks in the Auto & Vehicle Manufacturers category.

heading: Analyst: Tesla Inc (TSLA) Is Still Poised To Disrupt Multiple Industries
body:
While the headlines point to storm clouds surrounding Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA), the company is still in position to disrupt multiple industries. That’s the take from noted tech analyst Gene Munster, who is calling for investors to exercise some patience. more
CNBC passes along Munster’s take on Tesla.
Despite a recent barrage of bad news, Tesla is still poised to disrupt the energy and transportation industries, said tech analyst-turned venture capitalist Gene Munster.
Shares of the electric automaker have fallen under pressure as it is hit with headline after headline. The stock fell 22.4 percent in March, its second-worst month on record. The S&P 500 declined 2.69 percent over the same period.
Among the clouds that have surrounded Tesla are concerns about production numbers, and an ill-advised April Fool’s tweet from CEO Elon Musk that said his company was going “bankwupt.” Despite those and other concerns, Munster notes that he’s “still a believer” in both Musk and Tesla.
“Their mission statement is to accelerate the globe’s adoption rate of renewable energy,” he explained to CNBC. “This has little to do with a car. More about energy’s capture, storage in your home and then ultimately used in a vehicle.”
Tesla Inc shares were trading at $268.43 per share on Tuesday afternoon, up $15.95 (+6.32%). Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -13.79%, versus a -2.04% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.

heading: Tesla Inc (TSLA) CEO Elon Musk Will Directly Oversee Model 3 Production
body:
Tesla Inc (NASDAQ:TSLA) and production concerns seem to go hand in hand these days, but it sounds like CEO Elon Musk has come up with a solution to get to the bottom of things. Musk is now going to directly oversee production of the Model 3, pushing aside another company executive in the process. more
CNBC has the details on the changes at Tesla.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk has taken charge of production of the company’s flagship electric sedan, pushing aside former Apple executive Doug Field, according to The Information.
Field, Tesla’s senior vice president of engineering, will focus on “vehicle engineering,” while Musk focuses on Model 3 production.
Musk has never been shy about laying out ambitious production goals, but Tesla has been unable to execute at that level. Last July, he estimated that 20,000 Model 3’s per month would be rolling off the line by December, but the company has been having a rough time making it to just 2,000 per week.
“Model 3 production is the highest priority at Tesla, so Elon is focusing his time there while Doug focuses on vehicle engineering,” according to a Tesla spokesperson.
Tesla Inc shares rose $2.77 (+1.10%) in premarket trading Tuesday. Year-to-date, TSLA has declined -17.94%, versus a -2.61% rise in the benchmark S&P 500 index during the same period.
